Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Commerce and Trade
===================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 1 - Department of Commerce
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-1 Legislative findings and declarations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that many businesses and occupations in the state have a pronounced physical and economic impact on the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the state.  The Legislature further finds that while the overall impact is generally beneficial to the public, the potential for harm and injury frequently warrants intervention by state government.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-3 Executive director.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-3(1): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The department shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of the executive director of commerce.  The executive director shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate. The executive director shall hold office at the pleasure of the governor. The governor shall establish the executive director's salary within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-3(2): The executive director shall employ personnel necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-4 Centralization of duties.
------------------------------------------------------
The department shall centralize the duties and responsibilities of its divisions and agencies in order to:Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-4(1): reduce and avoid duplication;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-4(2): provide efficient planning and management services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-4(3): maximize utilization of resources.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-5 Executive director's authority over division directors.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The executive director has policymaking and management jurisdiction over directors of the divisions and agencies within the department. He shall appoint the division directors, subject to approval by the governor, unless otherwise provided by law and shall determine their compensation.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-6 Rules and regulations.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-6(1): The executive director shall prescribe rules and procedures for the management and operation of the department, the conduct of its employees, and the custody, use, and preservation of its records, papers, books, documents, and property.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-6(2): (1) The department and its divisions, in contemplation, formulation, and passage of rules pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-7 Budgets.
-------------------------------------
The department shall prepare and submit to the governor a proposed budget for each division or agency within the department to be included in the budget submitted by the governor to the Legislature for the fiscal year following the convening of the Legislature in an annual general session.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-8 Annual report.
-------------------------------------------
The department shall prepare and submit to the governor and the Legislature by October 1 of each year an annual report of the operation, activities and goals of the department, its divisions, and agencies for the preceding fiscal year.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-8.5 Procedures -- Adjudicative proceedings.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-8.5(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The Department of Commerce and its divisions shall comply with the procedures and requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-8.5(2): The department may contract with other state agencies or departments to conduct hearings in its name or in the name of its divisions or agencies.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-11 Employment of administrative law judges.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The department may employ administrative law judges to conduct hearings for the department, its divisions, and agencies, and to advise the executive director, division directors, and agency boards on hearing and rulemaking procedures.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15 Exemptions from licensure.
--------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided by statute or rule, the following individuals may engage in the practice of an occupation or profession regulated by this title, subject to the stated circumstances and limitations, without being licensed under this title:Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15(1): an individual licensed under the laws of this state, other than under this title, to practice or engage in an occupation or profession, while engaged in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15(2): an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States, the United States Public Health Service, the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, or any other federal agency while engaged in activities regulated under this title as a part of employment with that federal agency if the individual holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15(3): the spouse of an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States while the individual is stationed within this state, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15(3)(a): the spouse holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1-15(3)(b): the license is current and the spouse is in good standing in the state or jurisdiction of licensure.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 1a - Division of Corporations and Commercial Code
******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-1 Creation of division -- Responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
There is established within the Department of  Commerce the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code which is responsible for corporation and commercial code filings in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-2 Director to supervise division -- Appointment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of a director.  The director shall be appointed by the executive director of the Department of Commerce with the approval of the governor.  The director shall hold office at the pleasure of the governor.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-3 Employment and compensation of personnel -- Compensation of director.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The director, with the approval of the executive director, may employ personnel necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the division at salaries established by the executive director according to standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.  The executive director shall establish the salary of the director according to standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-4 Annual budget.
--------------------------------------------
On or before the 1st day of October each year, the director shall prepare and submit to the executive director an annual budget of the administrative expenses of the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-5 Authority of director.
----------------------------------------------------
The director has authority:Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-5(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act to make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-5(2): to investigate, upon complaint, the corporation and commercial code filings and compliance governed by the laws administered and enforced by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-5(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act under the provisions of


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-6 Powers of Division of Corporations and Commercial Code -- Document retention.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-6(1): The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code shall have the power and authority reasonably necessary to enable it to efficiently administer the laws and rules for which it is responsible and to perform the duties imposed upon it by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-6(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division has authority under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-6(3): 63A-12-105; Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act Notwithstanding the provisions of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-7 Hearing powers.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-7(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The director, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-7(2): The director or the director's designee, for the purposes outlined in this chapter or any chapter administered by the division, may administer oaths, issue subpoenas, compel the attendance of witnesses, and compel the production of papers, books, accounts, documents, and evidence.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1a-8 Violation of restraining or injunctive order -- Civil penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any restraining order or injunction issued under this chapter is violated, the division may submit a motion for, or the court on its own motion may impose, a civil penalty of not more than $100 for each day a restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction issued under this chapter is violated, if the party has received notice of the restraining order or injunction.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 1b - Office of Professional Licensure Review
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(1): "Department" means the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(2): "Director" means the director of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(3): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4): "Government requestor" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4)(a): the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4)(b): an executive branch officer other than the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4)(c): an executive branch agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4)(d): a legislator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(4)(e): a legislative committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(5): "Health, safety, or financial welfare of the public" includes protecting against physical injury, property damage, or financial harm of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(6): "License" or "licensing" means a state-granted authorization for a person to engage in a specified occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(6)(a): based on the person meeting personal qualifications established under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(6)(b): where state law requires the authorization before the person may lawfully engage in the occupation for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(7): "Newly regulate" means to create by statute or administrative rule a new license, certification, registration, or exemption classification regarding an occupation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(8): "Occupation" means a course of conduct, pursuit, or profession that includes the sale of goods or services that are not illegal to sell, irrespective of whether the individual selling the goods or services is subject to an occupational regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(9): "Office" means the Office of Professional Licensure Review created in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(10): 13-1b-203(2) "Periodic review" means a review described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(a): "Personal qualifications" means criteria established in state law related to an individual's background.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(b): "Personal qualifications" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(b)(i): completion of an approved education program;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(b)(ii): satisfactory performance on an examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(b)(iii): work experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(11)(b)(iv): completion of continuing education.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(12): "Regulated occupation" means an occupation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(12)(a): requires a person to obtain a license to practice the occupation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(12)(b): provides for state certification or state registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(13): "State certification" means a state-granted authorization given to a person to use the term "state certified" as part of a designated title related to engaging in a specified occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(13)(a): based on the person meeting personal qualifications established under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(13)(b): where state law prohibits a noncertified person from using the term "state certified" as part of a designated title but does not otherwise prohibit a noncertified person from engaging in the occupation for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(14): "State registration" means a state-granted authorization given to a person to use the term "state registered" as part of a designated title related to engaging in a specified occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(14)(a): based on the person meeting requirements established under state law, which may include the person's name and address, the person's agent for service of process, the location of the activity to be performed, and bond or insurance requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(14)(b): where state law does not require the person to meet any personal qualifications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(14)(c): where state law prohibits a nonregistered person from using the term "state registered" as part of a designated title.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-101(15): "Sunrise review" means a review under this chapter of an application to establish a new regulated occupation.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-102 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
This chapter applies to any regulation of an occupation that is administered by a state executive branch agency.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-201 Creation of office -- Director appointed -- Personnel.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-201(1): There is created within the department the Office of Professional Licensure Review to perform the functions and duties described in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-201(2): The office is under the direction and control of a director appointed by the executive director with approval of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-201(3): The executive director shall establish the salary of the director in accordance with standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-202 Powers of the director and the office.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-202(1): The director may employ personnel necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the office at salaries determined by the executive director in accordance with standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-202(2)(b): make recommendations to other state executive branch agencies regarding regulated occupations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-202(2)(c): survey stakeholders regarding appropriate criteria for conducting a sunrise review or a periodic review.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-202(3): (2)(b) A state executive branch agency may adopt or reject a recommendation described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301 Application for sunrise review -- Fees.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(1): If a government requestor or a representative of an occupation that is not a regulated occupation proposes that the state make the occupation a regulated occupation, the government requestor or representative shall, before the introduction of any proposed legislation, submit to the office an application for sunrise review in a form the office prescribes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(2): (1) The application described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(2)(a): why making the occupation a regulated occupation is necessary to protect against present, recognizable, and significant harm to the health, safety, or financial welfare of the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(2)(b): the least restrictive regulation of the occupation that would protect against present, recognizable, and significant harm to the health, safety, or financial welfare of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(3): If a representative of an occupation submits an application in accordance with this section, the application shall include a nonrefundable fee of $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-301(4): All application fees collected under this section shall be deposited into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302 Review criteria.
------------------------------------------------
In conducting a sunrise review or a periodic review, unless otherwise directed in accordance with SubsectionUtah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(1): whether the regulation of the occupation is necessary to address a present, recognizable, and significant harm to the health, safety, or financial welfare of the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(2): for any harm to the health, safety, or financial welfare of the public, the harm's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(2)(a): severity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(2)(b): probability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(2)(c): permanence;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(3): (1) the extent to which the proposed or existing regulation of the occupation protects against or diminishes the harm described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4): 31A-22-618 whether the proposed or existing regulation of the occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(a): affects the supply of qualified practitioners;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(b): creates barriers to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(b)(i): service that are not in the public financial welfare or interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(b)(ii): entry into the occupation or related occupations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(c): imposes new costs on existing practitioners;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(d): affects:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(d)(i): license reciprocity with other jurisdictions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(d)(ii): mobility of practitioners; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(4)(e): 31A-22-618 if the occupation involves a health care provider, impacts the health care provider's ability to obtain payment of benefits for the health care provider's treatment of an illness, injury, or health care condition under an insurance contract subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(5): if the review involves licensing, the potential alternative pathways for a person to obtain a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(6): the costs to the state of regulating the occupation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(7): whether the proposed or existing administering agency has sufficient expertise and resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(8): the regulation of the occupation in other jurisdictions;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(9): the scope of the proposed or existing regulation, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(9)(a): whether the occupation is clearly distinguishable from an already regulated occupation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(9)(b): potential for regulating only certain occupational activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(10): the potentially less burdensome alternatives to the proposed or existing regulation and the effect of implementing an alternative method of regulation on:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(10)(a): the health, safety, or financial welfare of the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(10)(b): the occupation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(10)(c): practitioners of the occupation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-302(11): any other criteria the office adopts, including criteria suggested in a stakeholder survey.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-303 Legislative prioritization of reviews.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-303(1): Before October 1 of each year, the office shall prepare and submit to the Business and Labor Interim Committee a list of each periodic review that the office proposes to conduct during the upcoming year, including the scope of each periodic review.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-303(2): (1) Before December 1 of the calendar year in which the office submits a list under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-303(2)(a): approve the list, with or without modification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-303(2)(b): submit a copy of the approved list to the Legislative Management Committee for approval, with or without modification.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-304 Reporting.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-304(1): Beginning in 2024, before October 1, the office shall annually prepare and submit a written report to the Business and Labor Interim Committee that describes the office's work during the prior year.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-304(2): (1) In a written report described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-304(2)(a): a summary of each periodic review, each sunrise review, and each response to a legislator inquiry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-1b-304(2)(b): each recommendation the office made to another state executive branch agency regarding a regulated occupation.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 2 - Division of Consumer Protection
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1 Consumer protection division established -- Functions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(1): There is established within the Department of Commerce the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2): The division shall administer and enforce the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(a): Chapter 10a, Music Licensing Practices Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(b): Chapter 11, Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(c): Chapter 15, Business Opportunity Disclosure Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(d): Chapter 20, New Motor Vehicle Warranties Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(e): Chapter 21, Credit Services Organizations Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(f): Chapter 22, Charitable Solicitations Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(g): Chapter 23, Health Spa Services Protection Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(h): Chapter 25a, Telephone and Facsimile Solicitation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(i): Chapter 26, Telephone Fraud Prevention Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(j): Chapter 28, Prize Notices Regulation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(k): Chapter 32a, Pawnshop, Secondhand Merchandise, and Catalytic Converter Transaction Information Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(l): Chapter 34, Utah Postsecondary School and State Authorization Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(m): Chapter 41, Price Controls During Emergencies Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(n): Chapter 42, Uniform Debt-Management Services Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(o): Chapter 49, Immigration Consultants Registration Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(p): Chapter 51, Transportation Network Company Registration Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(q): Chapter 52, Residential Solar Energy Disclosure Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(r): Chapter 53, Residential, Vocational and Life Skills Program Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(s): Chapter 54, Ticket Website Sales Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(t): Chapter 56, Ticket Transferability Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(u): Chapter 57, Maintenance Funding Practices Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(v): Chapter 61, Utah Consumer Privacy Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(w): Chapter 63, Utah Social Media Regulation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(x): Chapter 64, Vehicle Value Protection Agreement Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(y): Chapter 65, Utah Commercial Email Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(z): Chapter 67, Online Dating Safety Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(2)(aa): Chapter 68, Lawyer Referral Consultants Registration Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the division may make rules to establish:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a): a public list that identifies a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a)(i): violates a chapter described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a)(ii): without proper legal justification, fails to comply with an order, subpoena, judgment, or other legal process issued by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a)(ii)(A): the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a)(ii)(B): a court of competent jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(a)(iii): breaches a settlement agreement, stipulation, assurance of voluntary compliance, or similar instrument signed by the person and the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-1(3)(b): a process by which a person may be removed from the list the division establishes as described in Subsection (3)(a).

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-2 Director of division -- Appointment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The division shall be under the supervision, direction, and control of a director.  The director shall be appointed by the executive director of commerce with the approval of the governor.  The director shall hold office at the pleasure of the governor.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-3 Employment of personnel -- Compensation of director.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-3(1): The director, with the approval of the executive director, may employ personnel necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the division at salaries established by the executive director according to standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-3(2): The executive director shall establish the salary of the director according to standards established by the Division of Human Resource Management.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-3(3): The director may employ specialists, technical experts, or investigators to participate or assist in investigations if they reasonably require expertise beyond that normally required for division personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-3(4): (3); 53-13-105 An investigator employed pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-4 Annual report -- Budget.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-4(1): On or before the 1st day of October each year, the director in connection with the executive director shall report to the governor and the Legislature for the preceding fiscal year on the operations, activities, and goals of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-4(2): The director shall prepare and submit to the executive director a budget of the administrative expenses for the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5 Powers of director.
------------------------------------------------
The director has authority to:Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 13-2-1 in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(2): investigate the activities of any business governed by the laws administered and enforced by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(3): take administrative and judicial action against persons in violation of the division rules and the laws administered and enforced by it, including the issuance of cease and desist orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(4): coordinate, cooperate, and assist with business and industry desiring or attempting to correct unfair business practices between competitors;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(5): provide consumer information and education to the public and assist any organization providing such services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-5(6): coordinate with, assist, and utilize the assistance of federal, state, and local agencies in the performance of the director's duties and the protection of the public.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6 Enforcement powers.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(1): 13-2-1 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act, the division shall have authority to convene administrative hearings, issue cease and desist orders, and impose fines under all the chapters identified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(2): A person who intentionally violates a final cease and desist order entered by the division of which the person has notice is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3): 13-2-1; 63G-4-201; 13-2-1; 13-2-1 If the division has reasonable cause to believe that a person has violated or is violating any chapter listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(a): 63G-4-201 Each citation shall be in writing and shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(a)(i): set forth with particularity the nature of the violation, including a reference to the statutory or administrative rule provision violated;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(a)(ii): state that a request for review of the citation shall be made in writing and be received by the division no more than 20 calendar days after the day on which the division issues the citation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(a)(iii): state the consequences of failing to make a timely request for review; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(a)(iv): 63G-4-201 state all other information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(b): In computing a time period under this section, the following days may not be included:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(b)(i): the day on which the division issues a citation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(b)(ii): the day on which the division receives a request for review of a citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c): 13-2-1; 13-2-1
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(i): 13-2-1 Except as provided in Subsection (3)(c)(iii), if the presiding officer finds that there is not substantial evidence that the recipient violated a chapter listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(i)(A): the citation may not become final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(i)(B): the division shall immediately vacate the citation and promptly notify the recipient in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(ii): 13-2-1 Except as provided in Subsection (3)(c)(iv), if the presiding officer finds that there is substantial evidence that the recipient violated a chapter listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(ii)(A): the citation shall become final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(ii)(B): the division may enter a cease and desist order against the recipient.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iii): For a citation issued for a violation of Chapter 41, Price Controls During Emergencies Act, if the presiding officer finds that there is not clear and convincing evidence that the recipient violated the chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iii)(A): the citation may not become final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iii)(B): the division shall immediately vacate the citation and promptly notify the recipient in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iv): For a citation issued for a violation of Chapter 41, Price Controls During Emergencies Act, if the presiding officer finds that there is clear and convincing evidence that the recipient violated the chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iv)(A): the citation shall become final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(c)(iv)(B): the division may enter a cease and desist order against the recipient.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(d)(i): A citation issued under this chapter may be personally served upon a person upon whom a summons may be served in accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(d)(ii): A citation also may be served by first-class mail, postage prepaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(e)(i): If the recipient fails to make a request for review within 20 calendar days after the day on which the division issues the citation, the citation shall become the final order of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(e)(ii): The period to contest the citation may be extended by the director for good cause shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(3)(f): If the chapter violated allows for an administrative fine, after a citation becomes final, the director may impose the administrative fine.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4): 13-2-1
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(a): 13-2-1 A person who  has violated, is violating, or has attempted  to violate a chapter identified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(a)(i): the violation or attempted violation is committed wholly or partly within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(a)(ii): conduct committed outside the state constitutes an attempt to commit a violation within the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(a)(iii): transactional resources located within the state are used by the offender to directly or indirectly facilitate a violation or attempted violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b): As used in this section, "transactional resources" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(i): a mail drop or mail box, regardless of whether the mail drop or mail box is located on the premises of a United States Post Office;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(ii): a telephone or facsimile transmission device;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(iii): an Internet connection by a resident or inhabitant of this state with a resident- or nonresident-maintained Internet site;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(iv): a business office or private residence used for a business-related purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(v): an account with or services of a financial institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(vi): the services of a common or private carrier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(4)(b)(vii): the use of a city, county, or state asset or facility, including a road or highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(5): The director or the director's designee, for the purposes outlined in a chapter administered by the division, may administer oaths, issue subpoenas, compel the attendance of witnesses, conduct audits, compel sworn responses to written questions, or compel the production of papers, books, accounts, documents, or evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(6): 13-2-1; 13-2-1
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(6)(a): 13-2-1 An administrative action filed under this chapter or a chapter listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(6)(b): 13-2-1 A civil action filed under this chapter or a chapter listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-6(6)(c): The provisions of this Subsection (6) control over the provisions of Title 78B, Chapter 2, Statutes of Limitations.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-7 Violation of restraining or injunctive order -- Civil penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any restraining order, any chapter administered by the division, or injunction granted under this chapter is violated, the division may submit a motion for, or the court on its own motion, may impose a civil penalty of not more than $2,000 for each day a temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction or permanent injunction issued under this chapter is violated, if the party has received notice of the restraining or injunctive order.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-8 Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-8(1): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the "Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12 Generative artificial intelligence -- Impact on liability for violation of consumer protection law.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(a): "Generative artificial intelligence" means an artificial system that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(a)(i): is trained on data;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(a)(ii): interacts with a person using text, audio, or visual communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(a)(iii): generates non-scripted outputs similar to outputs created by a human, with limited or no human oversight.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(b): "License" means a state-granted authorization for a person to engage in a specified occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(b)(i): based on the person meeting personal qualifications established under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(b)(ii): where state law requires the authorization before the person may lawfully engage in the occupation for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(c): "Regulated occupation" means an occupation regulated by the Department of Commerce that requires a person to obtain a license or state certification to practice the occupation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(d): "State certification" means a state-granted authorization given to a person to use the term "state certified" as part of a designated title related to engaging in a specified occupation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(d)(i): based on the person meeting personal qualifications established under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(1)(d)(ii): where state law prohibits a noncertified person from using the term "state certified" as part of a designated title but does not otherwise prohibit a noncertified person from engaging in the occupation for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(2): 13-2-1 It is not a defense to the violation of any statute administered and enforced by the division, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(2)(a): made the violative statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(2)(b): undertook the violative act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(2)(c): was used in furtherance of the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(3): 13-2-1 A person who uses, prompts, or otherwise causes generative artificial intelligence to interact with a person in connection with any act administered and enforced by the division, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(4)(a): A person who provides the services of a regulated occupation shall prominently disclose when a person is interacting with a generative artificial intelligence in the provision of regulated services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(4)(b): Nothing in this section permits a person to provide the services of a regulated occupation through generative artificial intelligence without meeting the requirements of the regulated occupation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(5): A disclosure described Subsection (4)(a) shall be provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(5)(a): verbally at the start of an oral exchange or conversation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(5)(b): through electronic messaging before a written exchange.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(6): The division shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section in accordance with Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(7): In addition to the division's enforcement powers described by Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(7)(a): the division director may impose an administrative fine for up to $2,500 for each violation of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(7)(b): the division may bring an action in court to enforce a provision of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(8)(b): issue an injunction for a violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(8)(c): order disgorgement of any money received in violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(8)(d): order payment of disgorged money to a person injured by a violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(8)(e): impose a fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(8)(f): award any other relief that the court deems reasonable and necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(9): If a court of competent jurisdiction grants judgment or injunctive relief to the division, the court shall award the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(9)(a): reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(9)(b): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(9)(c): investigative fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(10)(a): A person who violates an administrative or court order issued for a violation of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty of no more than $5,000 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-2-12(10)(b): A civil penalty authorized under this section may be imposed in any civil action brought by the attorney general on behalf of the division.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 5b - Integrated Health System Fair Practices Act
*****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Integrated Health System Fair Practices Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
For purposes of this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(1): "Affiliate" means an organization that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(2): "Integrated health system" means an organization that directly, or through an affiliate or subsidiary:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(2)(a): owns and operates one or more hospitals in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(2)(b): offers health insurance to residents of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(3): "Subsidiary" means an affiliate controlled:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(3)(a): by a specified person;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(3)(b): directly or indirectly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-5b-102(3)(c): through one or more intermediaries.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 7 - Civil Rights
*********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-1 Policy and purposes of act.
--------------------------------------------------------
It is hereby declared that the practice of discrimination on the basis of race, color, sex, pregnancy, religion, ancestry, or national origin in business establishments or places of public accommodation or in enterprises regulated by the state endangers the health, safety, and general welfare of this state and its inhabitants; and that such discrimination in business establishments or places of public accommodation or in enterprises regulated by the state, violates the public policy of this state. It is the purpose of this act to assure all citizens full and equal availability of all goods, services and facilities offered by business establishments and places of public accommodation and enterprises regulated by the state without discrimination because of race, color, sex, pregnancy, religion, ancestry, or national origin. The rules of common law that statutes in derogation thereof shall be strictly construed has no application to this act.  This act shall be liberally construed with a view to promote the policy and purposes of the act and to promote justice. The remedies provided herein are not exclusive but are in addition to any other remedies available at law or equity.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(1): Title 70C, Utah Consumer Credit Code; Title 32B, Alcoholic Beverage Control Act; Title 31A, Insurance Code; Title 54, Public Utilities "Enterprise regulated by the state" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(1)(a): Title 70C, Utah Consumer Credit Code an institution subject to regulation under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(1)(b): Title 32B, Alcoholic Beverage Control Act a place of business that sells an alcoholic product at retail as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(1)(c): Title 31A, Insurance Code an insurer regulated by
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(1)(d): Title 54, Public Utilities a public utility subject to regulation under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(2): "Person" includes  an individual, partnership, association, organization, corporation, labor union, legal representative, trustee, trustee in bankruptcy, receiver, and other organized groups of persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(a): "Place of public accommodation" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(a)(i): every place, establishment, or facility of whatever kind, nature, or class that caters or offers services, facilities, or goods to the general public for a fee or charge, except, an establishment that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(a)(i)(A): located within a building that contains not more than five rooms for rent or hire; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(a)(i)(B): actually occupied by the proprietor of the establishment as the proprietor's residence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(a)(ii): a place, establishment, or facility that caters or offers services, facilities, or goods to the general public gratuitously  if the place, establishment, or facility  receives any substantial governmental subsidy or support.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(3)(b): "Place of public accommodation" does not include an institution, church, apartment house, club, or place of accommodation that is in nature distinctly private except to the extent that  the institution, church, apartment house, club, or place of accommodation  is open to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(4): "Pregnancy" includes pregnancy or a pregnancy-related condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-2(5): "Pregnancy-related condition" includes breastfeeding, lactation, or a medical condition related to breastfeeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-3 Equal right in business establishments, places of public accommodation, and enterprises regulated by the state.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-3(1): All persons within the jurisdiction of this state are free and equal and are entitled to full and equal accommodations, advantages, facilities, privileges, goods and services in all business establishments and in all places of public accommodation, and by all enterprises regulated by the state of every kind whatsoever, without discrimination on the basis of race, color, sex, pregnancy, religion, ancestry or national origin.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-3(2): Nothing in this act shall be construed to deny any person the right to regulate the operation of a business establishment or place of public accommodation or an enterprise regulated by the state in a manner which applies uniformly to all persons without regard to race, color, sex, pregnancy, religion, ancestry, or national origin; or to deny any religious organization the right to regulate the operation and procedures of its establishments.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-3(3): Nothing in this act regulates business website accessibility.

Upon the trial of the cause, on finding that the material allegations of the complaint are true, the court shall order such nuisance to be abated, and enjoin all persons from maintaining or permitting such nuisance.  When any injunction as herein provided has been granted it shall be binding upon the defendant and shall act as an injunction in personam against the defendant throughout the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-4(3): 13-7-3; 13-7-3 Any person who is denied the rights provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-4(4): Any business establishment or place of public accommodation or enterprises regulated by the state charged with maintaining a public nuisance in violation of this chapter, which is determined or found not to be in violation of this chapter, may be awarded all actual and necessary expenses incurred in defending such action, as determined and approved by the court having jurisdiction of the matter.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-7-5(1): As used in this section, "immunity status" means an indication of whether an individual is immune to a disease, whether through vaccination or infection and recovery.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2 Contractual limitations of liability arising from services of design professionals prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(a): "Agreement" means a contract, promise, covenant, or understanding.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(b): "Contractor" means any person engaged by an owner to develop or assist in the development of the owner's land.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(c): "Design professional" means an architect, engineer, or land surveyor.  It includes any other person who, for a fee or other compensation, performs services similar to the services of an architect, engineer, or land surveyor in connection with the development of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(d): "Development" means the construction, alteration, repair, maintenance, or improvement of land, including any related moving, demolition, or excavation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(e): "Land" means any real property, including any building, fixture, improvement, appurtenance, structure, road, highway, or other development.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(f): "Liability" includes liability arising by contract, indemnity, contribution, tort, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(g): "Owner" means the holder of any legal or equitable title or interest in property.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(1)(h): "Subcontractor" means any person engaged by a contractor to develop or assist in the development of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(2): An agreement between an owner and a contractor may not limit the owner's or a design professional's liability to the contractor for any claim arising from services performed by the design professional in connection with the development of land.  This subsection does not apply if the owner and the contractor are the same person or entity or are controlled by the same person or entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(3): An agreement between a contractor and a subcontractor may not limit the owner's or a design professional's liability to the subcontractor for any claim arising from services performed by the design professional in connection with the development of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(4): This section does not apply if the design professional is retained under a single contract to perform both the design and the construction of the project, such as in a design-build or turn-key project.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(5): This section may not be construed to affect any limitation of a design professional's liability to an owner or other design professional that may exist in an agreement between the owner and the design professional or between design professionals.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-2(6): This section does not affect or impair the obligations of agreements in existence as of May 1, 1988.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-3(1)(e): supplier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-3(1)(f): (1)(a); (e) any combination of the persons described under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-3(2): A provision in a construction agreement requiring a dispute arising under the agreement to be resolved in a forum outside of this state is void and unenforceable as against the public policy of this state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-3(2)(a): one of the parties to the agreement is domiciled in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-3(2)(b): work to be done and the equipment and materials to be supplied under the agreement involves a construction project in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-8-4(2): A party to a construction contract shall make all scheduled payments under the terms of the construction contract.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 9 - Foreign Trade
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-9-1 "Foreign-Trade Zones Act" defined.
---------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this act:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-9-2 Authority of state, county or municipality or public or private corporation to apply to establish foreign-trade zone.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The state of Utah or any county or municipality within the state of Utah, or a public or private corporation, or any combination thereof, may apply to the Foreign-Trade Zones Board, United States Department of Commerce, for the right to establish, operate, and maintain a foreign-trade zone as defined in the Foreign-Trade Zones Act.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 10 - Unauthorized Recording Practices Act
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-1 Title of chapter.
-----------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Unauthorized Recording Practices Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-2 Purpose of chapter.
-------------------------------------------------
In enacting this chapter, it is the purpose of the Legislature to prevent the piracy of recorded materials by making it mandatory that certain copying of recorded materials be made only with the express consent of the owner.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-3 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-3(1): "Fixed" means embodied in a recording or other tangible medium of expression, by or under the authority of the author, so that the matter embodied in the recording or other tangible medium of expression is sufficiently permanent or stable to permit it to be perceived, reproduced, or otherwise communicated for a period of more than transitory duration.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-3(2): "Owner" means the person, corporation, partnership, or business association who owns the sounds fixed in a master phonograph record, master disc, master wire, master tape, master film, or other device used for reproducing recorded sounds on phonograph records, discs, wires, tapes, films, or other articles or materials in which sound is recorded and from which the transferred recorded sounds are directly or indirectly derived.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-4 Prohibited practices.
---------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any individual, partnership, corporation, or association:Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-4(1): to knowingly transfer or cause to be transferred, directly or indirectly, for sale or profit within this state, without the express consent of the owner, by any means, any sounds recorded on a phonographic record, disc, wire, tape, film, or other article or material on which sounds are recorded onto any other phonograph record, disc, wire, tape, film, article, or material;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-4(2): to sell, distribute, circulate, or offer for sale, distribution or circulation, or cause to be sold, distributed, circulated, or possess for the purpose of sale, distribution, or circulation, within the state, for a consideration, any phonograph record, disc, wire, tape, film, or other article or material onto which such sounds have been transferred, with the knowledge that the sounds thereon have been transferred without the express consent of the owner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-4(3): to knowingly rent, make available, or permit the use of, or offer to rent, make available, or permit the use of, for a fee, rental, or any other form of compensation, any equipment or machinery for the purpose of enabling, aiding, or causing another to transfer without the consent of the owner any sounds recorded on a phonograph record, disc, wire, tape, film, or other article or material onto any other phonograph record, disc, wire, tape, film, article, or material.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-5 Exemptions.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-5(1): 13-10-3; 13-10-4 This chapter does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-5(1)(a): 13-10-3; 13-10-4 any person engaged in radio or television broadcasting or cable television who transfers, or causes to be transferred, any of the sounds referred to in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-5(1)(b): any person transferring any such sounds without any compensation being derived by this person or any other person from the transfer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-5(2): This chapter shall neither enlarge nor diminish the rights of parties in civil litigation.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-6 Violation a misdemeanor.
------------------------------------------------------
Each violation of Section

--------------------------------------------------------
Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8 Failure to disclose the origin of a recording -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(1): For purposes of this section "recording" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(1)(a): a tangible medium on which sounds or images are recorded or otherwise stored, including an original phonograph record, disc, tape, audio or video cassette, wire, film, or other similar medium; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(1)(b): a copy or reproduction that duplicates the original in whole or in part.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2): (2)(a)(i); (ii) A person is guilty of failure to disclose the origin of a recording if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2)(a): (2)(a)(i); (ii) the person commits any of the following acts for commercial advantage or private financial gain:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2)(a)(i): offers a recording for sale, resale, or rent;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2)(a)(ii): sells, resells, rents, leases, or lends a recording; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2)(a)(iii): (2)(a)(i); (ii) possesses a recording for any of the purposes described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(2)(b): the person knows that the recording does not contain the true name and address of the manufacturer in a prominent place on its cover, jacket, or label.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(3): (2) A person who fails to disclose the origin of a recording under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(3)(a): a felony of the third degree if the offense involves 100 or more recordings, or the commercial equivalent of 100 or more recordings, during a 180-day period or if the person has previously been convicted of a violation of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(3)(b): a class A misdemeanor if the offense involves at least 10 recordings and fewer than 100 recordings, or the commercial equivalent of at least 10 recordings and fewer than 100 recordings, during a 180-day period; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10-8(3)(c): a class B misdemeanor if the offense involves fewer than 10 recordings or fewer than the commercial equivalent of 10 recordings.
