Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 10a - Music Licensing Practices Act
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-1 Title.
-------------------------------------
This act is known as the "Music Licensing Practices Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(1): "Copyright laws of the United States" means those laws specified pursuant to Title 17, United States Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(2): "Copyright owner" does not include the owner of a copyright in a motion picture or audio-visual work or a part of a motion picture or audio-visual work.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(3): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(4): "Performing rights society or organization" means an association, corporation, or other entity that licenses the nondramatic public performance of musical works on behalf of copyright owners, such as the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP), Broadcast Music, Inc. (BMI), and SESAC, Inc.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(5): "Proprietor" means the owner of a retail establishment, restaurant, inn, bar, tavern, sports or entertainment facility, not for profit organization, or any other place of business or professional office located in this state in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(5)(a): the public may assemble; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(5)(b): musical works may be performed, broadcast, or otherwise transmitted for the enjoyment of the members of the public there assembled.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-2(6): "Royalty" or "royalties" means the fees payable by a proprietor to a performing rights society for the nondramatic public performance of musical or other similar works.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3 Access to repertoire.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(1): Each performing rights society or organization licensing music in the state shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(1)(a): maintain a current electronic list of the titles and names of the authors and publishers of all performed copyrighted musical works for which the performing rights society collects royalties on behalf of copyright owners;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(1)(b): update the list at least quarterly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(1)(c): provide to the division the electronic address at which the list may be viewed.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(2): Upon request, any person may review the list, in electronic form, of copyrighted works through the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(3): Each performing rights society or organization shall provide an electronic or printed copy of its most current lists of copyrighted musical works and members at cost, not including the cost of maintaining the database or any other overhead, to any person upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-3(4): Each performing rights society or organization licensing music in this state shall establish and maintain a toll free telephone number which can be used to answer inquiries regarding specific musical works licensed by that performing rights society and the copyright owners represented by the performing rights society or organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-4 Notification of rights.
------------------------------------------------------
No performing rights society or organization may enter into, or offer to enter into, a contract for the payment of royalties by a proprietor unless at the time of the offer, or any time thereafter, but no later than 72 hours prior to the execution of the contract, it provides to the proprietor, in writing, a schedule of the rates and terms of royalties under the contract, including:Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-4(1): any sliding scale, discounts, or reductions in fees on any basis for which the proprietor may be eligible; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-4(2): any scheduled increases or decreases in fees during the term of the contract.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5 Contract requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1): Beginning July 1, 1998, each contract for the payment of royalties between a proprietor and a performing rights society or organization executed, issued, or renewed in the state shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(a): be in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(b): be signed by both parties to the contract; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(c): include at least the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(c)(i): the proprietor's name and business address and the name and location of each place of business to which the contract applies;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(c)(ii): the name and business address of the performing rights society or organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(c)(iii): the duration of the contract; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(1)(c)(iv): the schedule of rates and terms of royalties to be collected under the contract, including any sliding scale, discount, or schedule for any increase or decrease of those rates for the duration of the contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(2)(a): Nothing in this act shall be construed to affect any contract signed before July 1, 1998.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-5(2)(b): All contracts signed before July 1, 1998, that are renewed after that date are subject to the requirements of this act.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-6 Jurisdiction of court action.
------------------------------------------------------------
An action may be brought or a counterclaim may be asserted in a court of competent jurisdiction against a performing rights society to enjoin a violation of this act and to recover actual damages sustained as a result of that violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-7 Provisions of chapter not exclusive.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The remedies, duties, and prohibitions of this chapter are not exclusive and are in addition to all other causes of actions, remedies, and penalties provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-8 Exemptions.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-8(1): This act does not apply to contracts between performing rights societies or organizations and broadcasters licensed by the Federal Communications Commission, unless any such society is licensed by the Federal Communications Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10a-8(2): 13-10-8(2)(b) This act does not apply to investigations by law enforcement agencies or other persons with respect to suspected violations of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 10b - Unlawful Recording of a Motion Picture
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Unlawful Recording of a Motion Picture."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-102(1): "Audiovisual recording function" means the capability of a device to record or transmit a motion picture or any part of the motion picture by means of any technology.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-102(2): 13-10b-201 "Motion picture theater" means a movie theater, screening room, or other venue that is being utilized primarily for the exhibition of a motion picture at the time of the commission of an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-102(3): "Owner or employee" means the owner or lessee of a motion picture theater, or the authorized agent or employee of the owner or lessee.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201 Unlawful recording of a motion picture -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(1): It is unlawful for any individual to knowingly operate the audiovisual recording function of any camcorder or similar device in a motion picture theater:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(1)(a): while a motion picture is being exhibited; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(1)(b): without the consent of the motion picture theater owner or operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(2)(a): A violation of this section is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-201(2)(b): A second or subsequent violation of this section is a third degree felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301 Detention of suspect by owner or employee.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1): 13-10b-201; 13-10b-201; 13-10b-201 Any owner or employee who has probable cause to believe that an individual has unlawfully recorded a motion picture under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(a): 13-10b-201 make reasonable inquiry as to whether the individual has in his possession a device that may reasonably be used in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(b): request identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(c): verify the identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(d): 13-10b-201 make a reasonable request of the individual to place or keep in full view any device that the employer or employee has reason to believe the individual may have used in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(e)(i): inform a peace officer of the detention of the individual and surrender that individual to the custody of a peace officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(1)(e)(ii): in the case of a minor, inform a peace officer, the parents, or the legal guardian of this detention and to surrender custody of the minor to the responding individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-301(2): (1); 13-10b-201 An employer or employee may make a detention under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-302 Immunity of owner or employee who contacts law enforcement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The owner or employee of a motion picture theater who advises a law enforcement agency of an alleged violation of this section is not liable in any civil action that arises out of detaining an individual under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 13-10b-401 Law enforcement functions exempt.
------------------------------------------------------------------
This part does not prohibit any lawful investigation or collection of evidence by a federal, state, or local law enforcement or investigative agency by means of any audiovisual recording device used in a motion picture theater as part of investigative, protective, or law enforcement functions.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 11 - Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act
*******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-1 Citation of act.
----------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2 Construction and purposes of act.
---------------------------------------------------------------
This act shall be construed liberally to promote the following policies:Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(1): to simplify, clarify, and modernize the law governing consumer sales practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(2): to protect consumers from suppliers who commit deceptive and unconscionable sales practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(3): to encourage the development of fair consumer sales practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(4): to make state regulation of consumer sales practices not inconsistent with the policies of the Federal Trade Commission Act relating to consumer protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(5): to make uniform the law, including the administrative rules, with respect to the subject of this act among those states which enact similar laws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-2(6): to recognize and protect suppliers who in good faith comply with the provisions of this act.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(1): "Charitable solicitation" means any request directly or indirectly for money, credit, property, financial assistance, or any other thing of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable purpose.  A charitable solicitation may be made in any manner, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(1)(a): any oral or written request, including a telephone request;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(1)(b): the distribution, circulation, or posting of any handbill, written advertisement, or publication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(1)(c): the sale of, offer or attempt to sell, or request of donations for any book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket, flower, flag, button, sticker, ribbon, token, trinket, tag, souvenir, candy, or any other article in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable purpose, or where the name of any charitable organization or movement is used or referred to as an inducement or reason for making any purchase donation, or where, in connection with any sale or donation, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds of any sale or donation will go to or be donated to any charitable purpose.  A charitable solicitation is considered complete when made, whether or not the organization or person making the solicitation receives any contribution or makes any sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(a): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a) "Consumer transaction" means a sale, lease, assignment, award by chance, or other written or oral transfer or disposition of goods, services, or other property, both tangible and intangible (except securities and insurance) to, or apparently to, a person for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(a)(i): primarily personal, family, or household purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a) purposes that relate to a business opportunity that requires:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(a)(ii)(A): (2)(a) expenditure of money or property by the person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(a)(ii)(B): (2)(a); (2)(a) the person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b): (2)(a) "Consumer transaction" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) any of the following with respect to a transfer or disposition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(i)(A): an offer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(i)(B): a solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(i)(C): an agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(i)(D): performance of an agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(2)(b)(ii): a charitable solicitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(3): "Enforcing authority" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(4): "Final judgment" means a judgment, including any supporting opinion, that determines the rights of the parties and concerning which appellate remedies have been exhausted or the time for appeal has expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(5): "Person" means an individual, corporation, government, governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, cooperative, or any other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-3(6): "Supplier" means a seller, lessor, assignor, offeror, broker, or other person who regularly solicits, engages in, or enforces consumer transactions, whether or not he deals directly with the consumer.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4 Deceptive act or practice by supplier.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(1): A deceptive act or practice by a supplier in connection with a consumer transaction violates this chapter whether it occurs before, during, or after the transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2): 7-1-103; 15-10-201; 13-59-201; 13-54-202 Without limiting the scope of Subsection (1), a supplier commits a deceptive act or practice if the supplier knowingly or intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(a): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction has sponsorship, approval, performance characteristics, accessories, uses, or benefits, if it has not;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(b): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction is of a particular standard, quality, grade, style, or model, if it is not;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(c): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction is new, or unused, if it is not, or has been used to an extent that is materially different from the fact;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction is available to the consumer for a reason that does not exist, including any of the following reasons falsely used in an advertisement:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(i): "going out of business";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(ii): "bankruptcy sale";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(iii): "lost our lease";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(iv): "building coming down";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(v): "forced out of business";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(vi): "final days";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(vii): "liquidation sale";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(viii): "fire sale";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(ix): "quitting business"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(d)(x): an expression similar to any of the expressions in Subsections (2)(d)(i) through (ix);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(e): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction has been supplied in accordance with a previous representation, if it has not;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(f): indicates that the subject of a consumer transaction will be supplied in greater quantity than the supplier intends;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(g): indicates that replacement or repair is needed, if it is not;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(h): indicates that a specific price advantage exists, if it does not;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(i): indicates that the supplier has a sponsorship, approval, license, certification, or affiliation the supplier does not have;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(j): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(j)(i): indicates that a consumer transaction involves or does not involve a warranty, a disclaimer of warranties, particular warranty terms, or other rights, remedies, or obligations, if the representation is false; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(j)(ii): fails to honor a warranty or a particular warranty term;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(k): indicates that the consumer will receive a rebate, discount, or other benefit as an inducement for entering into a consumer transaction in return for giving the supplier the names of prospective consumers or otherwise helping the supplier to enter into other consumer transactions, if receipt of the benefit is contingent on an event occurring after the consumer enters into the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(l): after receipt of payment for goods or services, fails to ship the goods or furnish the services within the time advertised or otherwise represented or, if no specific time is advertised or represented, fails to ship the goods or furnish the services within 30 days, unless within the applicable time period the supplier provides the buyer with the option to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(l)(i): cancel the sales agreement and receive a refund of all previous payments to the supplier if the refund is mailed or delivered to the buyer within 10 business days after the day on which the seller receives written notification from the buyer of the buyer's intent to cancel the sales agreement and receive the refund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(l)(ii): extend the shipping date to a specific date proposed by the supplier;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(m): except as provided in Subsection (3)(b), fails to furnish a notice meeting the requirements of Subsection (3)(a) of the purchaser's right to cancel a direct solicitation sale within three business days of the time of purchase if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(m)(i): the sale is made other than at the supplier's established place of business pursuant to the supplier's personal contact, whether through mail, electronic mail, facsimile transmission, telephone, or any other form of direct solicitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(m)(ii): the sale price exceeds $25;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(n): promotes, offers, or grants participation in a pyramid scheme as defined under Title 76, Chapter 6a, Pyramid Scheme Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o): in connection with a charitable solicitation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i): falsely indicates that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(A): the supplier is affiliated with a charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(B): the supplier is an employee, officer, or representative of a public safety agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(C): the supplier has sponsorship or approval of a given charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(D): a charitable contribution will be provided to a given charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(E): providing a charitable contribution has an additional benefit, including a tax benefit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(i)(F): the recipient of the solicitation has previously contributed to a given charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(ii): uses a fictitious name or a name the supplier is not authorized to use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(iii): with intent to deceive:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(iii)(A): uses a name that is substantially similar to that of another charitable organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(o)(iii)(B): falsely indicates that a charitable contribution will be used for a particular purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p): if a consumer indicates the consumer's intention of making a claim for a motor vehicle repair against the consumer's motor vehicle insurance policy:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(i): commences the repair without first giving the consumer oral and written notice of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(i)(A): the total estimated cost of the repair; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(i)(B): the total dollar amount the consumer is responsible to pay for the repair, which dollar amount may not exceed the applicable deductible or other copay arrangement in the consumer's insurance policy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(ii): requests or collects from a consumer an amount that exceeds the dollar amount a consumer was initially told the consumer was responsible to pay as an insurance deductible or other copay arrangement for a motor vehicle repair under Subsection (2)(p)(i), even if that amount is less than the full amount the motor vehicle insurance policy requires the insured to pay as a deductible or other copay arrangement, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(ii)(A): the consumer's insurance company denies that coverage exists for the repair, in which case, the full amount of the repair may be charged and collected from the consumer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(p)(ii)(B): the consumer misstates, before the repair is commenced, the amount of money the insurance policy requires the consumer to pay as a deductible or other copay arrangement, in which case, the supplier may charge and collect from the consumer an amount that does not exceed the amount the insurance policy requires the consumer to pay as a deductible or other copay arrangement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(q): includes in any contract, receipt, or other written documentation of a consumer transaction, or any addendum to any contract, receipt, or other written documentation of a consumer transaction, any confession of judgment or any waiver of any of the rights to which a consumer is entitled under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(r): charges a consumer for a consumer transaction or a portion of a consumer transaction that has not previously been agreed to by the consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(s): solicits or enters into a consumer transaction with a person who lacks the mental ability to comprehend the nature and consequences of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(s)(i): the consumer transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(s)(ii): the person's ability to benefit from the consumer transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(t): 7-1-103 solicits for the sale of a product or service by providing a consumer with an unsolicited check or negotiable instrument the presentment or negotiation of which obligates the consumer to purchase a product or service, unless the supplier is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(t)(i): 7-1-103 a depository institution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(t)(ii): an affiliate of a depository institution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(t)(iii): an entity regulated under Title 7, Financial Institutions Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(u): sends an unsolicited mailing to a person that appears to be a billing, statement, or request for payment for a product or service the person has not ordered or used, or that implies that the mailing requests payment for an ongoing product or service the person has not received or requested;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(v): issues a gift certificate, instrument, or other record in exchange for payment to provide the bearer, upon presentation, goods or services in a specified amount without printing in a readable manner on the gift certificate, instrument, packaging, or record any expiration date or information concerning a fee to be charged and deducted from the balance of the gift certificate, instrument, or other record;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(w): misrepresents the geographical origin or location of the supplier's business;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(x): 15-10-201 fails to comply with the restrictions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(y): 13-59-201 violates Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(z): 13-54-202 fails to comply with the restrictions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(2)(aa): states or implies that a registration or application administered or enforced by the division is an endorsement, sanction, or approval by the division or a governmental agency or office.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(a): The notice required by Subsection (2)(m) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(a)(i): be a conspicuous statement written in dark bold with at least 12-point type on the first page of the purchase documentation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(a)(ii): read as follows: "YOU, THE BUYER, MAY CANCEL THIS CONTRACT AT ANY TIME PRIOR TO MIDNIGHT OF THE THIRD BUSINESS DAY (or time period reflecting the supplier's cancellation policy but not less than three business days) AFTER THE DATE OF THE TRANSACTION OR RECEIPT OF THE PRODUCT, WHICHEVER IS LATER."
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(b): A supplier is exempt from the requirements of Subsection (2)(m) if the supplier's cancellation policy:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(b)(i): is communicated to the buyer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(3)(b)(ii): offers greater rights to the buyer than Subsection (2)(m).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(4)(a): A gift certificate, instrument, or other record that does not print an expiration date in accordance with Subsection (2)(v) does not expire.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(4)(b): A gift certificate, instrument, or other record that does not include printed information concerning a fee to be charged and deducted from the balance of the gift certificate, instrument, or other record is not subject to the charging and deduction of the fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4(4)(c): Subsections (2)(v) and (4)(b) do not apply to a gift certificate, instrument, or other record useable at multiple, unaffiliated sellers of goods or services if an expiration date is printed on the gift certificate, instrument, or other record.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1 Targeted solicitations involving financial information -- Restrictions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1): 61-2c-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(a): "Account holder" means a person for whom a personal account is held by a financial institution.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b): 61-2c-102 "Financial institution" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i): a state or federally chartered:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i)(A): bank;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i)(B): savings and loan association;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i)(C): savings bank;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i)(D): industrial bank; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(i)(E): credit union;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(ii): any other institution under the jurisdiction of the commissioner of Financial Institutions as described in Title 7, Financial Institutions Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(iii): 61-2c-102 a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(iii)(A): is subject to Title 61, Chapter 2c, Utah Residential Mortgage Practices and Licensing Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(b)(iii)(B): 61-2c-102 engages in the business of residential mortgage loans as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(i): "Specific account information" means information that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(i)(A): relative to the account of an account holder, in addition to the name of the account holder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(i)(B): not provided by the financial institution that holds the account holder's account to the person offering a targeted solicitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(ii): "Specific account information" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(ii)(A): a loan number;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(ii)(B): a loan amount; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(c)(ii)(C): any other specific account or loan information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(d): "Targeted solicitation" means any written or oral advertisement or solicitation for products or services that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(d)(i): is addressed to an account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(d)(ii): contains specific account information;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(d)(iii): is offered by a supplier that is not sponsored by or affiliated with the financial institution that holds the account holder's account; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(1)(d)(iv): is not authorized by the financial institution that holds the account holder's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2)(a): A supplier who is not the financial institution of an account holder may not represent, directly or indirectly, that the supplier is the financial institution of the account holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2)(b): If a presiding officer or court determines appropriate after considering other relevant factors, the following actions by a supplier who is not the financial institution of an account holder establish a presumption that the supplier is representing that the supplier is the financial institution of the account holder in violation of Subsection (2)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2)(b)(i): the use or reference to the name, trade name, or trademark of the financial institution of the account holder, when sending a targeted solicitation, unless the supplier has written authorization from the financial institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2)(b)(ii): the placement of specific account information on the outside of an envelope, visible through the envelope window, or on a postcard, when sending a targeted solicitation by direct mail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(2)(b)(iii): the placement of specific account information in the subject line, when sending a targeted solicitation by email.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(3)(a): A targeted solicitation, if offered in writing, shall include a clear and conspicuous statement in bold type on the front page of the document containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(3)(a)(i): the name, address, and telephone number of the supplier offering the targeted solicitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(3)(a)(ii): a statement indicating that the supplier offering the targeted solicitation is not sponsored by or affiliated with the financial institution that holds the account holder's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(3)(b): If the targeted solicitation is offered orally, the supplier offering the targeted solicitation shall verbally communicate the statement described in Subsection (3)(a) at the time the oral solicitation is offered to the account holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-4.1(4): 13-11-4 A supplier who violates this section commits a deceptive act or practice under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-5 Unconscionable act or practice by supplier.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-5(1): An unconscionable act or practice by a supplier in connection with a consumer transaction violates this act whether it occurs before, during, or after the transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-5(2): The unconscionability of an act or practice is a question of law for the court. If it is claimed or appears to the court that an act or practice may be unconscionable, the parties shall be given a reasonable opportunity to present evidence as to its setting, purpose, and effect to aid the court in making its determination.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-5(3): In determining whether an act or practice is unconscionable, the court shall consider circumstances which the supplier knew or had reason to know.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6 Service of process.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(1): In addition to any other method provided by rule or statute, personal jurisdiction over a supplier may be acquired in a civil action or proceeding instituted in a court of this state by the service of process as provided in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(2)(a): A supplier that engages in any act or practice in this state governed by this chapter, or engages in a consumer transaction subject to this chapter, may designate an agent upon whom service of process may be made in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(2)(b): A designation of an agent under Subsection (2)(a) shall be in writing and filed with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(2)(c): An agent designated under this Subsection (2) shall be a resident of or a corporation authorized to do business in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3): 16-17-301
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(a): 16-17-301 Subject to Subsection (3)(b), process upon a supplier may be served as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(a)(i): a designation is not made and filed under Subsection (2); or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(a)(ii): process cannot be served in the state upon the designated agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(b): Service upon a supplier is not effective unless the plaintiff promptly mails a copy of the process and pleadings by registered or certified mail to the defendant at the defendant's last reasonably ascertainable address.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(c): The plaintiff shall file an affidavit of compliance with this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(c)(i): with the clerk of the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-6(3)(c)(ii): on or before the return day of the process, if any, or within any future time the court allows.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7 Duties of enforcing authority -- Confidentiality of identity of persons investigated -- Civil penalty for violation of restraining or injunctive orders.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1): The enforcing authority shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1)(a): enforce this chapter throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1)(b): cooperate with state and local officials, officials of other states, and officials of the federal government in the administration of comparable statutes;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1)(c): inform consumers and suppliers on a continuing basis of the provisions of this chapter and of acts or practices that violate this chapter ;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1)(d): receive and act on complaints; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(1)(e): maintain a public file of final judgments rendered under this chapter that have been either reported officially or made available for public dissemination under Subsection (1)(c), final consent judgments, and to the extent the enforcing authority considers appropriate, assurances of voluntary compliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-7(2): On motion of the enforcing authority, or on its own motion, the court may impose a civil penalty of not more than $5,000 for each day a temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction issued under this chapter is violated, if the supplier received notice of the restraining or injunctive order.  Civil penalties imposed under this section shall be paid to the General Fund.

-------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-16 Investigatory powers of enforcing authority.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-16(1): If, by his own inquiries or as a result of complaints, the enforcing authority has reason to believe that a person has engaged in, is engaging in, or is about to engage in an act or practice that violates this act, he may administer oaths and affirmations, subpoena witnesses or matter, and collect evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-16(2): If matter that the enforcing authority subpoenas is located outside this state, the person subpoenaed may either make it available to the enforcing authority at a convenient location within the state or pay the reasonable and necessary expenses for the enforcing authority or his representative to examine the matter at the place where it is located.  The enforcing authority may designate representatives, including officials of the state in which the matter is located, to inspect the matter on his behalf, and he may respond to similar requests from officials of other states.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-16(3): Upon failure of a person without lawful excuse to obey a subpoena and upon reasonable notice to all persons affected, the enforcing authority may apply to the court for an order compelling compliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-16(4): Title 77, Chapter 22b, Grants of Immunity In the event a witness asserts a privilege against self-incrimination, testimony and evidence from the witness may be compelled pursuant to

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-17.5 Costs and attorney's fees.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Any judgment granted in favor of the enforcing authority in connection with the enforcement of this chapter shall include, in addition to any other monetary award or injunctive relief, an award of reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, and costs of investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-18 Noncompliance by supplier subject to other state supervision -- Cooperation of enforcing authority and other official or agency.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-18(1): If the enforcing authority receives a complaint or other information relating to noncompliance with this act by a supplier who is subject to other supervision in this state, the enforcing authority shall inform the official or agency having that supervision. The enforcing authority may request information about suppliers from the official or agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-18(2): The enforcing authority and any other official or agency in this state having supervisory authority over a supplier shall consult and assist each other in maintaining compliance with this act. Within the scope of their authority, they may jointly or separately make investigations, prosecute suits, and take other official action they consider appropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19 Actions by consumer.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(1): Whether he seeks or is entitled to damages or otherwise has an adequate remedy at law, a consumer may bring an action to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(1)(a): obtain a declaratory judgment that an act or practice violates this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(1)(b): enjoin, in accordance with the principles of equity, a supplier who has violated, is violating, or is likely to violate this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(2): A consumer who suffers loss as a result of a violation of this chapter may recover, but not in a class action, actual damages or $2,000, whichever is greater, plus court costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(3): Whether a consumer seeks or is entitled to recover damages or has an adequate remedy at law, he may bring a class action for declaratory judgment, an injunction, and appropriate ancillary relief against an act or practice that violates this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(4): 13-11-8(2); 13-11-4; 13-11-5; 13-11-7(1)(c); Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act

Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(4)(b): Title 67, Chapter 4a, Revised Uniform Unclaimed Property Act If an act or practice that violates this chapter unjustly enriches a supplier and the damages can be computed with reasonable certainty, damages recoverable on behalf of consumers who cannot be located with due diligence shall be transferred to the state treasurer pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 13-11-19(4)(c): If a supplier shows by a preponderance of the evidence that a violation of this chapter resulted from a bona fide error notwithstanding the maintenance of procedures reasonably adapted to avoid the error, recovery under this section is limited to the amount, if any, in which the supplier was unjustly enriched by the violation.
