Utah Code Annotated § 13-21-9 Damages -- Punitive damages -- Attorney's fees and costs -- Remedies.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-21-9(1): Any buyer injured by a violation of this chapter may bring any action for recovery of damages.  Judgment shall be entered for actual damages, but in no case less than the amount paid by the buyer to the credit services organization, plus reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.  An award may also be entered for punitive damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-21-9(2): The remedies provided under this chapter are in addition to any other procedures or remedies for any violation or conduct provided for in any other law.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-21-9(3): The Division of Consumer Protection may maintain an action for damages or injunctive relief on behalf of itself or any other person to enforce compliance with this chapter.  Any judgment granted in favor of the division shall include, in addition to any other monetary award or injunctive relief, an award of reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, and costs of investigation.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 22 - Charitable Solicitations Act
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Charitable Solicitations Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(1): "Chapter" means a chapter, branch, area, office, or similar affiliate of a charitable organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a): "Charitable organization" or "organization" means any person, joint venture, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, association, group, or other entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(i): who is or holds itself out to be:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(i)(A): a benevolent, educational, voluntary health, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, religious or eleemosynary, social welfare or advocacy, public health, environmental or conservation, or civic organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(i)(B): for the benefit of a public safety, law enforcement, or firefighter fraternal association; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(i)(C): established for any charitable purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(ii): who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the public for a charitable purpose; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(a)(iii): in any manner employs a charitable appeal as the basis of any solicitation or employs an appeal that reasonably suggests or implies that there is a charitable purpose to any solicitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(b): "Charitable organization" includes a chapter or a person who solicits contributions within the state for a charitable organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(2)(c): "Charitable organization" does not include a political organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(3): "Charitable purpose" means any benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, religious, eleemosynary, social welfare or advocacy, public health, environmental, conservation, civic, or other charitable objective or for the benefit of a public safety, law enforcement, or firefighter fraternal association.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(4): "Charitable sales promotion" means an advertising or sales campaign, conducted by a commercial co-venturer, which represents that the purchase or use of goods or services offered by the commercial co-venturer will benefit, in whole or in part, a charitable organization or purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(a): "Charitable solicitation" or "solicitation" means any request, directly or indirectly, for money, credit, property, financial assistance, or any other thing of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b): "Charitable solicitation" or "solicitation" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b)(i): any of the following done, or purporting to be done, for a charitable purpose:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b)(i)(A): any oral or written request, including any request by telephone, radio, television, or other advertising or communications media;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b)(i)(B): the distribution, circulation, or posting of any handbill, written advertisement, or publication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b)(i)(C): an application or other request for a a private grant or, if made by an individual, a public grant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(b)(ii): the sale of, offer or attempt to sell, or request of donations in exchange for any advertisement, membership, subscription, or other article in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable purpose, or the use of the name of any charitable organization or movement as an inducement or reason for making any purchase donation, or, in connection with any sale or donation, stating or implying that the whole or any part of the proceeds of any sale or donation will go to or be donated to any charitable purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(5)(c): "Charitable solicitation" or "solicitation" does not include an entity's application or other request for a public grant.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(6): "Commercial co-venturer" means a person who for profit is regularly and primarily engaged in trade or commerce other than in connection with soliciting for a charitable organization or purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(a): "Contribution" means the pledge or grant for a charitable purpose of any money or property of any kind, including any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(a)(i): a gift, subscription, loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(a)(ii): a contract, promise, or agreement, express or implied, whether or not legally enforceable, to make a contribution for charitable purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(a)(iii): fees, dues, or assessments paid by members, when membership is conferred solely as consideration for making a contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(b): "Contribution" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(b)(i): money loaned to a charitable organization by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(7)(b)(ii): fees, dues, or assessments paid by members when membership is not conferred solely as consideration for making a contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(8): "Contributor" means a donor, pledgor, purchaser, or other person who makes a contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(9): "Director" means the director of the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(10): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(11)(a): "Exempt function" means the function of influencing or attempting to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of an individual to a federal, state, or local public office or an office in a political organization, or the election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, regardless of whether the individual or the electors are selected, nominated, elected, or appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(11)(b): "Exempt function" includes making an expenditure relating to an office described in Subsection (11)(a) which, if incurred by the individual, would be allowable as a deduction under section 162(a) of 26 I.R.C. Sec. 1.162-20.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(12): 16-6a-102 "Foreign nonprofit corporation" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(13): "Material fact" means information that a person of ordinary intelligence and prudence would consider relevant in deciding whether or not to make a contribution in response to a charitable solicitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(14): 16-6a-102 "Nonprofit corporation" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(15): "Political organization" means an incorporated or unincorporated party, committee, association, fund, or other organization organized and operated primarily for the purpose of directly or indirectly accepting contributions or making expenditures for an exempt function.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a): "Professional fund raiser" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(i): for compensation or any other consideration, for or on behalf of a charitable organization that is a nonprofit corporation, or any other person that is not a political organization:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(i)(A): solicits contributions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(i)(B): promotes or sponsors the solicitation of contributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(ii)(A): for compensation or any other consideration, plans, manages, consults, or prepares material for, or with respect to, the solicitation of contributions for a charitable organizationthat is a nonprofit corporation, or any other person that is not a political organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(ii)(B): at any time has custody of a contribution for the charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(iii): engages in, or represents being independently engaged in, the business of soliciting contributions for a charitable organization that is a nonprofit corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(iv): manages, supervises, or trains any solicitor whether as an employee or otherwise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(a)(v): uses a vending device or vending device decal for financial or other consideration that implies a solicitation of contributions or donations for any charitable organization or charitable purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b): "Professional fund raiser" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(i): an individual acting in the individual's capacity as a bona fide officer, director, volunteer, or full-time employee of a charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(ii): an attorney, investment counselor, or banker who, in the conduct of that person's profession, advises a client regarding legal, investment, or financial advice;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(iii): a person who tangentially prepares materials, including a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(iii)(A): makes copies;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(iii)(B): cuts or folds flyers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(iii)(C): creates a graphic design or other artwork without providing strategic or campaign-related input; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(16)(b)(iv): a political organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(a): "Professional fund raising consultant" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(a)(i): for compensation or any other consideration, plans, manages, consults, or prepares material for, or with respect to, the solicitation of contributions for a charitable organization that is a nonprofit corporation or any other person that is not a political organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(a)(ii): does not solicit contributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(a)(iii): does not at any time have custody of a contribution from solicitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(a)(iv): does not employ, procure, or engage any compensated person to solicit or receive contributions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b): "Professional fund raising counsel or consultant" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(i): an individual acting in the individual's capacity as a bona fide officer, director, volunteer, or full-time employee of a charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(ii): an attorney, investment counselor, or banker who, in the conduct of that person's profession, advises a client regarding legal, investment, or financial advice; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(iii): a person who tangentially prepares materials, including a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(iii)(A): makes copies;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(iii)(B): cuts or folds flyers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(17)(b)(iii)(C): creates a graphic design or other artwork without providing strategic or campaign-related input.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(18): 63G-6a-103 "Public grant" means the same as the term "grant" is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(19): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(19)(a): "Vending device" means a container used by a charitable organization or professional fund raiser, for the purpose of collecting a charitable solicitation, contribution, or donation whether or not the device offers a product or item in return for the contribution or donation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(19)(b): "Vending device" includes machines, boxes, jars, wishing wells, barrels, or any other container.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-2(20): "Vending device decal" means any decal, tag, or similar designation material that is attached to a vending device, whether or not used or placed by a charitable organization or professional fund raiser, that would indicate that all or a portion of the proceeds from the purchase of items from the vending device will go to a specific charitable organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3 Investigative and enforcement powers -- Education.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(1): The division shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter in accordance with Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(2): Upon request, the attorney general shall give legal advice to, and act as counsel for, the division in the exercise of the division's responsibilities under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(3): The division may audit or investigate as necessary to determine whether a person is violating, has violated, or is about to violate a provision of this chapter or a rule made or order issued under this chapter.  As part of the investigation, the division may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(3)(a): require a person to file a statement in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(3)(b): administer oaths, subpoena witnesses and compel a witness to attend, compel sworn responses to written questions, take evidence, and examine under oath a person in connection with an investigation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(3)(c): require the production of books, papers, documents, merchandise, or other material relevant to the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(4): In addition to the division's enforcement powers under Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(4)(a): the director may impose an administrative fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(4)(b): the division may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction to enjoin the acts or practices constituting the violation or to enforce compliance with this chapter or a rule made or order issued under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5): Upon a proper showing, the court hearing an action brought under Subsection (4)(b) may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(a): issue an injunction;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(b): enter a declaratory judgment;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(c): appoint a receiver for the defendant or the defendant's assets;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(d): order disgorgement of any money received in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(e): order rescission of agreements violating this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(f): impose fines for each violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(5)(g): impose a civil penalty or any other relief the court determines reasonable and necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(6): If a court with jurisdiction grants judgment or injunctive relief to the division, the court shall award the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(6)(a): reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(6)(b): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(6)(c): investigative fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(7): In assessing the amount of a fine or penalty under Subsection (4)(a), (5)(f), or (5)(g), the director or court imposing the fine or penalty may consider the gravity of the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(8)(a): A person who violates an administrative or court order issued for a violation of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(8)(b): A court may impose a civil penalty authorized under this section in a civil action brought by the attorney general on behalf of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9): The division may provide or contract to provide public education and voluntary education for applicants and registrants under this chapter.  The education may be in the form of publications, advertisements, seminars, courses, or other appropriate means.  The scope of the education may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9)(a): the requirements, prohibitions, and regulated practices under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9)(b): suggestions for effective financial and organizational practices for charitable organizations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9)(c): charitable giving and solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9)(d): potential problems with solicitations and fraudulent or deceptive practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(9)(e): any other matter relevant to the subject of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-3(10): Nothing in this chapter limits other available rights or remedies authorized under the laws of this state or the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-4 Action for damages.
-------------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5 Registration required.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(1): 13-22-9 Unless a person acting as a professional fund raiser is registered with the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(1)(a): make or facilitate a solicitation either directed toward the state or originating from the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(1)(b): maintain a place of business in the state or employ an individual located in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(2): 13-22-9 Unless a person acting as a professional fund raising consultant is registered with the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(2)(a): maintain a place of business in the state or employ an individual located in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-5(2)(b): provide any service of a professional fund raising consultant to or for a charitable organization, or any other person, over which the state has general jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9 Professional fund raiser's or fund raising consultant's registration.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1): 63J-1-504 A person applying for or renewing a registration as a professional fund raiser or a professional fund raising consultant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(a): 63J-1-504 pay an application fee as determined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b): submit a written application, verified under oath, on a form approved by the division that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(i): the applicant's name, address, telephone number, facsimile number, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(ii): the name and address of each organization or person controlled by, controlling, or affiliated with the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(iii): the applicant's business, occupation, or employment for the three-year period immediately preceding the date of the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(iv): whether it is an individual, joint venture, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, association, or other entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(v): the names and residence addresses of the applicant's officers and directors;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vi): the name and address of the applicant's registered agent for service of process and a consent to service of process;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii): if a professional fund raiser:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii)(A): the purpose of the solicitation and use of the contributions to be solicited;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii)(B): the method by which the solicitation will be conducted and the projected length of time it is to be conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii)(C): the anticipated expenses of the solicitation, including all commissions, costs of collection, salaries, and other expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii)(D): a statement of what percentage of the contributions collected as a result of the solicitation are projected to remain available to the charitable organization declared in the application, including a satisfactory statement of the factual basis for the projected percentage and projected anticipated revenues provided to the charitable organization, and if a flat fee is charged, documentation to support the reasonableness of the flat fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(vii)(E): a statement of total contributions collected or received by the professional fund raiser within the calendar year immediately preceding the date of the application, including a description of the expenditures made from or the use made of the contributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii): if a professional fund raising consultant:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii)(A): the purpose of the plan, management, advice, or preparation of materials for, or with respect to, the solicitation and use of the contributions solicited;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii)(B): the method by which the plan, management, advice, or preparation of materials for, or with respect to, the solicitation will be organized or coordinated and the projected length of time of the solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii)(C): the anticipated expenses of the plan, management, advice, or preparation of materials for, or with respect to, the solicitation, including all commissions, costs of collection, salaries, and other expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii)(D): a statement of total fees to be earned or received from the charitable organization declared in the application, and what percentage of the contributions collected as a result of the plan, management, advice,  or preparation of materials for, or with respect to, the solicitation are projected after deducting the total fees to be earned or received remain available to the charitable organization declared in the application, including a satisfactory statement of the factual basis for the projected percentage and projected anticipated revenues provided to the charitable organization, and if a flat fee is charged, documentation to support the reasonableness of such flat fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(viii)(E): a statement of total net fees earned or received within the calendar year immediately preceding the date of the application, including a description of the expenditures made from or the use of the net earned or received fees in the planning, management, advising, or preparation of materials for, or with respect to, the solicitation and use of the contributions solicited for the charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(ix): disclosure of any injunction, judgment, or administrative order against the applicant or the applicant's conviction of a crime involving a charitable solicitation or a felony involving fraud, dishonesty, a false statement, forgery, or theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(x): each written agreement the applicant has with a charitable organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(xi): disclosure of any injunction, judgment, or administrative order or conviction of a crime involving a charitable solicitation or a felony involving fraud, dishonesty, a false statement, forgery, or theft with respect to any officer, director, manager, operator, or principal of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(xii): a copy of all agreements to which the applicant is, or proposes to be, a party regarding the use of proceeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(xiii): an acknowledgment that fund raising in the state will not commence until both the professional fund raiser or professional fund raising consultant and the charity, and its parent foundation, if any, are registered and in compliance with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(1)(b)(xiv): additional information the division may require by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(2): If information contained in the application for registration becomes incorrect or incomplete, the applicant or registrant shall, within 30 days after the information becomes incorrect or incomplete, correct the application or file the complete information required by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-9(3): In addition to the registration fee, an applicant failing to file an application for registration or renewal by the due date or filing an incomplete application for registration or renewal shall pay an additional fee of $25 for each month or part of a month after the date on which the application for registration or renewal was due to be filed.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-11 Expiration of registration.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-11(1): Each professional fund raiser's registration issued under this chapter expires annually on the date of issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-11(2): Each professional fund raising consultant's registration issued under this chapter expires annually on the date of issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-11(3): A registration may be renewed only by complying with the requirements for obtaining the original registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12 Grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(1): the application for registration or renewal is incomplete or misleading in any material respect;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2): 13-22-3 the applicant or registrant or an officer, director, agent, or employee of the applicant or registrant has:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(a): violated this chapter or committed a prohibited act or practice described in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(b): been enjoined by a court, or is the subject of an administrative order issued in this or another state, if the injunction or order includes a finding or admission of fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, material misrepresentation, or if the injunction or order was based on a finding of lack of integrity, truthfulness, or mental competence of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(c): been convicted of a crime involving fraud, dishonesty, a false statement, forgery, or theft;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(d): obtained or attempted to obtain a registration by misrepresentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(e): materially misrepresented or caused to be misrepresented the purpose and manner in which contributed funds and property will be used in connection with a solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(f): caused or allowed a paid solicitor to violate a rule made or order issued under this chapter by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(g): failed to take corrective action with a solicitor that has violated this chapter or committed an act or practice prohibited by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(h): used, or attempted to use a name that is deceptive or is reasonably likely to cause confusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(i): failed to timely file with the division a report or information required in this chapter or by rules made under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-12(2)(j): 13-22-3 failed to pay a fine imposed by the division in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-13 Prohibited practices.
----------------------------------------------------
In connection with a solicitation, each of the following acts and practices is prohibited:Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-13(1): stating or implying that registration constitutes endorsement or approval by the division or a governmental entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-13(2): violating a requirement of this chapter or a rule made under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-13(3): making a false statement of a material fact or failing to state a material fact necessary to make statements made, in the context of the circumstances under which they are made, not misleading, whether in connection with a charitable solicitation or a filing with the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-13(4): 13-22-3 violating an order issued by the division under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-14 Accuracy not guaranteed.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-14(1): By issuing a registration, the state does not guarantee the accuracy of any representation contained in the registration, nor does it warrant that any statement made by the holder of the registration is truthful.  The state makes no certification as to the charitable worthiness of any organization on whose behalf a solicitation is made nor as to the moral character of the holder of the registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-14(2): The following statement shall appear on each registration: "THE STATE OF UTAH MAKES NO CERTIFICATION AS TO THE CHARITABLE WORTHINESS OF ANY ORGANIZATION ON WHOSE BEHALF A SOLICITATION IS MADE NOR AS TO THE MORAL CHARACTER OF THE HOLDER OF THE REGISTRATION."


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15  Financial reports required -- Rulemaking.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(1)(a): Beginning January 1, 2025, and subject to Subsection (2), a charitable organization that is a nonprofit corporation, or that is a foreign nonprofit corporation, shall file an unredacted copy of the charitable organization's most recent IRS Form 990, 990-EZ, 990-N, or 990-PF.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(1)(b): Subsection (1)(a) does not apply to a nonprofit corporation or a foreign nonprofit corporation that is not required to file a Form 990, 990-EZ, 990-N, or 990-PF with the IRS.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(a)(i): The division may not require a charitable organization to file Schedule B of a form described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(a)(ii): An IRS Form 990-T is not required to be filed under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(b): The division shall make rules, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to establish:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(b)(i): the manner in which a charitable organization is required to file the forms described in Subsection (1); and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-15(2)(b)(ii): the process by which a charitable organization is required to file the forms  described in Subsection (1).


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16 Separate accounts and receipts required.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(1)(a): Each professional fund raiser shall segregate and maintain all contributed funds in an account held separately from the professional fund raiser's operating account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(1)(b): Each contribution in the control or custody of the professional fund raiser shall, no later than 10 days after the day on which the contribution is received, be deposited into an account at a bank or other federally insured financial institution that is in the name of the charitable organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(1)(c): The charitable organization shall maintain and administer the account and shall have sole control of all withdrawals.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(2): Each professional fund raiser shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(2)(a): maintain a record of each contribution of money, securities, or cash equivalent sufficient to allow the organization or professional fund raiser to provide a receipt to the contributor upon request or as required by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(2)(b): provide a contributor a receipt for each contribution upon request or as required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-16(3): A professional fund raiser shall develop and maintain adequate internal controls for receipt, management, and disbursement of money that are reasonable in light of the organization's or professional fund raiser's assets and organizational complexity.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-17 Written agreement required.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-17(1): A professional fund raiser may only engage in activities on behalf of a charitable organization through written agreement with the organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-17(2): A professional fund raising consultant may only engage in activities on behalf of a charitable organization through written agreement with the organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-17(3): A charitable organization may only engage the services of a professional fund raiser or professional fund raising consultant through written agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-17(4): A professional fund raiser or professional fund raising consultant shall file each agreement described in this section with its application for registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-18 Local ordinance.
-----------------------------------------------
This chapter does not prohibit any political subdivision of the state from enacting any ordinance regulating the solicitation of contributions within the subdivision's boundaries so long as the ordinance only coordinates enforcement of this chapter with the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-19 Reciprocal agreements.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-19(1): The division may convey or exchange information obtained under this chapter with other agencies having regulatory authority over charitable organizations.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-19(2): The division may accept information that a charitable organization or professional fund raiser files in another state or with any federal agency or other organization in place of substantially similar information that is required to be filed under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-22 Charitable sales promotions.
-----------------------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-23 Fiduciary capacity.
--------------------------------------------------
Every person soliciting, collecting, or expending contributions for charitable purposes, and every officer, director, trustee, or employee of any person concerned with the solicitation, collection, or expenditure of those contributions, shall be considered to be a fiduciary and acting in a fiduciary capacity.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24 Fund raising campaign registration required.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(1): As used in this section, "fund raising campaign" means charitable solicitation activity that a professional fund raiser engages in on behalf of a charitable organization where the professional fund raiser receives a portion of the funds raised or other compensation in exchange for services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2): Before commencing a fund raising campaign, a professional fund raiser shall submit to the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2)(a): projected expenses and revenue for the campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2)(b): bank account information for the bank account where the professional fund raiser will hold contributions collected in connection with the fund raising campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2)(c): the solicitation scripts that will be used for the fund raising campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2)(d): an affirmation from the professional fund raiser that the charity has approved the solicitation materials to be used in the fund raising campaign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(2)(e): names and contact information for the individuals overseeing the fund raising campaign.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(3): No later than 90 days after the day on which the fund raising campaign ends, the professional fund raiser shall submit a report to the division detailing:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(3)(a): all contributions collected during the fund raising campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(3)(b): all contributions paid to the charitable organization as a result of the fund raising campaign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(3)(c): expenses paid by the charitable organization to the professional fund raiser for the fund raising campaign.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-22-24(4): A professional fund raiser shall keep records related to the information described in Subsection (2) for five years after the day on which the fund raising campaign ends.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 23 - Health Spa Services Protection Act
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Health Spa Services Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(1): "Business enterprise" means a sole proprietorship, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, or other entity used in carrying on a business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(2): "Consumer" means a purchaser of health spa services for consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(3): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4): 29-2-102; 29-2-102
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(a): "Health spa" means a business enterprise that provides access to a facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(a)(i): for a charge or a fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(a)(ii): for the development or preservation of physical fitness or well-being, through exercise, weight control, or athletics.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b): 29-2-102; 29-2-102 "Health spa" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(i): a licensed physician who operates a facility at which the physician engages in the practice of medicine;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(ii): a hospital, intermediate care facility, or skilled nursing care facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(iii): a public or private school, college, or university;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(iv): the state or a political subdivision of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(v): the United States or a political subdivision of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(vi): a person offering instruction if the person does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(vi)(A): utilize an employee or independent contractor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(vi)(B): grant a consumer the use of a facility containing exercise equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(vii): a business enterprise, the primary operation of which is to teach self-defense or a martial art, including kickboxing, judo, or karate;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(viii): a business enterprise, the primary operation of which is to teach or allow an individual to develop a specific skill rather than develop or preserve physical fitness, including gymnastics, tennis, rock climbing, or a winter sport;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(ix): a business enterprise, the primary operation of which is to teach or allow an individual to practice yoga or Pilates;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(x): a private employer who owns and operates a facility exclusively for the benefit of the employer's employees, retirees, or family members, if the operation of the facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(x)(A): is only incidental to the overall function and purpose of the employer's business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(x)(B): is offered on a nonprofit basis;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xi): an individual providing professional services within the scope of the individual's license with the Division of Professional Licensing;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xii): a country club;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xiii): a nonprofit religious, ethnic, or community organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xiv): a residential weight reduction center;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xv): a business enterprise that only offers virtual services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xvi): a business enterprise that only offers a credit for a service that a separate business enterprise offers;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xvii): 29-2-102; 29-2-102 the owner of a lodging establishment, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xvii)(A): 29-2-102 a guest, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xvii)(B): an operator or employee of the lodging establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xviii): an association, declarant, owner, lessor, or developer of a residential housing complex, planned community, or development, if at least 80% of the individuals accessing the facility reside in the housing complex, planned community, or development; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(4)(b)(xix): a person offering a personal training service exclusively as an employee or independent contractor of a health spa.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(5): "Health spa facility" means a facility to which a business entity provides access:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(5)(a): for a charge or a fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(5)(b): for the development or preservation of physical fitness or well-being, through exercise, weight control, or athletics.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(6)(a): "Health spa service" means instruction, a service, a privilege, or a right that a health spa offers for sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(6)(b): "Health spa service" includes a personal training service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(7): "Personal training service" means the personalized instruction, training, supervision, or monitoring of an individual's physical fitness or well-being, through exercise, weight control, or athletics.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-23-2(8): "Primary location" means the health spa facility that a health spa designates in a contract for health spa services as the health spa facility the consumer in the contract will primarily use for health spa services.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 24 - Uniform Trade Secrets Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Uniform Trade Secrets Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise:Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(1): "Improper means" includes theft, bribery, misrepresentation, breach or inducement of a breach of a duty to maintain secrecy, or espionage through electronic or other means.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2): "Misappropriation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(a): acquisition of a trade secret of another by a person who knows or has reason to know that the trade secret was acquired by improper means; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b): disclosure or use of a trade secret of another without express or implied consent by a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(i): used improper means to acquire knowledge of the trade secret; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(ii): at the time of disclosure or use, knew or had reason to know that his knowledge of the trade secret was:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(ii)(A): derived from or through a person who had utilized improper means to acquire it;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(ii)(B): acquired under circumstances giving rise to a duty to maintain its secrecy or limit its use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(ii)(C): derived from or through a person who owed a duty to the person seeking relief to maintain its secrecy or limit its use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(2)(b)(iii): before a material change of his position, knew or had reason to know that it was a trade secret and that knowledge of it had been acquired by accident or mistake.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(3): "Person" means a natural person, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, joint venture, government, governmental subdivision or agency, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(4): "Trade secret" means information, including a formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique, or process, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(4)(a): derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-2(4)(b): is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-3 Injunctive relief.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-3(1): Actual or threatened misappropriation may be enjoined.  Upon application to the court, an injunction shall be terminated when the trade secret has ceased to exist, but the injunction may be continued for an additional reasonable period of time in order to eliminate commercial advantage that otherwise would be derived from the misappropriation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-3(2): In exceptional circumstances, an injunction may condition future use upon payment of a reasonable royalty for no longer than the period of time for which use could have been prohibited.  Exceptional circumstances include, but are not limited to, a material and prejudicial change of position prior to acquiring knowledge or reason to know of misappropriation that renders a prohibitive injunction inequitable.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-3(3): In appropriate circumstances, affirmative acts to protect a trade secret may be compelled by court order.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-4 Damages.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-4(1): Except to the extent that a material and prejudicial change of position prior to acquiring knowledge or reason to know of misappropriation renders a monetary recovery inequitable, a complainant is entitled to recover damages for misappropriation.  Damages can include both the actual loss caused by misappropriation and the unjust enrichment caused by misappropriation that is not taken into account in computing actual loss.  In lieu of damages measured by any other methods, the damages caused by misappropriation may be measured by imposition of liability for a reasonable royalty for a misappropriator's unauthorized disclosure or use of a trade secret.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-4(2): (1) If willful and malicious misappropriation exists, the court may award exemplary damages in an amount not exceeding twice any award made under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-5 Attorneys' fees.
----------------------------------------------
If a claim of misappropriation is made in bad faith, a motion to terminate an injunction is made or resisted in bad faith, or willful and malicious misappropriation exists, the court may award reasonable attorneys' fees to the prevailing party.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-6 Preservation of secrecy.
------------------------------------------------------
In an action under this chapter, a court shall preserve the secrecy of an alleged trade secret by reasonable means, which may include granting protective orders in connection with discovery proceedings, holding in-camera hearings, sealing the records of the action, and ordering any person involved in the litigation not to disclose an alleged trade secret without prior court approval.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-7 Statute of limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------
An action for misappropriation shall be brought within three years after the misappropriation is discovered or, by the exercise of reasonable diligence, should have been discovered.  For the purposes of this section, a continuing misappropriation constitutes a single claim.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8 Effect on other law.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8(2): This chapter does not affect:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8(2)(a): contractual remedies, whether or not based upon misappropriation of a trade secret;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8(2)(b): other civil remedies that are not based upon misappropriation of a trade secret; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-8(2)(c): criminal remedies, whether or not based upon misappropriation of a trade secret.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-24-9 Uniformity of application and construction.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter shall be applied and construed to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law with respect to the subject of the chapter among states enacting it.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 25a - Telephone and Facsimile Solicitation Act
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Telephone and Facsimile Solicitation  Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(1): "Advertisement" means material offering for sale, or advertising the availability or quality of, any property, good, or service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2)(a): "Automated telephone dialing system" means equipment used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2)(a)(i): store or produce telephone numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2)(a)(ii): call a stored or produced number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2)(a)(iii): connect the number called with a recorded message or artificial voice.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(2)(b): "Automated telephone dialing system" does not include a system used in an emergency involving the immediate health or safety of a person, including a burglar alarm system, voice messaging system, fire alarm system, or other similar system.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(3): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4): 16-10a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a): "Established business relationship" means a relationship that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a)(i): is based on inquiry, application, purchase, or transaction regarding products or services offered;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a)(ii): is formed by a voluntary two-way communication between a person making a telephone solicitation and a person to whom a telephone solicitation is made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a)(iii): has not been terminated by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a)(iii)(A): an act by either person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(a)(iii)(B): the passage of 18 months since the most recent inquiry, application, purchase, transaction, or voluntary two-way communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(4)(b): 16-10a-102 "Established business relationship" includes a relationship with an affiliate as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(5): "Facsimile machine" means equipment used for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(5)(a): scanning or encoding text or images for conversion into electronic signals for transmission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(5)(b): receiving electronic signals and reproducing them as a duplicate of the original text or image.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(6): "Negative response" means a statement from a person stating the person does not wish to listen to the sales presentation or participate in the solicitation presented in the telephone call.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(7): "On-call emergency provider" means an individual who is required by an employer to be on call to respond to a medical emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8): "Telephone solicitation" means the initiation of a telephone call or message for a commercial purpose or to seek a financial donation, including calls:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(a): encouraging the purchase or rental of, or investment in, property, goods, or services, regardless of whether the transaction involves a nonprofit organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(b): soliciting a sale of or extension of credit for property or services to the person called;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(c): soliciting information that will be used for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(c)(i): the direct solicitation of a sale of property or services to the person called; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(c)(ii): an extension of credit to the person called for a sale of property or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(d): soliciting a charitable contribution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(8)(e): encouraging the person called to sell real or personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(9): "Telephone solicitor" means an individual, firm, organization, partnership, association, or corporation who makes or causes to be made an unsolicited telephone call, including calls made by use of an automated telephone dialing system.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(10): "Unsolicited telephone call" means a telephone call for a commercial purpose or to seek a financial donation other than a call made:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(10)(a): in response to an express request of the person called;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(10)(b): primarily in connection with an existing debt or contract, payment or performance of which has not been completed at the time of the call;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(10)(c): to a person with whom the telephone solicitor has an established business relationship; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-102(10)(d): as required by law for a medical purpose.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103 Prohibited conduct for telephone solicitations -- Exceptions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(2): A person may operate an automated telephone dialing system if a call is made:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(2)(a): with the prior express consent of the person who is called agreeing to receive a telephone solicitation from a specific solicitor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(2)(b): to a person with whom the solicitor has an established business relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(3): A person may not make a telephone solicitation to a residential telephone or cellular telephone without prior express consent during any of the following times:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(3)(a): between the hours of 9 p.m. and 8 a.m. local time;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(3)(b): on a Sunday; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(3)(c): on a legal holiday.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(4): A person may not make or authorize a telephone solicitation in violation of Title 47 U.S.C. 227.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5): A telephone solicitor who makes an unsolicited telephone call to a telephone number shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5)(a): identify the telephone solicitor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5)(b): identify the business on whose behalf the telephone solicitor is soliciting;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5)(c): promptly identify the purpose of the call upon making contact by telephone with the person who is the object of the telephone solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5)(d): discontinue the solicitation if the person being solicited gives a negative response at any time during the telephone call; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(5)(e): hang up the phone, or in the case of an automated telephone dialing system operator, disconnect the automated telephone dialing system from the telephone line within 25 seconds of the termination of the call by the person being called.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-103(6): If a telephone solicitor's service or equipment is capable of displaying the telephone solicitor's telephone number through a caller identification service, the telephone solicitor may not withhold the display of the telephone solicitor's telephone number from a caller identification service when that number is being used for telemarketing purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104 Prohibited conduct for facsimiles -- Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104(2): A person may operate a facsimile machine if the advertisement is sent:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104(2)(a): with the prior express written consent of the person who receives the facsimile agreeing to receive the facsimile from a specific solicitor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104(2)(b): to a person with whom the solicitor has an established business relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-104(3): A person may not make or authorize the sending of an advertisement by facsimile in violation of Title 47 U.S.C. 227.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105 Penalties -- Administrative and criminal.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(1): Any person who violates this chapter is subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(1)(a): a cease and desist order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(1)(b): an administrative fine of not less than $100 or more than $2,500 for each separate violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(2): Any person who violates this chapter by soliciting an on-call emergency provider while the on-call emergency provider is on call is subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(2)(a): a cease and desist order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(2)(b): an administrative fine of not less than $1,000 or more than $2,500 for each separate violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(3): 13-2-8 All administrative fines collected under this chapter shall be deposited in the Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(4): Any person who intentionally violates this chapter is guilty of a class A misdemeanor and may be fined up to $2,500.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-105(5): A person intentionally violates this chapter if the violation occurs after the division, attorney general, or a district or county attorney notifies the person by certified mail that the person is in violation of this chapter.

---------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-107.2 Requests to a specific telephone solicitor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-107.2(1): A telephone solicitor may not make or cause to be made a telephone solicitation to a person who has informed the telephone solicitor, either in writing or orally, that the person does not wish to receive a telephone call from the telephone solicitor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-107.2(2): A telephone solicitor is not liable for a violation of this section if the telephone solicitor complies with 16 C.F.R. Part 310.4(b)(3) and (4).


Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108 Prohibited telephone solicitations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(1): A person may not make or cause to be made an unsolicited telephone call to a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(1)(a): located in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(1)(b)(i): at a Utah telephone number contained in the national "do-not-call" registry established and maintained by the Federal Trade Commission under 16 C.F.R. 310.4(b)(1)(iii)(B); or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(1)(b)(ii): at a non-Utah telephone number contained in the national "do-not-call" registry established and maintained by the Federal Trade Commission under 16 C.F.R. 310.4(b)(1)(iii)(B), if the person making the call or causing the call to be made knows or reasonably should know that the person receiving the call is in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-25a-108(2): Each unsolicited telephone call made in violation of this section is a separate violation.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 26 - Telephone Fraud Prevention Act
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Telephone Fraud Prevention Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires:Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(1): "Affiliated person" means a seller or a seller's contractor, director, employee, officer, owner, or partner.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(2): "Continuity plan" means a shipment, with the prior express consent of the buyer, at regular intervals of similar special-interest products, in which there is no binding commitment period or purchase amount.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(3): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(4): "Fictitious personal name" means a name other than an individual's legal name.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(5): "Material statement" or "material fact" means information that a person of ordinary intelligence or prudence would consider important in deciding whether to accept an offer extended through a telephone solicitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6): "Participant" means a person seeking to register or renew a registration as a seller including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(a): a seller;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(b): an owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(c): an officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(d): a director;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(e): a member or manager of a limited liability company;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(f): a principal;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(g): a trustee;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(h): a general or limited partner;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(i): a sole proprietor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(6)(j): an individual with a controlling interest in an entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(7): "Premium" means a gift, bonus, prize, award, certificate, or other document by which a prospective purchaser is given a right, chance, or privilege to purchase or receive goods or services with a stated or represented value of $25 or more as an inducement to a prospective purchaser to purchase other goods or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8): "Seller" means a person, or a group of persons engaged in a common effort to conduct a telephone solicitation, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(a): on behalf of the person, or the group of persons engaged in a common effort to conduct a telephone solicitation:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(a)(i): makes a telephone solicitation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(a)(ii): causes a telephone solicitation to be made; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(b): through a telephone solicitor:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(b)(i): makes a telephone solicitation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(8)(b)(ii): causes a telephone solicitation to be made.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(9): "Subscription arrangements," "standing order arrangements," "supplements," and "series arrangements" mean products or services provided, with the prior express request or consent of the buyer, for a specified period of time at a price dependent on the duration of service and to complement an initial purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10): 13-26-4; (10); 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv); 13-25a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a): 13-26-4; (10); 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv); 13-25a-102 "Telephone solicitation," "sale," "selling," or "solicitation of sale" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i): 13-26-4; (10); 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv) a sale or solicitation of goods or services in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(A): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(A)(I): the seller solicits the sale over the telephone;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(A)(II): the purchaser's agreement to purchase is made over the telephone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(A)(III): the purchaser, over the telephone, pays for or agrees to commit to payment for goods or services prior to or upon receipt by the purchaser of the goods or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(B): 13-26-4 the seller, not exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(C): (10) the seller offers or promises a premium to a prospective purchaser if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(C)(I): the seller induces the prospective purchaser to initiate a telephone contact with the seller; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(C)(II): (10) the resulting solicitation meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(i)(D): 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv) the seller solicits a charitable donation involving the exchange of any premium, prize, gift, ticket, subscription, or other benefit in connection with an appeal made for a charitable purpose by an organization that is not otherwise exempt under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(a)(ii): 13-25a-102 a telephone solicitation as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(b): "Telephone solicitation," "sale," "selling," or "solicitation of sale" does not include a sale or solicitation that occurs solely through an Internet website without the use of a telephone call.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(10)(c): A solicitation of sale or telephone solicitation is considered complete when made, whether or not the person receiving the solicitation agrees to the sale or to make a charitable donation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-2(11): "Telephone solicitor" or "solicitor" means an individual who engages in a telephone solicitation on behalf of a seller.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3 Registration and bond required.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1): 13-26-4
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(a): 13-26-4 Unless exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(a)(i): the seller engages in telephone solicitations that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(a)(i)(A): originate in Utah; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(a)(i)(B): are received in Utah; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(a)(ii): the seller, or a solicitor on behalf of the seller, conducts any business operations in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(b): The registration form shall designate an agent residing in this state who is authorized by the seller to receive service of process in any action brought by this state or a resident of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(c): If a seller fails to designate an agent to receive service or fails to appoint a successor to the agent, the division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(c)(i): deny the seller's application for an initial or renewal registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(c)(ii): if the application is for a renewal registration, suspend the seller's current registration until the seller designates an agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(d): For purposes of this section only, the registered agent of a seller shall provide the division the registered agent's proof of residency in the state in the form of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(d)(i): a valid Utah driver license;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(d)(ii): a valid governmental photo identification issued to a resident of this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(1)(d)(iii): other verifiable identification indicating residency in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(2): 63J-1-504; (4) The division may impose an annual registration fee set in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(a): Each seller subject to this chapter engaging in telephone solicitation or sales in this state shall obtain and maintain the following security:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(a)(i): a performance bond issued by a surety authorized to transact surety business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(a)(ii): an irrevocable letter of credit issued by a financial institution authorized under the laws of this state or the United States doing business in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(a)(iii): a certificate of deposit held in this state in a financial institution authorized under the laws of this state or the United States to accept deposits from the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(b): A seller's bond, letter of credit, or certificate of deposit shall be payable to the division for the benefit of any consumer who incurs damages as the result of the seller's violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(c): If the consumer has first recovered full damages, the division may recover from the bond, letter of credit, or certificate of deposit administrative fines, civil penalties, investigative costs, attorney fees, and other costs of collecting and distributing funds under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(d): A seller shall keep a bond, certificate of deposit, or letter of credit in force for one year after the day on which the seller notifies the division in writing that the seller has ceased all activities regulated by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e): The seller shall post a bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or certificate of deposit in the amount of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(i): $25,000 if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(i)(A): neither the seller nor any affiliated person has violated this chapter in the three-year period immediately before the day on which the seller files the application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(i)(B): the seller has fewer than 10 employees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(ii): $50,000 if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(ii)(A): neither the seller nor any affiliated person has violated this chapter in the three-year period immediately before the day on which the seller files the application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(ii)(B): the seller has 10 or more employees; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(3)(e)(iii): $75,000 if the seller or any affiliated person has violated this chapter in the three-year period immediately before the day on which the seller files the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4): 53-10-201 To register or renew a registration as a seller, a participant:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4)(a): may not have been convicted of a felony in the 10-year period immediately before the day on which the participant files the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4)(b): may not have been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, including theft, fraud, or dishonesty, in the 10-year period immediately before the day on which the participant files the application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4)(c): 53-10-201 shall submit to the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4)(c)(i): the participant's fingerprints, in a form acceptable to the division, for purposes of a criminal background check; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(4)(c)(ii): 53-10-201 consent to a criminal background check by the Bureau of Criminal Identification created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(6): If information in an application for registration or for renewal of registration as a seller materially changes or becomes incorrect or incomplete, the applicant shall, within 30 days after the day on which information changes or becomes incorrect or incomplete, submit the correct information to the division in a manner that the division establishes by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-3(7): The division director may deny or revoke a registration under this section for any violation of this chapter.

-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(1): In an enforcement action initiated by the division, a person claiming an exemption has the burden of proving that the person is entitled to the exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2): 13-26-8; 13-26-11; Title 54, Public Utilities; 7-1-103; (2)(j)(i); Chapter 21, Credit Services Organizations Act; Chapter 21, Credit Services Organizations Act; Chapter 42, Uniform Debt-Management Services Act; Chapter 42, Uniform Debt-Management Services Act The following are exempt from this chapter except for the requirements described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(a): a broker, agent, dealer, or sales professional licensed in this state, when soliciting sales within the scope of the broker's, agent's, dealer's, or sales professional's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b): Title 54, Public Utilities the solicitation of sales by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(i): Title 54, Public Utilities a public utility that is regulated under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(ii): a newspaper of general circulation;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv): a nonprofit organization if no part of the net earnings from the sale inures to the benefit of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv)(A): a member, officer, trustee, or serving board member of the organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(iv)(B): an individual, or a family member of an individual, holding a position of authority or trust in the organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(v): a person who periodically publishes and delivers a catalog of the seller's merchandise to prospective purchasers, if the catalog:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(v)(A): contains the price and a written description or illustration of each item offered for sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(b)(v)(B): includes the seller's business address;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(h)(i): does not offer any premium in conjunction with a sale or offer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(h)(ii): is not selling an investment or an opportunity for an investment that is not registered with a state or federal authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(h)(iii): is not regularly engaged in telephone sales;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(i): the solicitation of a sale that is an isolated transaction and not done in the course of a pattern of repeated transactions of a similar nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(j): (2)(j)(i) the solicitation of a person by a retail business that has been in operation for at least five years in Utah under the same name as that used in connection with telemarketing if the following occur on a continuing basis:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(j)(i): at the retail business's place of business, the retail business:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(k): a person primarily soliciting the sale of a magazine or periodical sold by the publisher or the publisher's agent through a written agreement, or printed or recorded material through a contractual plan, such as a book or record club, continuity plan, subscription, standing order arrangement, or supplement or series arrangement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(k)(i): the person provides the consumer with a form that the consumer may use to instruct the person not to ship the offered merchandise, and the arrangement is regulated by the Federal Trade Commission trade regulation concerning use of negative option plans by a person making a sale in commerce; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(k)(ii):

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(l): a telephone marketing service company that provides telemarketing sales services under contract to a person making a sale if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(l)(i): the telephone marketing service company has been doing business regularly with customers in Utah for at least five years under the same business name and with the telephone marketing service company's principal office in the same location;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-4(2)(l)(iii): neither the telephone marketing service company nor the telephone marketing service company's principals have been enjoined from doing business or subjected to criminal actions for the telephone marketing service company's or the telephone marketing company's principal's business activities in this or any other state;
