Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5 Right of rescission -- Cancellation.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(1): As used in this section, "business day" means a day other than Sunday or a federal or state holiday.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(2): (2)(b); (c); (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(2)(a): (2)(b); (c) Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(2)(b): If the seller or the seller's solicitor fails to orally advise a purchaser of the right to cancel under this section at the time of a solicitation, the purchaser's right to cancel is extended to 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(2)(c): If the seller or the seller's solicitor fails to orally advise a purchaser of the seller's or the seller's solicitor's legal name, telephone number, and complete address at the time of a solicitation, the purchaser may cancel the sale at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(2)(d): (5) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(3): A purchaser may cancel a sale by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(3)(a): mailing a notice of cancellation to the seller or seller's solicitor's correct address, postage prepaid; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(3)(b): if the seller or the seller's solicitor fails to provide the purchaser with the seller's or the seller's solicitor's correct address, sending a notice of cancellation to the division's office, postage prepaid.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(4)(a): If a purchaser cancels a sale and the seller or the seller's solicitor provides the purchaser with the seller's correct address, the purchaser shall, within seven business days after the day on which the purchaser exercises the right to cancel, make a reasonable attempt to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(4)(a)(i): if the canceled sale involves durable goods, return the goods to the seller; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(4)(a)(ii): if the canceled sale involves expendable goods, return any unused portion of the goods to the seller.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(4)(b): If the seller or the seller's solicitor fails to provide to a purchaser the seller's correct address, a purchaser who cancels a sale is not required to return any canceled goods to the seller.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(5)(a): If the purchaser who cancels a sale has used any portion of the services or goods purchased, the purchaser shall provide the seller a reasonable allowance for the value given.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-5(5)(b): (5)(a) A seller may deduct the reasonable allowance described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8 Penalties.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(a): A seller or solicitor who violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(a)(i): a class B misdemeanor for a first violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(a)(ii): if the seller or solicitor has one prior violation of this chapter, a class A misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(a)(iii): if the seller or solicitor has two prior violations of this chapter, a third-degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(b): (1)(a) For the purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(b)(i): a final prior conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(b)(ii): a final determination by a court of competent jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(1)(b)(iii): a final determination in an administrative adjudicative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(2): A person who violates a provision of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty in a court of competent jurisdiction of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The division may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3)(a)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3)(a)(ii): bring a court action to enforce the provisions of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3)(a)(iii): in addition to other penalties described in this chapter, issue a cease and desist order and impose an administrative fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(3)(b): For purposes of this section, each telephone solicitation made in violation of this chapter is a separate violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-8(4): 13-2-8 The division shall deposit all administrative fines and civil penalties collected under this chapter into the Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-10 Provisions of chapter not exclusive.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The remedies, duties, prohibitions, and penalties of this chapter are not exclusive and are in addition to all other causes of action, remedies, and penalties provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11 Prohibited practices.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1): 13-26-5; 13-26-4; 13-26-5 It is unlawful for a seller to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(a): solicit a prospective purchaser if the seller is not registered with the division or exempt from registration under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(b): in connection with a telephone solicitation or a filing with the division, make or cause to be made a false material statement or fail to disclose a material fact necessary to make the seller's statement not misleading;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(c): make or authorize the making of a misrepresentation to a purchaser or prospective purchaser about the seller's compliance with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(d): 13-26-5 fail to refund within 30 days any amount due a purchaser who exercises the right to cancel under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(e): 13-26-4; 13-26-5 unless the seller is exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(f): employ an inmate in a correctional facility for telephone soliciting operations when the employment would give the inmate access to an individual's personal data, including the individual's name, address, telephone number, Social Security number, credit card information, or physical description; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(1)(g): cause or permit a solicitor to violate a provision of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(2): 13-26-4; 13-26-5 It is unlawful for a solicitor to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(2)(a): use a fictitious personal name in connection with a telephone solicitation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(2)(b): in connection with a telephone solicitation, make or cause to be made a false material statement or fail to disclose a material fact necessary to make the solicitor's statement not misleading;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(2)(c): make a misrepresentation to a purchaser or prospective purchaser about the solicitor's compliance with this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(2)(d): 13-26-4; 13-26-5 unless the solicitor is exempt under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(3): If a person knows or has reason to know that a seller or solicitor is engaged in an act or practice that violates this chapter, it is unlawful for the person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(3)(a): benefit from the seller's or solicitor's services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-26-11(3)(b): provide substantial assistance or support to the seller or solicitor.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 28 - Prize Notices Regulation Act
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-1 Title.
------------------------------------
This chapter shall be known as the "Prize Notices Regulation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
For the purpose of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(1): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection in the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(2): "Prize" means a gift, award, or other item or service of value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(a): "Prize notice" means a notice given to an individual in this state that satisfies all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(a)(i): is or contains a representation that the individual has been selected or may be eligible to receive a prize; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(a)(ii): conditions receipt of a prize on a payment or donation from the individual or requires or invites the individual to make a contact to learn how to receive the prize or to obtain other information related to the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(b): "Prize notice" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(b)(i): a notice given at the request of the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(3)(b)(ii): a notice informing the individual that he or she has been awarded a prize as a result of his actual prior entry in a game, drawing, sweepstakes, or other contest if the individual is awarded the prize stated in the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(4): "Solicitor" means a person who represents to an individual that the individual has been selected or may be eligible to receive a prize.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(5): "Sponsor" means a person on whose behalf a solicitor gives a prize notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(6): (6)(a) "Verifiable retail value" of a prize means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(6)(a): a price at which the solicitor or sponsor can demonstrate that a substantial number of the prizes have been sold by a person other than the solicitor or sponsor in the trade area in which the prize notice is given; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-2(6)(b): (6)(a) if the solicitor or sponsor is unable to satisfy Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-3 Notice requirement.
-------------------------------------------------
If a solicitor represents to an individual that he has been selected or may be eligible to receive a prize, the solicitor may not request, and the solicitor or sponsor may not accept, a payment from the individual in any form before the individual receives a written prize notice that contains all of the information required under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4 Contents of notices.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1): (2); (6) A written prize notice shall contain all of the following information presented in the manner required under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(a): the name and address of the solicitor and sponsor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(b): the verifiable retail value of each prize the individual has been selected or may be eligible to receive;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(c): if the notice lists more than one prize that the individual has been selected or may be eligible to receive, a statement of the odds the individual has of receiving each prize;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(d): any requirement or invitation for the individual to view, hear, or attend a sales presentation in order to claim a prize, the approximate length of the sales presentation and a description of the property or service that is the subject of the sales presentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(e): any requirement that the individual pay shipping or handling fees or any other charges to obtain or use a prize;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(f): if receipt of the prize is subject to a restriction, a statement that a restriction applies, a description of the restriction, and a statement containing the location in the notice where the restriction is described; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(1)(g): any limitations on eligibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(2): (1)(b); (c)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(2)(a): (1)(b); (c) The verifiable retail value and the statement of odds required in a written prize notice under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(2)(b): The statement of odds shall include, for each prize, the total number of prizes to be given away and the total number of written prize notices to be delivered.  The number of prizes and written prize notices shall be stated in Arabic numerals.  The statement of odds shall be in the following form:  "...(number of prizes) out of... written prize notices".
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(2)(c): The verifiable retail value shall be in the following form:  "verifiable retail value: $...".
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(3): If an individual is required to pay shipping or handling fees or any other charges to obtain or use a prize, the following statement shall appear in immediate proximity to each listing of the prize in each place the prize appears in the written prize notice and shall be in not less than 10-point boldface type:  "YOU MUST PAY $.... IN ORDER TO RECEIVE OR USE THIS ITEM."
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(4): (1)(d); (1)(f); (g) The information required in a written prize notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(5): If a written prize notice is given by a solicitor on behalf of a sponsor, the name of the sponsor shall be more prominently and conspicuously displayed than the name of the solicitor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(6): A solicitor or sponsor may not do any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(6)(a): place on an envelope containing a written prize notice any representation that the person to whom the envelope is addressed has been selected or may be eligible to receive a prize;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(6)(b): deliver a written prize notice that contains language, or is designed in a manner that would lead a reasonable person to believe that it originates from a government agency, public utility, insurance company, consumer reporting agency, debt collector, accounting or law firm unless the written prize notice originates from that source; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-4(6)(c): represent directly or by implication that the number of individuals eligible for the prize is limited or that an individual has been separately selected to receive a particular prize unless the representation is true.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-5 Sales presentations.
--------------------------------------------------
If a prize notice requires or invites an individual to view, hear, or attend a sales presentation in order to claim a prize, the sales presentation may not begin until the solicitor does all of the following:Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-5(1): informs the individual of the prize, if any, that has been selected to be received by or awarded to the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-5(2): 13-28-6 if the individual has been awarded a prize, delivers to the individual the prize or the item selected by the individual under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6 Prize awards -- Options if unavailable.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6(1): A solicitor who represents to an individual in a written prize notice that the individual has been awarded a prize shall provide the prize to the individual unless the prize is not available.  If the prize is not available, the solicitor shall provide the individual with any one of the following items selected by the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6(1)(a): any other prize listed in the written prize notice that is available and that is of equal or greater value;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6(1)(b): the verifiable retail value of the prize in the form of cash, a money order, or a certified check; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6(1)(c): a voucher, certificate, or other evidence of obligation stating that the prize will be shipped to the individual within 30 days at no cost to the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-6(2): (1)(c) If a voucher, certificate, or other evidence of obligation delivered under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7 Penalties -- Administrative and criminal.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7(1): Any person who violates this chapter shall be subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7(1)(a): a cease and desist order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7(1)(b): an administrative fine of not less than $100 or more than $5,000 for each separate violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7(2): 13-2-8 All administrative fines shall be deposited in the Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-7(3): Any person who intentionally violates this part is guilty of a class A misdemeanor and may be fined up to $10,000.  A person intentionally violates this part if the violation occurs after the division, attorney general, or a district or county attorney notifies the person by certified mail that he is in violation of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8 Enforcement.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8(1): The division shall investigate and assess administrative fines for violations of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8(2): 13-28-7(1); 13-28-7(3) Upon referral from the division, the attorney general or any district or county attorney may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8(2)(a): bring an action for temporary or permanent injunctive or other relief in any court of competent jurisdiction for any violation of this part.  The court may, upon entry of final judgment, award restitution when appropriate to any person suffering loss because of a violation of this part if proof of loss is submitted to the satisfaction of the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8(2)(b): 13-28-7(1) bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of penalties authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-8(2)(c): 13-28-7(3) bring an action under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-9 Private action.
---------------------------------------------
In addition to any other remedies, a person suffering pecuniary loss because of a violation by another person of this chapter may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction and may recover:Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-9(1): the greater of $500 or twice the amount of the pecuniary loss; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-28-9(2): court costs and reasonable attorney's fees as determined by the court.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 31 - Mold Retention and Lien Act
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter shall be known as the "Mold Retention and Lien Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(1): "All rights and title" does not include rights or title in patents or copyrights.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(2): "Customer" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(2)(a): causes a molder to fabricate, cast, or otherwise make a mold; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(2)(b): provides a molder with a mold to make a product for the customer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(3): "Make" includes to manufacture, assemble, cast, or fabricate.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(4): "Mold" includes a die, form, or pattern.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(5)(a): "Molder" means a person that makes or uses a mold for the purpose of making a product for a customer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-102(5)(b): "Molder" includes a tool or die maker.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-103 Relationship to federal law.
------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not affect any right of a customer under federal law related to patent, copyright, or unfair competition.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-201 Ownership rights to molds.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-201(1): Unless otherwise agreed to by the molder and the customer, the customer has all rights and title to a mold in the possession of the molder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-201(2): 13-31-202 If a customer does not claim possession from a molder of a mold within three years following the last prior use of the mold, all rights and title to the mold may be transferred to the molder in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202 Transfer of ownership to molder.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202(1): If a customer does not claim possession from a molder of a mold within three years following the last prior use of the mold, the molder may transfer all rights and title to the mold in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202(2): (2)(a); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202(2)(a): Prior to obtaining all rights and title to the mold, the molder shall send written notice by registered mail to the last-known address of the customer notifying the customer that the molder is terminating the customer's rights and title to the mold.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202(3)(b): makes other contractual arrangements with the molder for the storage of the mold.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-202(4): (2) After rights and title to a mold are transferred to the molder under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-31-203 Scope of part.
----------------------------------------------
In determining whether a customer has claimed possession of a mold within three years following the last prior use, a molder may include any period following the last prior use of a mold even if that period is prior to May 4, 1998.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 32 - Swap Meets and Flea Markets Act
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Swap Meets and Flea Markets Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(1): "Manufacturer's or distributor's representative" means a person who has available for public inspection written proof of authorization from the manufacturer or distributor of a product to offer that product for public retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(2): "New and unused property" means tangible personal property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(2)(a): was acquired by the vendor directly from the producer, manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer of that property in the ordinary course of business;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(2)(b): has never been used since its production or manufacturing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(2)(c): if the property was packaged when originally produced or manufactured, is in its original and unopened package or container.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(a): "Swap meet" or "flea market" means an event at which personal property is offered for sale or exchange:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(a)(i): by two or more persons and a fee is charged to vendors for the privilege of offering or displaying such personal property or to prospective buyers for admission to the area where such personal property is offered or displayed for sale; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(a)(ii): if the event is held more than six times in any 12-month period, regardless of the number of persons offering or displaying personal property or the absence of fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(b): The terms "swap meet" and "flea market" do not include any events:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(b)(i): that are organized for the exclusive benefit of any community chest, fund, foundation, association, or corporation organized and operated exclusively for religious, educational, or charitable purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(3)(b)(ii): at which all of the personal property offered for sale or displayed is new and unused property, and all persons selling, exchanging, offering, or displaying the personal property are manufacturer's or distributor's representatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-102(4): "Vendor" means a person who offers for sale or exchange six or more like items of new and unused property at a swap meet or flea market in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-103 Prohibited sales.
-------------------------------------------------
A vendor who is not a manufacturer's or distributor's representative may not sell or offer for sale or exchange at a swap meet or flea market any:Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-103(1): food product which is manufactured and packaged specifically for consumption by a child under two years of age;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-103(2): nonprescription or over-the-counter drug or medication other than herbal products, dietary supplements, botanical extracts, or vitamins; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-103(3): cosmetic or personal care product which has an expiration date.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104 Receipts and transaction records -- Retention of receipts and transaction records.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1): Every vendor shall maintain receipts or a permanent record book for the acquisition of new and unused property which shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1)(a): the date of the transaction on which the property was acquired;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1)(b): the name and address of the person from whom the property was acquired;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1)(c): an identification and description of the property acquired;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1)(d): the price paid for such property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(1)(e): the signatures of the person selling the property and the vendor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-104(2): (1) The receipt or record for each transaction required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105 Violations.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105(1): 13-32-104 It is a violation of this chapter for any vendor, required to maintain receipts or records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105(1)(a): falsify, obliterate, or destroy the receipts or records;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105(1)(b): refuse or fail to make such receipts available for inspection, upon the request of a law enforcement officer, within a reasonable period of time under the circumstances surrounding the request; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105(1)(c): present credentials pursuant to the requirements of this chapter which are false, fraudulent, forged, or fraudulently obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-105(2): 13-32-104 Nothing contained within this section shall be construed to require a vendor to possess the receipts or records required by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-106 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
A person who violates this chapter is guilty of an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107 Exemptions.
-------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter do not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107(1): the sale of a motor vehicle or trailer that is required to be registered or is subject to the certificate of title laws of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107(2): the sale of agricultural products, forestry products, livestock, or food products other than those which are manufactured and packaged specifically for consumption by a child under two years of age;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107(3): business conducted at any industry or association trade show;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107(4): the sale of arts or crafts by the person who produced such arts and crafts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32-107(5): anyone who displays only samples, catalogs, or brochures and sells property for future delivery.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 32a - Pawnshop, Secondhand Merchandise, and Catalytic Converter Transaction Information Act
************************************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Pawnshop, Secondhand Merchandise, and Catalytic Converter Transaction Information Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(1): 13-32a-113 "Account" means the Pawnbroker, Secondhand Merchandise, and Catalytic Converter Operations Restricted Account created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(2): "Antique item" means an item:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(2)(a): that is generally older than 25 years;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(2)(b): whose value is based on age, rarity, condition, craftsmanship, or collectability;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(2)(c): that is furniture or other decorative objects produced in a previous time period, as distinguished from new items of a similar nature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(2)(d): obtained from auctions, estate sales, other antique shops, and individuals.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(3): "Antique shop" means a business operating at an established location that deals primarily in the purchase, exchange, or sale of antique items.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4): "Automated recycling kiosk" means an interactive machine that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(a): is installed inside a commercial site used for the selling of goods and services to consumers;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(b): is monitored remotely by a live representative during the hours of operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(c): only engages in secondhand merchandise transactions involving wireless communication devices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(d): has the following technological functions:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(d)(i): verifies the seller's identity by a live representative using the individual's identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(d)(ii): generates a ticket; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(4)(d)(iii): electronically transmits the secondhand merchandise transaction information to the central database.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(5): "Automated recycling kiosk operator" means a person whose sole business activity is the operation of one or more automated recycling kiosks.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(6): 76-6-1402 "Catalytic converter" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(a): "Catalytic converter purchase" means a purchase from an individual of a used catalytic converter that is no longer affixed to a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(b): "Catalytic converter purchase" does not mean a purchase of a catalytic converter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(b)(i): from a business regularly engaged in automobile repair, crushing, dismantling, recycling, or salvage;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(b)(ii): from a new or used vehicle dealer licensed under Title 41, Chapter 3, Motor Vehicle Business Regulation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(b)(iii): from another catalytic converter purchaser; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(7)(b)(iv): that has never been affixed to a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(8): "Catalytic converter purchaser" means a person who purchases a used catalytic converter in a catalytic converter purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(9): 13-32a-105 "Central database" or "database" means the electronic database created and operated under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(10): "Children's product" means a used item that is for the exclusive use of children, or for the care of children, including clothing and toys.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(11): "Children's product resale business" means a business operating at a commercial location and primarily selling children's products.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(12): "Coin" means a piece of currency, usually metallic and usually in the shape of a disc that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(12)(a): stamped metal, and issued by a government as monetary currency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(12)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(12)(b)(i): worth more than its current value as currency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(12)(b)(ii): worth more than its metal content value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(13): "Coin dealer" means a person whose sole business activity is the selling and purchasing of numismatic items and precious metals.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(14): "Collectible paper money" means paper currency that is no longer in circulation and is sold and purchased for the paper currency's collectible value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(15)(a): "Commercial grade precious metals" or "precious metals" means ingots, monetized bullion, art bars, medallions, medals, tokens, and currency that are marked by the refiner or fabricator indicating their fineness and include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(15)(a)(i): .99 fine or finer ingots of gold, silver, platinum, palladium, or other precious metals; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(15)(a)(ii): .925 fine sterling silver ingots, art bars, and medallions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(15)(b): "Commercial grade precious metals" or "precious metals" does not include jewelry.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(16): "Consignment shop" means a business, operating at an established location:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(16)(a): that deals primarily in the offering for sale property owned by a third party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(16)(b): where the owner of the property only receives consideration upon the sale of the property by the business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(17): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection created in Chapter 1, Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(18): "Exonumia"  means a privately issued token for trade that is sold and purchased for the token's collectible value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19): "Gift card" means a record that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19)(a): is usable at:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19)(a)(i): a single merchant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19)(a)(ii): a specified group of merchants;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19)(b): is prefunded before the record is used; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(19)(c): can be used for the purchase of goods or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20): 53-3-207 "Identification" means any of the following non-expired forms of identification issued by a state government, the United States government, or a federally recognized Indian tribe, if the identification includes a unique number, photograph of the bearer, and date of birth:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(a): a United States Passport or United States Passport Card;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(b): a state-issued driver license;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(c): a state-issued identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(d): a state-issued concealed carry permit;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(e): a United States military identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(f): a United States resident alien card;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(g): an identification of a federally recognized Indian tribe; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(20)(h): 53-3-207 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(21): "IMEI number" means an International Mobile Equipment Identity number.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(22): "Indicia of being new" means property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(22)(a): is represented by the individual pawning or selling the property as new;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(22)(b): is unopened in the original packaging; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(22)(c): possesses other distinguishing characteristics that indicate the property is new.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(23): "Local law enforcement agency" means the law enforcement agency that has direct responsibility for ensuring compliance with central database reporting requirements for the jurisdiction where the pawn or secondhand business or catalytic converter purchaser is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(24): "Numismatic item" means a coin, collectible paper money, or exonumia.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(25): "Original victim" means a victim who is not a party to the pawn or sale transaction or catalytic converter purchase and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(25)(a): an authorized representative designated in writing by the original victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(25)(b): an insurer who has indemnified the original victim for the loss of the described property.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(26): "Pawn or secondhand business" means a business operated by a pawnbroker or secondhand merchandise dealer, or the owner or operator of the business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(27): "Pawn transaction" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(27)(a): an extension of credit in which an individual delivers property to a pawnbroker for an advance of money and retains the right to redeem the property for the redemption price within a fixed period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(27)(b): a loan of money on one or more deposits of personal property;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(27)(c): the purchase, exchange, or possession of personal property on condition of selling the same property back again to the pledgor or depositor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(27)(d): a loan or advance of money on personal property by the pawnbroker taking chattel mortgage security on the personal property, taking or receiving the personal property into the pawnbroker's possession, and selling the unredeemed pledges.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(28): "Pawnbroker" means a person whose business:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(28)(a): engages in a pawn transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(28)(b): holds itself out as being in the business of a pawnbroker or pawnshop, regardless of whether the person or business enters into pawn transactions or secondhand merchandise transactions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(29): "Pawnshop" means the physical location or premises where a pawnbroker conducts business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(30): "Pledgor" means an individual who conducts a pawn transaction with a pawnshop.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(31): "Property" means an article of tangible personal property, numismatic item, precious metal, gift card, transaction card, or other physical or digital card or certificate evidencing store credit, and includes a wireless communication device.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(32): "Retail media item" means recorded music, a movie, or a video game that is produced and distributed in hard copy format for retail sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(33): "Scrap jewelry" means an item purchased solely:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(33)(a): for its gold, silver, or platinum content; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(33)(b): for the purpose of reuse of the metal content.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34): 41-1a-102; 76-6-1402
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(a): "Secondhand merchandise dealer" means a person whose business:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(a)(i): engages in a secondhand merchandise transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(a)(ii): does not engage in a pawn transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(b): "Secondhand merchandise dealer" includes a coin dealer and an automated recycling kiosk operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c): 41-1a-102; 76-6-1402 "Secondhand merchandise dealer" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(i): an antique shop when dealing in antique items;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(ii): 41-1a-102 a person who operates an auction house, flea market, or vehicle, vessel, and outboard motor dealers as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(iii): the sale of secondhand goods at events commonly known as "garage sales," "yard sales," "estate sales," "storage unit sales," or "storage unit auctions";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(iv): the sale or receipt of secondhand books, magazines, post cards, or nonelectronic:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(iv)(A): card games;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(iv)(B): table-top games; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(iv)(C): magic tricks;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(v): the sale or receipt of used merchandise donated to recognized nonprofit, religious, or charitable organizations or any school-sponsored association, and for which no compensation is paid;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(vi): the sale or receipt of secondhand clothing, shoes, furniture, or appliances;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(vii): a person offering the person's own personal property for sale, purchase, consignment, or trade via the Internet;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(viii): a person offering the personal property of others for sale, purchase, consignment, or trade via the Internet, when that person does not have, and is not required to have, a local business or occupational license or other authorization for this activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(ix): an owner or operator of a retail business that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(ix)(A): receives used merchandise as a trade-in for similar new merchandise  ; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(ix)(B): receives used retail media items as a trade-in for similar new or used retail media items;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(x): an owner or operator of a business that contracts with other persons to offer those persons' secondhand goods for sale, purchase, consignment, or trade via the Internet;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xi): 76-6-1402 any dealer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xii): the purchase of items in bulk that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xii)(A): sold at wholesale in bulk packaging;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xii)(B): sold by a person licensed to conduct business in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xii)(C): regularly sold in bulk quantities as a recognized form of sale;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xiii): the owner or operator of a children's product resale business;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xiv): a consignment shop when dealing in consigned property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(34)(c)(xv): a catalytic converter purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(35): "Secondhand merchandise transaction" means the purchase or exchange of used or secondhand property.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(36): "Ticket" means a document upon which information is entered when a pawn transaction or secondhand merchandise transaction is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(37): "Transaction card" means a card, code, or other means of access to a value with the retail business issued to a person that allows the person to obtain, purchase, or receive any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(37)(a): goods;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(37)(b): services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(37)(c): money; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(37)(d): anything else of value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102(38): "Wireless communication device" means a cellular telephone or a portable electronic device designed to receive and transmit a text message, email, video, or voice communication.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102.5 Administration and enforcement.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102.5(1): Title 13, Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection The division shall administer and enforce this chapter in accordance with the authority under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102.5(2): The attorney general, upon request, shall give legal advice to, and act as counsel for, the division in the exercise of its responsibilities under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102.5(3): Reasonable attorney fees, costs, and interest shall be awarded to the division in any action brought to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-102.5(4): Municipal and county law enforcement agencies, prosecutorial agencies, and governmental agencies may enforce the criminal and civil provisions of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1 Transaction or gift cards.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1(1): A retail business engaging in a transaction involving a transaction card or gift card issued by that retail business and that bears the branding of that retail business is not subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1(2): A pawn or secondhand business may not purchase or pawn a gift card or transaction card.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1(3): This chapter does not prohibit a pawn or secondhand business from issuing or accepting as payment a gift card that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1(3)(a): is issued solely by the pawn or secondhand business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-103.1(3)(b): bears the brand or name of the pawn or secondhand business.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(1)(f): the amount paid for each wireless communication device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(1)(g): (4) subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(1)(g)(iii): other unique identifying characteristics.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4): 13-32a-109(1)(b) If an automated recycling kiosk cannot electronically extract a wireless communication device's serial number or IMEI number from the wireless communication device at the time of the transaction:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4)(a): the automated recycling kiosk operator may not pay the seller more than $25 for the wireless communication device;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4)(b): the automated recycling kiosk operator shall engage in and document reasonable efforts to obtain and upload to the central database the wireless communication device's serial number and IMEI number within 15 calendar days of the date of the transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4)(c): 13-32a-109(1)(b) the central database information for the wireless communication device may not be considered submitted for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4)(c)(i): the wireless communication device's serial number and IMEI number have both been uploaded to the central database; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(4)(c)(ii): more than 45 calendar days have passed since the date of the transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(5): An automated recycling kiosk operator may not purchase more than 10 wireless communication devices with serial numbers or IMEI numbers that cannot be electronically extracted by an automated recycling kiosk at the time of the transaction from the same individual during the same calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-32a-104.6(6): An automated recycling kiosk operator may only purchase a wireless communication device with serial numbers or IMEI numbers that cannot be electronically extracted by an automated recycling kiosk at the time of the transaction in a single-item transaction.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 34 - Utah Postsecondary School and State Authorization Act
***************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(1): "Accredited postsecondary school" means a postsecondary school that is accredited by an accrediting agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(2): (2)(b) "Accrediting agency" means a private educational association that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(2)(a): is recognized by the United States Department of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(2)(b): develops education criteria; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(2)(c): (2)(b) conducts evaluations to assess whether a postsecondary school meets the criteria described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3): "Agent" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3)(a): owns an interest in a postsecondary school;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3)(b): is employed by a postsecondary school;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3)(c): enrolls or attempts to enroll a Utah resident in a postsecondary school;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3)(d): offers to award an educational credential on behalf of a postsecondary school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(3)(e): holds oneself out to a Utah resident as representing a postsecondary school for any purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(4): 35A-6-102 "Apprentice" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(5): 35A-6-102 "Apprenticeship" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(6): "Distance postsecondary education" means the same as that term is defined in 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1003(7).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(7): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(8): "Educational credential" means a degree, diploma, certificate, transcript, report, document, letter of designation, mark, or series of letters, numbers, or words that represent enrollment, attendance, or satisfactory completion of the requirements or prerequisites of an educational program.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(9): "Longstanding nonprofit accredited postsecondary school" means an accredited postsecondary school that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(9)(a): is a nonprofit organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(9)(b): has operated continuously as a nonprofit for at least 20 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(10): 16-6a-102 "Nonprofit organization" means a nonprofit corporation or foreign nonprofit corporation as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(11): "Operate" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(11)(a): maintain a physical presence in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(11)(b): provide postsecondary education to an individual who resides in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(12): "Physical presence" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(12)(a): to maintain in the state a physical location where a student receives postsecondary education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(12)(b): to provide to a student distance postsecondary education from a location in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(13)(a): "Postsecondary education" means education or educational services offered primarily to an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(13)(a)(i): has completed or terminated their secondary or high school education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(13)(a)(ii): is beyond the age of compulsory school attendance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(13)(b): "Postsecondary education" does not include instruction at or below the 12th grade level.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(14): "Postsecondary school" means a person that offers postsecondary education:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(14)(a): in exchange for payment of tuition, fees, or other consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(14)(b): for the purpose of attaining educational, professional, or vocational objectives.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(15): "Principal" means a postsecondary school's owner, officer, director, trustee, or administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(16): 53B-1-102 "Public postsecondary school" means a postsecondary school that is:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(16)(b): substantially supported with government funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(17): 13-34-303 "Reciprocity agreement" means an agreement the division enters into with another state in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(18)(a): "Registration certificate" means approval from the division to operate a postsecondary school in accordance with this chapter, and with rules adopted in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(18)(b): "Registration certificate" does not mean an approval or endorsement of the postsecondary school by the division or the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(19): "Registration statement" means an application and accompanying documentation required under this chapter for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(19)(a): a registration certificate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-101(19)(b): a state authorization certificate.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-107 Limitation of authority.
--------------------------------------------------------
Except for satisfying the provisions of this chapter and any rule made by the division in accordance with this chapter, nothing in this chapter authorizes the division to regulate educational content or to regulate a postsecondary school's day-to-day operations.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-108(1)(a)(i): the person files with the division a registration statement for the postsecondary school that complies with:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-108(2): A person who operates a postsecondary school, a postsecondary school, or a postsecondary school's agent or principal may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-108(2)(a): omit from a registration statement a material statement of fact required by this chapter or rule made by the division under this chapter;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111 Exemptions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(1): As used in this section, "State Authorization Reciprocity Agreement" or "SARA" means an agreement among member states, districts, and territories establishing comparable national standards for offering interstate postsecondary distance education courses and programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(2): (2)(b); (2)(a); 13-34-302
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(2)(b): (2)(a); 13-34-302 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(3): 13-34-201; 13-34-205; (3)(d)(i)(A); Title 35A, Chapter 6, Apprenticeship Act; 35A-6-104 A postsecondary school is exempt from Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(3)(a)(i): is an active participant institution in SARA that provides distance education to a person in Utah in accordance with SARA; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-111(3)(a)(ii): does not maintain a physical presence in the state;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-113(2)(c): rescission of a contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-113(2)(d): for a loss suffered as a result of a violation of this chapter, an amount equal to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-113(2)(d)(i): actual damages; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-113(2)(d)(ii): $2,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-34-113(2)(e): an award of reasonable attorney fees and court costs.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 35 - Powersport Vehicle Franchise Act
******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Powersport Vehicle Franchise Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(1): 13-35-103 "Advisory board" or "board" means the Utah Powersport Vehicle Franchise Advisory Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(2): 13-35-105 "Dealership" means a site or location in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(2)(a): at which a franchisee conducts the business of a new powersport vehicle dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(2)(b): 13-35-105 that is identified as a new powersport vehicle dealer's principal place of business for registration purposes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(3): "Department" means the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(4): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(5): "Franchise" or "franchise agreement" means a written agreement, for a definite or indefinite period, in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(5)(a): a person grants to another person a license to use a trade name, trademark, service mark, or related characteristic; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(5)(b): a community of interest exists in the marketing of new powersport vehicles, new powersport vehicle parts, and services related to the sale or lease of new powersport vehicles at wholesale or retail.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6): "Franchisee" means a person with whom a franchisor has agreed or permitted, in writing or in practice, to purchase, sell, or offer for sale new powersport vehicles manufactured, produced, represented, or distributed by the franchisor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7): (7)(a)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(a): "Franchisor" means a person who has, in writing or in practice, agreed with or permits a franchisee to purchase, sell, or offer for sale new powersport vehicles manufactured, produced, represented, or distributed by the franchisor, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(a)(i): the manufacturer or distributor of the new powersport vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(a)(ii): an intermediate distributor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(a)(iii): an agent, officer, or field or area representative of the franchisor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(a)(iv): a person who is affiliated with a manufacturer or a representative or who directly or indirectly through an intermediary is controlled by, or is under common control with the manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7)(b): (7)(a)(iv) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(8): "Lead" means the referral by a franchisor to a franchisee of an actual or potential customer for the purchase or lease of a new powersport vehicle, or for service work related to the franchisor's vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(9): "Line-make" means the powersport vehicles that are offered for sale, lease, or distribution under a common name, trademark, service mark, or brand name of the franchisor, or manufacturer of the powersport vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(10): "New powersport vehicle dealer" means a person who is engaged in the business of buying, selling, offering for sale, or exchanging new powersport vehicles either outright or on conditional sale, bailment, lease, chattel mortgage, or otherwise who has established a place of business for the sale, lease, trade, or display of powersport vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(11): "Notice" or "notify" includes both traditional written communications and all reliable forms of electronic communication unless expressly prohibited by statute or rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(1): 13-35-105 "Dealership" means a site or location in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(1)(a): at which a franchisee conducts the business of a new powersport vehicle dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(1)(b): 13-35-105 that is identified as a new powersport vehicle dealer's principal place of business for registration purposes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(2): "Department" means the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(3): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(4): "Franchise" or "franchise agreement" means a written agreement, for a definite or indefinite period, in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(4)(a): a person grants to another person a license to use a trade name, trademark, service mark, or related characteristic; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(4)(b): a community of interest exists in the marketing of new powersport vehicles, new powersport vehicle parts, and services related to the sale or lease of new powersport vehicles at wholesale or retail.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(5): "Franchisee" means a person with whom a franchisor has agreed or permitted, in writing or in practice, to purchase, sell, or offer for sale new powersport vehicles manufactured, produced, represented, or distributed by the franchisor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(a): "Franchisor" means a person who has, in writing or in practice, agreed with or permits a franchisee to purchase, sell, or offer for sale new powersport vehicles manufactured, produced, represented, or distributed by the franchisor, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(a)(i): the manufacturer or distributor of the new powersport vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(a)(ii): an intermediate distributor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(a)(iii): an agent, officer, or field or area representative of the franchisor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(a)(iv): a person who is affiliated with a manufacturer or a representative or who directly or indirectly through an intermediary is controlled by, or is under common control with the manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(6)(b): For purposes of Subsection (6)(a)(iv), a person is controlled by a manufacturer if the manufacturer has the authority directly or indirectly by law or by an agreement of the parties, to direct or influence the management and policies of the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(7): "Lead" means the referral by a franchisor to a franchisee of an actual or potential customer for the purchase or lease of a new powersport vehicle, or for service work related to the franchisor's vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(8): "Line-make" means the powersport vehicles that are offered for sale, lease, or distribution under a common name, trademark, service mark, or brand name of the franchisor, or manufacturer of the powersport vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(9): "New powersport vehicle dealer" means a person who is engaged in the business of buying, selling, offering for sale, or exchanging new powersport vehicles either outright or on conditional sale, bailment, lease, chattel mortgage, or otherwise who has established a place of business for the sale, lease, trade, or display of powersport vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-102(10): "Notice" or "notify" includes both traditional written communications and all reliable forms of electronic communication unless expressly prohibited by statute or rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201 Prohibited acts by franchisors -- Disclosures.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1): (2); 70A-2-608; 70A-2-602; (2); (5); 13-35-102; (1)(cc); (6); (7) A franchisor in this state may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(a): (2) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(b): require a franchisee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(b)(i): participate monetarily in any advertising campaign or contest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(b)(ii): purchase any promotional materials, display devices, or display decorations or materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(c): require a franchisee to change the capital structure of the franchisee's dealership or the means by or through which the franchisee finances the operation of the franchisee's dealership, if the dealership at all times meets reasonable capital standards determined by and applied in a nondiscriminatory manner by the franchisor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(d): require a franchisee to refrain from participating in the management of, investment in, or acquisition of any other line of new powersport vehicles or related products, if the franchisee:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(d)(i): maintains a reasonable line of credit for each make or line of powersport vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(d)(ii): complies with reasonable capital and facilities requirements of the franchisor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(e): require a franchisee to prospectively agree to a release, assignment, novation, waiver, or estoppel that would:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(e)(i): relieve a franchisor from any liability, including notice and hearing rights imposed on the franchisor by this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(e)(ii): require any controversy between the franchisee and a franchisor to be referred to a third party if the decision by the third party would be binding;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(f): require a franchisee to change the location of the principal place of business of the franchisee's dealership or make any substantial alterations to the dealership premises, if the change or alterations would be unreasonable;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(g): coerce or attempt to coerce a franchisee to join, contribute to, or affiliate with an advertising association;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(h): require, coerce, or attempt to coerce a franchisee to enter into an agreement with the franchisor or do any other act that is unfair or prejudicial to the franchisee, by threatening to cancel a franchise agreement or other contractual agreement or understanding existing between the franchisor and franchisee;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(i): adopt, change, establish, modify, or implement a plan or system for the allocation, scheduling, or delivery of new powersport vehicles, parts, or accessories to its franchisees so that the plan or system is not fair, reasonable, and equitable;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(j): increase the price of any new powersport vehicle that the franchisee has ordered from the franchisor and for which there exists at the time of the order a bona fide sale to a retail purchaser if the order was made prior to the franchisee's receipt of an official written price increase notification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k): 70A-2-608; 70A-2-602 fail to indemnify and hold harmless its franchisee against any judgment for damages or settlement approved in writing by the franchisor:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i): 70A-2-608; 70A-2-602 including court costs and attorneys' fees arising out of actions, claims, or proceedings including those based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(A): strict liability;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(B): negligence;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(C): misrepresentation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(D): express or implied warranty;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(E): 70A-2-608 revocation as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(i)(F): 70A-2-602 rejection as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(k)(ii): to the extent the judgment or settlement relates to alleged defective or negligent actions by the franchisor;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(l): threaten or coerce a franchisee to waive or forbear its right to protest the establishment or relocation of a same line-make franchisee in the relevant market area of the affected franchisee;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1): 70A-2-608; 70A-2-602; 13-35-102 A franchisor in this state may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(a): except as provided in Subsection (2), require a franchisee to order or accept delivery of any new powersport vehicle, part, accessory, equipment, or other item not otherwise required by law that is not voluntarily ordered by the franchisee;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(b)(i): participate monetarily in any advertising campaign or contest; or

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(1)(d): require a franchisee to refrain from participating in the management of, investment in, or acquisition of any other line of new powersport vehicles or related products, if the franchisee:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(7)(b): require a franchisor to disregard the preference of a potential customer in providing or directing a lead, provided that the franchisor does not direct the customer to such a preference.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-201(8): Subsection (1)(ff) does not limit the right of an affiliate to engage in business practices in accordance with the usage of trade in which the affiliate is engaged.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203 Succession to franchise.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a): A successor, including a family member of a deceased or incapacitated franchisee, who is designated by the franchisee may succeed the franchisee in the ownership and operation of the dealership under the existing franchise agreement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(i): the designated successor gives the franchisor written notice of an intent to succeed to the rights of the deceased or incapacitated franchisee in the franchise agreement within 180 days after the franchisee's death or incapacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(ii): the designated successor agrees to be bound by all of the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(iii): the designated successor meets the criteria generally applied by the franchisor in qualifying franchisees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(b): A franchisor may refuse to honor the existing franchise agreement with the designated successor only for good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2)(a): The franchisor may request in writing from a designated successor the personal and financial data that is reasonably necessary to determine whether the existing franchise agreement should be honored.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2)(b): The designated successor shall supply the personal and financial data promptly upon the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3): (3)(a); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a): If a franchisor believes that good cause exists for refusing to honor the requested succession, the franchisor shall serve upon the designated successor notice of its refusal to approve the succession, within 60 days after the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a)(i): receipt of the notice of the designated successor's intent to succeed the franchisee in the ownership and operation of the dealership; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a)(ii): the receipt of the requested personal and financial data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(b): (3)(a); (3)(a) Failure to serve the notice pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4): (3); (6) The notice of the franchisor provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4)(a): the specific grounds for the refusal to approve the succession; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4)(b): (6) that discontinuance of the franchise agreement shall take effect not less than 180 days after the date the notice of refusal is served unless the proposed successor files an application for hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5)(a): This section does not prevent a franchisee from designating a person as the successor by written instrument filed with the franchisor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5)(b): (5)(a) If a franchisee files an instrument under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6): (3); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(a): (3); (4) If a franchisor serves a notice of refusal to a designated successor pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b): If application for a hearing is timely filed, the franchisor shall continue to honor the franchise agreement until after:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b)(i): the requested hearing has been concluded;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b)(ii): a decision is rendered by the executive director; and

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203 Succession to franchise.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a): A successor, including a family member of a deceased or incapacitated franchisee, who is designated by the franchisee may succeed the franchisee in the ownership and operation of the dealership under the existing franchise agreement if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(i): the designated successor gives the franchisor written notice of an intent to succeed to the rights of the deceased or incapacitated franchisee in the franchise agreement within 180 days after the franchisee's death or incapacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(ii): the designated successor agrees to be bound by all of the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(a)(iii): the designated successor meets the criteria generally applied by the franchisor in qualifying franchisees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(1)(b): A franchisor may refuse to honor the existing franchise agreement with the designated successor only for good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2)(a): The franchisor may request in writing from a designated successor the personal and financial data that is reasonably necessary to determine whether the existing franchise agreement should be honored.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(2)(b): The designated successor shall supply the personal and financial data promptly upon the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a): If a franchisor believes that good cause exists for refusing to honor the requested succession, the franchisor shall serve upon the designated successor notice of its refusal to approve the succession, within 60 days after the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a)(i): receipt of the notice of the designated successor's intent to succeed the franchisee in the ownership and operation of the dealership; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(a)(ii): the receipt of the requested personal and financial data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(3)(b): Failure to serve the notice pursuant to Subsection (3)(a) is considered approval of the designated successor and the franchise agreement is considered amended to reflect the approval of the succession the day following the last day the franchisor can serve notice under Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4): The notice of the franchisor provided in Subsection (3) shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4)(a): the specific grounds for the refusal to approve the succession; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(4)(b): that discontinuance of the franchise agreement shall take effect not less than 180 days after the date the notice of refusal is served unless the proposed successor files an application for hearing under Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5)(a): This section does not prevent a franchisee from designating a person as the successor by written instrument filed with the franchisor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(5)(b): If a franchisee files an instrument under Subsection (5)(a), the instrument governs the succession rights to the management and operation of the dealership subject to the designated successor satisfying the franchisor's qualification requirements as described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(a): If a franchisor serves a notice of refusal to a designated successor pursuant to Subsection (3), the designated successor may, within the 180-day period provided in Subsection (4), file with the executive director an application for a hearing and a determination by the executive director regarding whether good cause exists for the refusal.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b): If application for a hearing is timely filed, the franchisor shall continue to honor the franchise agreement until after:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b)(i): the requested hearing has been concluded;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b)(ii): a decision is rendered by the executive director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-203(6)(b)(iii): the applicable appeal period has expired following a decision by the executive director.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(1)(a): the franchisee's obligations for new powersport vehicle preparation, delivery, and warranty service on its products;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(1)(b): the schedule of compensation to be paid to the franchisee for parts, work, and service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(1)(c): the time allowance for the performance of work and service.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(2)(a): (1) The schedule of compensation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(2)(b): (1) Time allowances described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(3)(a): In the determination of what constitutes reasonable compensation under this section, the principal factor to be considered is the prevailing wage rates being paid by franchisees in the relevant market area in which the franchisee is doing business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(3)(b): (3)(b) Compensation of the franchisee for warranty service work may not be less than the amount charged by the franchisee for like parts and service to retail or fleet customers, if the amounts are reasonable.  For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-35-204(4): A franchisor may not fail to:
