Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120 Termination of agreement.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(1): An individual who is a party to an agreement may terminate the agreement at any time, without penalty or obligation, by giving the provider notice in a record.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(2): A provider may terminate an agreement if an individual who is a party to the agreement fails for 60 days to make a payment or deposit required by the agreement or if other good cause exists.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(3): 13-42-123 If an agreement is terminated:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(3)(a): 13-42-123 the provider, no later than seven business days after the termination, shall pay the individual who is a party to the agreement all money the provider or its designee received from or on behalf of the individual, other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(3)(a)(i): an amount properly disbursed to a creditor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(3)(a)(ii): 13-42-123 fees earned pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-120(3)(b): any power of attorney granted by the individual to the provider is revoked.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-121 Required language.
--------------------------------------------------
Unless the administrator, by rule, provides otherwise, the disclosures and documents required by this chapter shall be in English.  If a provider communicates with an individual primarily in a language other than English, the provider shall furnish a translation in the other language of the disclosures and documents required by this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122 Trust account.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(1): All money paid to a provider by or on behalf of an individual for distribution to creditors pursuant to a plan is held in trust.  No later than two business days after receipt, the provider shall deposit the money in a trust account established for the benefit of individuals to whom the provider is furnishing debt-management services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2): 13-42-102(2)(b)(iv) A provider whose agreement contemplates the settlement of an individual's debt for less than the principal amount of the debt may request or require the individual to place money in an account to be used to pay a creditor or the provider's fees, or both, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2)(a): the money is held in an insured account at a bank;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2)(b): the individual owns the money held in the account and is paid any interest accrued on the account;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2)(c): 13-42-102(2)(b)(iv) the entity administering the account is not the provider or an affiliate of the provider, unless the affiliate is described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2)(d): the entity administering the account does not give or accept any money or other compensation in exchange for a referral of business involving debt-management services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(2)(e): the individual may terminate the agreement at any time without penalty and on termination must receive all money in the account, other than money earned by the provider in compliance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(3): (1) If an agreement contemplates the reduction of finance charges or fees for late payment, default, or delinquency, and the provider complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(4): Money held in trust by a provider is not property of the provider or its designee.  The money is not available to creditors of the provider or designee, except an individual from whom or on whose behalf the provider received money, to the extent that the money has not been disbursed to creditors of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5): A provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5)(a): maintain separate records of account for each individual to whom the provider is furnishing debt-management services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5)(b): disburse money paid by or on behalf of the individual to creditors of the individual as disclosed in the agreement, except that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5)(b)(i): the provider may delay payment to the extent that a payment by the individual is not final; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5)(b)(ii): if a plan provides for regular periodic payments to creditors, the disbursement shall comply with the due dates established by each creditor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(5)(c): promptly correct any payments that are not made or that are misdirected as a result of an error by the provider or other person in control of the trust account and reimburse the individual for any costs or fees imposed by a creditor as a result of the failure to pay or misdirection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(6): A provider may not commingle money in a trust account established for the benefit of individuals to whom the provider is furnishing debt-management services with money of other persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(7): A trust account shall at all times have a cash balance equal to the sum of the balances of each individual's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(8): (1) If a provider has established a trust account pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(9): If a provider discovers, or has a reasonable suspicion of, embezzlement or other unlawful appropriation of money held in trust, the provider immediately shall notify the administrator by a method approved by the administrator.  Unless the administrator by rule provides otherwise, no later than five days thereafter, the provider shall give notice to the administrator describing the remedial action taken or to be taken.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(10): 13-42-123 If an individual terminates an agreement or it becomes reasonably apparent to a provider that a plan has failed, the provider shall promptly refund to the individual all money paid by or on behalf of the individual which has not been paid to creditors, less fees that are payable to the provider under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-122(11): Before relocating a trust account from one bank to another, a provider shall inform the administrator of the name, business address, and telephone number of the new bank.  As soon as practicable, the provider shall inform the administrator of the account number of the trust account at the new bank.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-124 Voluntary contributions.
--------------------------------------------------------
A provider may not solicit a voluntary contribution from an individual or an affiliate of the individual for any service provided to the individual.  A provider may accept voluntary contributions from an individual but, until 30 days after completion or termination of a plan, the aggregate amount of money received from or on behalf of the individual may not exceed the total amount the provider may charge the individual under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-126 Retention of records.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-126(1): For each individual for whom a provider provides debt-management services, the provider shall maintain records for five years after the final payment made by the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-126(2): The provider shall produce a copy of the records to the individual within a reasonable time after a request for the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-126(3): The provider may use electronic or other means of storage of the records.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127 Periodic reports and retention of records.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(1): (2) A provider shall provide the accounting required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(1)(a): on cancellation or termination of an agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(1)(b): before cancellation or termination of any agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(1)(b)(i): at least once each month; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(1)(b)(ii): no later than five business days after a request by an individual, but the provider need not comply with more than one request in any calendar month.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2): A provider, in a record, shall provide each individual for whom it has established a plan an accounting of the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(a): the amount in an account containing money paid by or on behalf of the individual for fees or distribution to a creditor, or both, as of the date one month before the date of the accounting;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(b): the amount paid into the account since the last report;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(d): the amounts deducted, as fees or otherwise, from the amount paid into the account since the last report;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(e): if, since the last report, a creditor has agreed to accept as payment in full an amount less than the principal amount of the debt owed by the individual:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(e)(iv): the calculation of a settlement fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-127(2)(f): the amount in the account as of the date of the accounting.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128 Prohibited acts and practices.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1): A provider may not, directly or indirectly:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(a): include a secured debt in a plan, except as authorized by law other than this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(b): misappropriate or misapply money held in trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(c): settle a debt on behalf of an individual, unless the individual assents to the settlement after the creditor has assented;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(d): take a power of attorney that authorizes it to settle a debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(e): exercise or attempt to exercise a power of attorney after an individual has terminated an agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(f): initiate a transfer from an individual's account at a bank or with another person unless the transfer is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(f)(i): a return of money to the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(f)(ii): before termination of an agreement, properly authorized by the agreement and this chapter, and for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(f)(ii)(A): payment to one or more creditors pursuant to an agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(f)(ii)(B): payment of a fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(g): offer a gift or bonus, premium, reward, or other compensation to an individual for executing an agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(h): offer, pay, or give a gift or bonus, premium, reward, or other compensation to a lead generator or other person for referring a prospective customer, if the person making the referral:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(h)(i): has a financial interest in the outcome of debt-management services provided to the customer, unless neither the provider nor the person making the referral communicates to the prospective customer the identity of the source of the referral; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(h)(ii): compensates its employees on the basis of a formula that incorporates the number of individuals the employee refers to the provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(i): receive a bonus, commission, or other benefit for referring an individual to a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(j): structure a plan in a manner that would result in a negative amortization of any of an individual's debts, unless a creditor that is owed a negatively amortizing debt agrees to refund or waive the finance charge on payment of the principal amount of the debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(k): compensate its employees on the basis of a formula that incorporates the number of individuals the employee induces to enter into agreements;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(l): settle a debt or lead an individual to believe that a payment to a creditor is in settlement of a debt to the creditor unless, at the time of settlement, the individual receives a certification by the creditor that the payment:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(l)(i): is in full settlement of the debt; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(l)(ii): is part of a settlement plan, the terms of which are included in the certification, that, if completed according to its terms, will satisfy the debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(m): make a representation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(m)(i): the provider will furnish money to pay bills or prevent attachments;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(m)(ii): payment of a certain amount will permit satisfaction of a certain amount or range of indebtedness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(m)(iii): participation in a plan will or may prevent litigation, garnishment, attachment, repossession, foreclosure, eviction, or loss of employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(n): misrepresent that it is authorized or competent to furnish legal advice or perform legal services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(o): represent in its agreements, disclosures required by this chapter, advertisements, or Internet website that it is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(o)(i): a not-for-profit entity unless it is organized and properly operating as a not-for-profit entity under the law of the state in which it was formed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(o)(ii): a tax-exempt entity unless it has received certification of tax-exempt status from the Internal Revenue Service and is properly operating as a not-for-profit entity under the law of the state in which it was formed;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(p): take a confession of judgment or power of attorney to confess judgment against an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(q): employ an unfair, unconscionable, or deceptive act or practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r): knowingly omit any material information or material aspect of any provider's service, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(i): the amount of money or the percentage of the debt amount that an individual may save by using the provider's service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(ii): the amount of time necessary to achieve the results that the provider represents as achievable;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iii): the amount of money or the percentage of each outstanding debt that the individual is required to accumulate before the provider will:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iii)(A): initiate an attempt with the individual's creditors or debt collectors to negotiate, settle, or modify the terms of the individual's debt; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iii)(B): make a bona fide offer to negotiate, settle, or modify the terms of the individual's debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iv): the effect of the service on:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iv)(A): an individual's creditworthiness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(iv)(B): collection efforts of the individual's creditors or debt collectors;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(v): the percentage or number of individuals who achieve the results that the provider represents are achievable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(r)(vi): whether a provider's service is offered or provided by a nonprofit entity; or

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(1)(s)(ii): in the provision of services subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(2): 13-42-123(4)(c) If a provider furnishes debt-management services to an individual, the provider may not, directly or indirectly:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(2)(a): purchase a debt or obligation of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-128(2)(b): receive from or on behalf of the individual:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-129 Notice of litigation.
-----------------------------------------------------
No later than 30 days after a provider has been served with notice of a civil action for violation of this chapter by or on behalf of an individual who resides in this state at either the time of an agreement or the time the notice is served, the provider shall notify the administrator in a record that it has been sued.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-130 Advertising.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-130(1): If a provider whose agreements contemplate that creditors will reduce finance charges or fees for late payment, default, or delinquency advertises debt-management services, it shall disclose, in an easily comprehensible manner, that using a debt-management plan may make it harder for the individual to obtain credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-130(2): 13-42-117(4)(e); (f); 13-42-123 If a provider whose agreements contemplate that creditors will settle for less than the full principal amount of debt that advertises debt-management services, it shall disclose, in an easily comprehensible manner:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-130(2)(a): 13-42-117(4)(e); (f) the information specified in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-130(2)(b): 13-42-123 the provider's settlement fee structure, consistent with the limitations of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-131 Provider liability for the conduct of other persons -- Prohibited conduct of person providing service to provider.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-131(1): If a provider delegates any of its duties or obligations under an agreement or this chapter to another person, including an independent contractor, the provider is liable for conduct of the person which, if done by the provider, would violate the agreement or this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-131(2): A lead generator or other person that provides services to or for a provider may not engage in an unfair, unconscionable, or deceptive act or practice, including the knowing omission of any material information, with respect to an individual who the lead generator or other person has reason to believe is or may become a customer of the provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-138 Uniformity of application and construction.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration shall be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-139 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, and supersedes the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7001 et seq., but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. Section 7003(b).

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-140(1): Transactions entered into before July 1, 2007 and the rights, duties, and interests resulting from them may be completed, terminated, or enforced as required or permitted by a law amended, repealed, or modified by this chapter as though the amendment, repeal, or modification had not occurred.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-42-141 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
If any provision of this chapter or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of this chapter that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this chapter are severable.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 43 - Property Rights Ombudsman Act
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Property Rights Ombudsman Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(1): "Constitutional taking" or "taking" means a governmental action resulting in a taking of real property that requires compensation to the owner of the property under:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(1)(a): the Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(1)(b): Utah Constitution Article I, Section 22.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(2): "Takings and eminent domain law" means the provisions of the federal and state constitutions, the case law interpreting those provisions, and any relevant statutory provisions that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(2)(a): involve constitutional issues arising from the use or ownership of real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(2)(b): require a governmental unit to compensate a real property owner for a constitutional taking; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-102(2)(c): provide for relocation assistance to those persons who are displaced by the use of eminent domain.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201 Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(1): There is created an Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman in the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(2): 13-43-202 The executive director of the Department of Commerce, with the concurrence of the Land Use and Eminent Domain Advisory Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(3): A person appointed under this section is an exempt employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(4): An attorney appointed under this section is an at-will employee who may be terminated without cause by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(4)(a): the executive director of the Department of Commerce; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-201(4)(b): an action of the land Use and Eminent Domain Advisory Board.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206 Advisory opinion -- Process.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(1): 13-43-205 A request for an advisory opinion under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(1)(a): filed with the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(1)(b): accompanied by a filing fee of $150.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(2): The Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman may establish policies providing for partial fee waivers for a person who is financially unable to pay the entire fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(3): 10-9a-801; 17-27a-801 A person requesting an advisory opinion need not exhaust administrative remedies, including remedies described under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(4): The Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(4)(a): deliver notice of the request to opposing parties indicated in the request;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(4)(b): inquire of all parties if there are other necessary parties to the dispute; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(4)(c): deliver notice to all necessary parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(5): 63G-7-401 If a governmental entity is an opposing party, the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman shall deliver the request in the manner provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(6)(a): The Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman shall promptly determine if the parties can agree to a neutral third party to issue an advisory opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(6)(b): If no agreement can be reached within four business days after notice is delivered pursuant to Subsections (4) and (5), the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman shall appoint a neutral third party to issue an advisory opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(7): All parties that are the subject of the request for advisory opinion shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(7)(a): share equally in the cost of the advisory opinion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(7)(b): provide financial assurance for payment that the neutral third party requires.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8): 78B-11-109 The neutral third party shall comply with the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8)(a): seek a response from all necessary parties to the issues raised in the request for advisory opinion;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8)(b): investigate and consider all responses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8)(c): issue a written advisory opinion within 15 business days after the appointment of the neutral third party under Subsection (6)(b), unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8)(c)(i): the parties agree to extend the deadline; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(8)(c)(ii): the neutral third party determines that the matter is complex and requires additional time to render an opinion, which may not exceed 30 calendar days.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(9): An advisory opinion shall include a statement of the facts and law supporting the opinion's conclusions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(10): 63G-7-401
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(10)(a): Copies of any advisory opinion issued by the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman shall be delivered as soon as practicable to all necessary parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(10)(b): 63G-7-401 A copy of the advisory opinion shall be delivered to the government entity in the manner provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(11): An advisory opinion issued by the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman is not binding on any party to, nor admissible as evidence in, a dispute involving land use law except as provided in Subsection (12).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(12): Subject to Subsection (13), if the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman issues an advisory opinion described in this section, and if the same issue that is the subject of the advisory opinion is subsequently litigated in court on a cause of action alleging the same facts and circumstances that are at issue in the advisory opinion, and if the court resolves the issue consistent with the advisory opinion, the court may award the substantially prevailing party:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(12)(a): reasonable attorney fees and court costs pertaining to the development of the cause of action from the date the Office of the Property Rights Ombudsman delivers the advisory opinion to the date of the court's resolution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(12)(b): if the court finds that the opposing party knowingly and intentionally violated the law governing the cause of action:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(12)(b)(ii): consequential damages;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13)(a): Subsection (12) does not apply unless the resolution described in Subsection (12)(a) is final.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13)(b)(i): begins to accrue on the later of:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13)(b)(i)(B): the day on which the substantially prevailing party or opposing party filed the action in court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13)(b)(ii): ends the day on which the court enters a final judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-43-206(13)(c): A court may not impose a civil penalty against a party under Subsection (12)(b)(i) unless the party is the land use applicant or a government entity.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 44 - Protection of Personal Information Act
************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Protection of Personal Information Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(1)(a): "Breach of system security" means an unauthorized acquisition of computerized data maintained by a person that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(1)(b): "Breach of system security" does not include the acquisition of personal information by an employee or agent of the person possessing unencrypted computerized data unless the personal information is used for an unlawful purpose or disclosed in an unauthorized manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(2): "Consumer" means a natural person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(3): "Financial institution" means the same as that term is defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6809.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a): "Personal information" means a person's first name or first initial and last name, combined with any one or more of the following data elements relating to that person when either the name or date element is unencrypted or not protected by another method that renders the data unreadable or unusable:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a)(i): Social Security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a)(ii)(A): financial account number, or credit or debit card number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a)(ii)(B): any required security code, access code, or password that would permit access to the person's account; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(a)(iii): driver license number or state identification card number.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(4)(b): "Personal information" does not include information regardless of its source, contained in federal, state, or local government records or in widely distributed media that are lawfully made available to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-102(5): "Record" includes materials maintained in any form, including paper and electronic.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-103 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to a financial institution or an affiliate, as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6809, of a financial institution.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201 Protection of personal information.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(1): Any person who conducts business in the state and maintains personal information shall implement and maintain reasonable procedures to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(1)(a): prevent unlawful use or disclosure of personal information collected or maintained in the regular course of business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(1)(b): destroy, or arrange for the destruction of, records containing personal information that are not to be retained by the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(2): (1)(b) The destruction of records under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(2)(a): shredding;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(2)(b): erasing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-201(2)(c): otherwise modifying the personal information to make the information indecipherable.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202 Personal information -- Disclosure of system security breach.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1): 63A-16-1102
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(a): A person who owns or licenses computerized data that includes personal information concerning a Utah resident shall, when the person becomes aware of a breach of system security, conduct in good faith a reasonable and prompt investigation to determine the likelihood that personal information has been or will be misused for identity theft or fraud purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(b): If an investigation under Subsection (1)(a) reveals that the misuse of personal information for identity theft or fraud purposes has occurred, or is reasonably likely to occur, the person shall provide notification to each affected Utah resident.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(c): 63A-16-1102 If an investigation under Subsection (1)(a) reveals that the misuse of personal information relating to 500 or more Utah residents, for identity theft or fraud purposes, has occurred or is reasonably likely to occur, the person shall, in addition to the notification required in Subsection (1)(b), provide notification to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(c)(i): the Office of the Attorney General; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(c)(ii): 63A-16-1102 the Utah Cyber Center created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(1)(d): If an investigation under Subsection (1)(a) reveals that the misuse of personal information relating to 1,000 or more Utah residents, for identity theft or fraud purposes, has occurred or is reasonably likely to occur, the person shall, in addition to the notification required in Subsections (1)(b) and (c), provide notification to each consumer reporting agency that compiles and maintains files on consumers on a nationwide basis, as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(2): A person required to provide notification under Subsection (1) shall provide the notification in the most expedient time possible without unreasonable delay:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(2)(a): considering legitimate investigative needs of law enforcement, as provided in Subsection (4)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(2)(b): after determining the scope of the breach of system security; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(2)(c): after restoring the reasonable integrity of the system.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(3)(a): A person who maintains computerized data that includes personal information that the person does not own or license shall notify and cooperate with the owner or licensee of the information of any breach of system security immediately following the person's discovery of the breach if misuse of the personal information occurs or is reasonably likely to occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(3)(b): Cooperation under Subsection (3)(a) includes sharing information relevant to the breach with the owner or licensee of the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(4)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (2), a person may delay providing notification under Subsection (1)(b) at the request of a law enforcement agency that determines that notification may impede a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(4)(b): A person who delays providing notification under Subsection (4)(a) shall provide notification in good faith without unreasonable delay in the most expedient time possible after the law enforcement agency informs the person that notification will no longer impede the criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a): 45-1-101 A notification required by Subsection (1)(b) may be provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(i): in writing by first-class mail to the most recent address the person has for the resident;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(ii): electronically, if the person's primary method of communication with the resident is by electronic means, or if provided in accordance with the consumer disclosure provisions of 15 U.S.C. Section 7001;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(iii): by telephone, including through the use of automatic dialing technology not prohibited by other law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(iv): 45-1-101 for residents of the state for whom notification in a manner described in Subsections (5)(a)(i) through (iii) is not feasible, by publishing notice of the breach of system security:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(iv)(A): in a newspaper of general circulation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(a)(iv)(B): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(b): If a person maintains the person's own notification procedures as part of an information security policy for the treatment of personal information the person is considered to be in compliance with the notification requirement in Subsection (1)(b) if the procedures are otherwise consistent with this chapter's timing requirements and the person notifies each affected Utah resident in accordance with the person's information security policy in the event of a breach.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(5)(c): A person who is regulated by state or federal law and maintains procedures for a breach of system security under applicable law established by the primary state or federal regulator is considered to be in compliance with this part if the person notifies each affected Utah resident in accordance with the other applicable law in the event of a breach.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6): 63G-2-305; 63G-2-309
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(a): 63G-2-305; 63G-2-309 The following information may be deemed confidential and classified as a protected record under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(a)(i): a notification submitted under Subsection (1)(c), including supporting information provided under Subsection (6)(b); and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(a)(ii): information produced by the Office of the Attorney General or the Utah Cyber Center in providing coordination or assistance to the person providing notification under Subsection (1)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b): A person providing notification under Subsection (1)(c) to the Office of the Attorney General or the Utah Cyber Center of a breach of system security shall include the following information in the notification, to the extent the information is known or available at the time the person provides the notification:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b)(i): the date the breach of system security occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b)(ii): the date the breach of system security was discovered;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b)(iii): the total number of people affected by the breach of system security, including the total number of Utah residents affected;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b)(iv): the type of personal information involved in the breach of system security; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(6)(b)(v): a short description of the breach of system security that occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-202(7): A waiver of this section is contrary to public policy and is void and unenforceable.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301 Enforcement -- Confidentiality agreement -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(1): The attorney general may enforce this chapter's provisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(2)(a): Nothing in this chapter creates a private right of action.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(2)(b): Nothing in this chapter affects any private right of action existing under other law, including contract or tort.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3): A person who violates this chapter's provisions is subject to a civil penalty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(a): no greater than $2,500 for a violation or series of violations concerning a specific consumer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(b): no greater than $100,000 in the aggregate for related violations concerning more than one consumer, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(b)(i): the violations concern:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(b)(i)(A): 10,000 or more consumers who are residents of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(b)(i)(B): 10,000 or more consumers who are residents of other states; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(3)(b)(ii): the person agrees to settle for a greater amount.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(a): In addition to the penalties provided in Subsection (3), the attorney general may seek, in an action brought under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(a)(i): injunctive relief to prevent future violations of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(a)(ii): attorney fees and costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(b): Notwithstanding Title 78B, Chapter 3a, Venue for Civil Actions, if the attorney general brings an action under this chapter in the district court, the attorney general shall bring the action in:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(b)(i): Salt Lake City; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(4)(b)(ii): the county in which resides a consumer who is affected by the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(5): 76-10-3114 The attorney general shall deposit any amount received under Subsection (3), (4), or (10) into the Attorney General Litigation Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6): 13-44-201; 13-44-202 In enforcing this chapter, the attorney general may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6)(a): 13-44-201; 13-44-202 investigate the actions of any person alleged to violate Section

Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6)(c): subpoena a document or other evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6)(d): require the production of books, papers, contracts, records, or other information relevant to an investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6)(e): conduct an adjudication in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act, to enforce a civil provision under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(6)(f): enter into a confidentiality agreement in accordance with Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(7): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(7)(a): If the attorney general has reasonable cause to believe that an individual is in possession, custody, or control of information that is relevant to enforcing this chapter, the attorney general may enter into a confidentiality agreement with the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(7)(b): In a civil action brought under this chapter, a court may issue a confidentiality order that incorporates the confidentiality agreement described in Subsection (7)(a).

Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(7)(c)(v)(B): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(8): A subpoena issued under Subsection (6) may be served by certified mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(9): A person's failure to respond to a request or subpoena from the attorney general under Subsection (6)(b), (c), or (d) is a violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10)(a): The attorney general may inspect and copy all records related to the business conducted by the person alleged to have violated this chapter, including records located outside the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10)(b): For records located outside of the state, the person who is found to have violated this chapter shall pay the attorney general's expenses to inspect the records, including travel costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10)(c): Upon notification from the attorney general of the attorney general's intent to inspect records located outside of the state, the person who is found to have violated this chapter shall pay the attorney general $500, or a higher amount if $500 is estimated to be insufficient, to cover the attorney general's expenses to inspect the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10)(d): To the extent an amount paid to the attorney general by a person who is found to have violated this chapter is not expended by the attorney general, the amount shall be refunded to the person who is found to have violated this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(10)(e): The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code or any other relevant entity shall revoke any authorization to do business in this state of a person who fails to pay any amount required under this Subsection (10).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(a): Subject to Subsection (11)(c), the attorney general shall keep confidential a procedure agreed to, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section pursuant to a subpoena, confidentiality agreement, or confidentiality order, unless the individual who agreed to the procedure, provided testimony, produced the document, or produced material waives confidentiality in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(b): Subject to Subsections (11)(c) and (11)(d), the attorney general may use, in an enforcement action taken under this section, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section to the extent the use is not restricted or prohibited by a confidentiality agreement or a confidentiality order.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(c): The attorney general may use, in an enforcement action taken under this section, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section that is restricted or prohibited from use by a confidentiality agreement or a confidentiality order if the individual who provided testimony or produced the document or material waives the restriction or prohibition in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(d): The attorney general may disclose testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section, without consent of the individual who provided the testimony or produced the document or material, or the consent of an individual being investigated, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(d)(i): a grand jury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(d)(ii): a federal or state law enforcement officer, if the person from whom the information  was obtained is notified 20 days or greater before the day on which the information is disclosed, and the federal or state law enforcement officer certifies that the federal or state law enforcement officer will:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(d)(ii)(A): maintain the confidentiality of the testimony, document, or material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(11)(d)(ii)(B): use the testimony, document, or material solely for an official law enforcement purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(12)(a): An administrative action filed under this chapter shall be commenced no later than 10 years after the day on which the alleged breach of system security last occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-44-301(12)(b): A civil action under this chapter shall be commenced no later than five years after the day on which the alleged breach of system security last occurred.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 45 - Consumer Credit Protection Act
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Consumer Credit Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(1): "Consumer" means an individual who is not a protected consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(2): "Consumer reporting agency" means a person who, for fees, dues, or on a cooperative basis, regularly engages in whole or in part in the practice of assembling or evaluating information concerning a consumer's credit or other information for the purpose of furnishing a credit report to another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(3): 13-45-503; 13-45-504 "Consumer who is subject to a protected consumer security freeze" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(3)(a): 13-45-503 for whom a credit reporting agency placed a security freeze under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(3)(b): 13-45-504 who, on the day on which a request for the removal of the security freeze is submitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(4): "Credit report" means a consumer report, as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a, that is used or collected in whole or part for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing a consumer's eligibility for credit for personal, family, or household purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(5): "File" is as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(6): 75-1-201 "Incapacitated person" means an individual who is incapacitated, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(7): "Normal business hours" means Sunday through Saturday, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:30 p.m., Mountain Standard or Mountain Daylight Time.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8): (8)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(a): "Personal information" means personally identifiable financial information:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(a)(i): provided by a consumer to another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(a)(ii): resulting from any transaction with the consumer or any service performed for the consumer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(a)(iii): otherwise obtained by another person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(b): "Personal information" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(b)(i): publicly available information, as that term is defined by the regulations prescribed under 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6804; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(b)(ii): any list, description, or other grouping of consumers, and publicly available information pertaining to the consumers, that is derived without using any nonpublic personal information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(8)(c): (8)(b) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9): "Proper identification" has the same meaning as in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681h(a)(1), and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9)(a): the consumer's full name, including first, last, and middle names and any suffix;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9)(b): any name the consumer previously used;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9)(c): the consumer's current and recent full addresses, including street address, any apartment number, city, state, and ZIP code;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9)(d): the consumer's Social Security number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(9)(e): the consumer's date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(10): "Protected consumer" means an individual who, at the time a request for a security freeze is made, is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(10)(a): less than 16 years of age;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(10)(b): an incapacitated person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(10)(c): a protected person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(11): 75-5b-102 "Protected person" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(12): "Record" means a compilation of information that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(12)(a): identifies a protected consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(12)(b): is created by a consumer reporting agency solely for the purpose of complying with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(12)(c): may not be created or used to consider the protected consumer's credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(13): "Representative" means a person who provides to a consumer reporting agency sufficient proof of authority to act on behalf of a protected consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14)(a): "Sufficient proof of authority" means documentation that shows that a person has authority to act on behalf of a protected consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14)(b): "Sufficient proof of authority" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14)(b)(i): a court order;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14)(b)(ii): a lawfully executed power of attorney; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(14)(b)(iii): a written, notarized statement signed by the person that expressly describes the person's authority to act on behalf of the protected consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15)(a): "Sufficient proof of identification" means information or documentation that identifies a protected consumer or a representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15)(b): "Sufficient proof of identification" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15)(b)(i): a Social Security number or a copy of a Social Security card issued by the United States Social Security Administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15)(b)(ii): a certified or official copy of a birth certificate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-102(15)(b)(iii): a copy of a government issued driver license or identification card.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201 Security freeze.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(1): As used in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(1)(a): "Security freeze" means a prohibition, consistent with the provisions of this section, on a consumer reporting agency's furnishing of a consumer's credit report to a third party intending to use the credit report to determine the consumer's eligibility for credit.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(1)(b): "Unique personal identifier" means a personal identification number, password, or other secure form of identity verification accepted by a consumer reporting agency and intended for use by a consumer to place, remove, or temporarily remove a security freeze in accordance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2): (5); (5); (2)(a); (5)(b)(ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(a): (5); (5) A consumer may request a security freeze on a consumer's credit report by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(a)(i): (5); (5) submitting a request for a security freeze to the consumer reporting agency by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(a)(i)(A): (5) certified mail to the postal address identified by the consumer reporting agency in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(a)(i)(B): (5) electronic means developed by the consumer reporting agency in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(a)(ii): providing proper identification to the consumer reporting agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b): (2)(a); (5)(b)(ii); (iii) Upon receipt of a request described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(i): (5)(b)(ii); (iii) place a security freeze on the consumer's credit report:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(i)(A): if the consumer submits the request by certified mail, as soon as practicable but no later than five business days after the business day on which the consumer reporting agency receives the request and the consumer's proper identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(i)(B): (5)(b)(ii); (iii) if the consumer submits the request by a contact method described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(i)(C): if the consumer submits the request by mobile application, within 15 minutes after the consumer reporting agency receives the request and the consumer's proper identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(ii): provide the consumer a unique personal identifier, unless the consumer reporting agency previously provided the consumer a unique personal identifier; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(2)(b)(iii): within five business days after the business day on which the consumer reporting agency places the security freeze, provide the consumer confirmation that the consumer reporting agency placed the security freeze.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(3): If a security freeze is in place, a consumer reporting agency may not release a consumer's credit report, or information from the credit report, to a third party that intends to use the information to determine a consumer's eligibility for credit without prior authorization from the consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(4): (3); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(4)(a): (3) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(4)(b): (4)(a) If a third party requesting a consumer's credit report in connection with the consumer's application for credit is notified of the existence of a security freeze under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5)(a): A consumer reporting agency shall develop a contact method to receive and process a consumer's request to place, remove, or temporarily remove a security freeze.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5)(b): (5)(a) A contact method under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5)(b)(i): a postal address;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5)(b)(ii): an electronic contact method chosen by the consumer reporting agency, which may include the use of fax, Internet, or other electronic means; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(5)(b)(iii): the use of telephone in a manner that is consistent with any federal requirements placed on the consumer reporting agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(6): 13-45-202 A security freeze placed under this section may be removed only in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7): (2)(b)(i)(B); (C); (7)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a): (2)(b)(i)(B); (C) The time requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(i): an act of God, including fire, earthquakes, hurricanes, storms, or similar natural disaster or phenomena;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(ii): unauthorized or illegal acts by a third party, including terrorism, sabotage, riot, vandalism, labor strikes or disputes disrupting operations, or similar occurrence;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(iii): operational interruption, including electrical failure, unanticipated delay in equipment or replacement part delivery, computer hardware or software failures inhibiting response time, or similar disruption;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(iv): governmental action, including emergency orders or regulations, judicial or law enforcement action, or similar directives;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(v): regularly scheduled maintenance, during other than normal business hours, of, or updates to, the consumer reporting agency's systems; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(a)(vi): commercially reasonable maintenance of, or repair to, the consumer reporting agency's systems that is unexpected or unscheduled.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-201(7)(b): (7)(a) In the event of a circumstance described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202 Removal of security freeze -- Requirements and timing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(1): 13-45-201(5) A consumer reporting agency shall remove a security freeze from a consumer's credit report only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(1)(a): 13-45-201(5)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(1)(a)(i): 13-45-201(5) the consumer reporting agency receives the consumer's request through the contact method established and required in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(1)(a)(ii): the consumer reporting agency receives the consumer's proper identification or unique personal identifier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(1)(b): the consumer makes a material misrepresentation of fact in connection with the placement of the security freeze and the consumer reporting agency notifies the consumer in writing before removing the security freeze.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(2): 13-45-201(5) A consumer reporting agency shall temporarily remove a security freeze upon receipt of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(2)(a): 13-45-201(5) the consumer's request through the contact method established by the consumer reporting agency in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(2)(b): the consumer's proper identification or unique personal identifier; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(2)(c): a specific designation of the period of time for which the security freeze is to be removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(3): 13-45-201(5)(b)(i); 13-45-201(5)(b)(ii); (iii) A consumer reporting agency shall remove or temporarily remove a security freeze from a consumer's credit report within:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(3)(a): 13-45-201(5)(b)(i) three business days after the business day on which the consumer's written request to remove the security freeze is received by the consumer reporting agency at the postal address chosen by the consumer reporting agency in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(3)(b): 13-45-201(5)(b)(ii); (iii) 15 minutes after the consumer's request is received by the consumer reporting agency through a contact method described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4): (3)(b); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4)(a): (3)(b) The time requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4)(a)(i): an act of God, including fire, earthquakes, hurricanes, storms, or similar natural disaster or phenomena;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4)(a)(ii): unauthorized or illegal acts by a third party, including terrorism, sabotage, riot, vandalism, labor strikes or disputes disrupting operations, or similar occurrence;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4)(a)(iii): operational interruption, including electrical failure, unanticipated delay in equipment or replacement part delivery, computer hardware or software failures inhibiting response time, or similar disruption;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-202(4)(a)(iv): governmental action, including emergency orders or regulations, judicial or law enforcement action, or similar directives;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203 Exceptions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1): 13-45-201 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(i): the purpose of the credit report is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(i)(A): use the credit report for purposes permitted under 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681b(c); or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(i)(B): review the consumer's account with the third party, including for account maintenance or monitoring, credit line increases, or other upgrades or enhancements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(i)(C): collect on a financial obligation owed by the consumer to the third party requesting the credit report; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(ii)(A): the purpose of the credit report is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(ii)(A)(I): review the consumer's account with another person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(ii)(A)(II): collect on a financial obligation owed by the consumer to another person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(a)(ii)(B): use the credit report for purposes permitted under 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681b(c); or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(1)(b): the third party requesting the credit report is a subsidiary, affiliate, agent, assignee, or prospective assignee of the person holding the consumer's account or to whom the consumer owes a financial obligation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2): 13-45-102; (1)(b); (2)(b)(v)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(a): 13-45-102 The consumer's request for a security freeze does not prohibit the consumer reporting agency from disclosing the consumer's credit report for other than credit related purposes consistent with the definition of credit report found in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b): (1)(b); (2)(b)(v)(B) The following list identifies the types of credit report disclosures by consumer reporting agencies to third parties that are not prohibited by a security freeze:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(i): the third party does not use the credit report for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing a consumer's eligibility for credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(ii): the third party is acting under a court order, warrant, or subpoena requiring release of the credit report;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(iii): the third party is a child support agency, or its agent or assignee, acting under Part D, Title IV of the Social Security Act or a similar state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(iv): the federal Department of Health and Human Services or a similar state agency, or its agent or assignee, investigating Medicare or Medicaid fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v): (1)(b); (2)(b)(v)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(A): the purpose of the credit report is to investigate or collect delinquent taxes, assessments, or unpaid court orders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B): (1)(b); (2)(b)(v)(B) the third party is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(I): the federal Internal Revenue Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(II): a state taxing authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(III): the Department of Motor Vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(IV): a county, municipality, or other entity with taxing authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(V): a federal, state, or local law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(v)(B)(VI): (1)(b); (2)(b)(v)(B) the agent or assignee of any entity listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(vi): the third party is administering a credit file monitoring subscription to which the consumer has subscribed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(2)(b)(vii): the third party requests the credit report for the sole purpose of providing the consumer with a copy of the consumer's credit report or credit score upon the consumer's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3): 13-45-201 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3)(a): a consumer reporting agency, the sole purpose of which is to resell credit information by assembling and merging information contained in the database of another consumer reporting agency and that does not maintain a permanent database of credit information from which a consumer's credit report is produced;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3)(b): a check services or fraud prevention services company that issues:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3)(b)(i): reports on incidents of fraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3)(b)(ii): authorizations for the purpose of approving or processing negotiable instruments, electronic funds transfers, or similar methods of payment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(3)(c): a deposit account information service company that issues reports concerning account closures based on fraud, substantial overdrafts, automated teller machine abuse, or similar information concerning a consumer to a requesting financial institution for the purpose of evaluating a consumer's request to create a deposit account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-203(4): Nothing in this chapter prohibits a person from obtaining, aggregating, or using information lawfully obtained from public records in a manner that does not otherwise violate this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-204 Fees for security freeze.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-204(1): A consumer reporting agency may not charge a fee for placing, removing, or temporarily removing a security freeze.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-204(2): A consumer reporting agency may not charge a fee to download or install a mobile application through which a person places or removes a security freeze.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205 Changes to information in a credit report subject to a security freeze.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205(1): If a credit report is subject to a security freeze, a consumer reporting agency shall notify the consumer who is the subject of the credit report within 30 days if the consumer reporting agency changes the consumer's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205(1)(a): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205(1)(b): date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205(1)(c): Social Security number; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-205(1)(d): address.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-301 Protection of personal information.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-301(1): Except as allowed by other law, a person may not display a Social Security number in a manner or location that is likely to be open to public view.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-301(2): The state, or a branch, agency, or political subdivision of the state, may not employ or contract for the employment of an inmate in any Department of Corrections facility or county jail in any capacity that would allow any inmate access to any other person's personal information.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401 Enforcement -- Confidentiality agreement -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(1): The attorney general may enforce the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2): A person who violates a provision of this chapter is subject to a civil fine of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(a): no greater than $2,500 for a violation or series of violations concerning a specific consumer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(b): no greater than $100,000 in the aggregate for related violations concerning more than one consumer, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(b)(i): the violations concern:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(b)(i)(A): 10,000 or more consumers who are residents of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(b)(i)(B): 10,000 or more consumers who are residents of other states; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(2)(b)(ii): the person agrees to settle for a greater amount.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(a): In addition to the penalties provided in Subsection (2), the attorney general may seek, in an action brought under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(a)(i): injunctive relief to prevent future violations of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(a)(ii): attorney fees and costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(b): Notwithstanding Title 78B, Chapter 3a, Venue for Civil Actions, if the attorney general brings an action under this chapter in the district court, the attorney general shall bring the action in:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(b)(i): Salt Lake City; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(3)(b)(ii): the county in which resides a consumer who is the subject of a credit report on which a violation occurs.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(4): 76-10-3114 The attorney general shall deposit any amount received under Subsection (2) or (3) into the Attorney General Litigation Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(a): If the attorney general has reasonable cause to believe that an individual is in possession, custody, or control of information that is relevant to enforcing this chapter, the attorney general may enter into a confidentiality agreement with the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(b): In a civil action brought under this chapter, a court may issue a confidentiality order that incorporates the confidentiality agreement described in Subsection (5)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 A confidentiality agreement entered into under Subsection (5)(a) or a confidentiality order issued under Subsection (5)(b) may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(i): address a procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(ii): address testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(iii): provide whom may access testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(iv): provide for safeguarding testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(v): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 require that the attorney general:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(v)(A): return a document or material to an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(5)(c)(v)(B): 63A-12-105; 63G-2-604 notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(a): Subject to Subsection (6)(c), the attorney general shall keep confidential a procedure agreed to, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section pursuant to a subpoena, confidentiality agreement, or confidentiality order, unless the individual who agreed to the procedure, provided testimony, or produced the document or material waives confidentiality in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(b): Subject to Subsections (6)(c) and (6)(d), the attorney general may use, in an enforcement action taken under this section, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section to the extent the use is not restricted or prohibited by a confidentiality agreement or a confidentiality order.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(c): The attorney general may use, in an enforcement action taken under this section, testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section that is restricted or prohibited from use by a confidentiality agreement or a confidentiality order if the individual who provided testimony, produced the document, or produced the material waives the restriction or prohibition in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(d): The attorney general may disclose testimony taken, a document produced, or material produced under this section, without consent of the individual who provided the testimony, produced the document, or produced the material, or without the consent of an individual being investigated, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(d)(i): a grand jury; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(d)(ii): a federal or state law enforcement officer, if the person from whom the information was obtained is notified 20 days or greater before the day on which the information is disclosed, and the federal or state law enforcement officer certifies that the federal or state law enforcement officer will:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(d)(ii)(A): maintain the confidentiality of the testimony, document, or material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(6)(d)(ii)(B): use the testimony, document, or material solely for an official law enforcement purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-401(7): A civil action filed under this chapter shall be commenced no later than five years after the day on which the alleged violation last occurred.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Credit Report Protection for Minors."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "security freeze" means:Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(1): if a consumer reporting agency does not have a file that pertains to a protected consumer, a restriction that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(1)(a): is placed on the protected consumer's record in accordance with this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(1)(b): except as otherwise provided in this part, prohibits the consumer reporting agency from releasing the protected consumer's record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(2): if a consumer reporting agency has a file that pertains to the protected consumer, a restriction that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(2)(a): is placed on the protected consumer's credit report in accordance with this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-502(2)(b): except as otherwise provided in this part, prohibits the consumer reporting agency from releasing the protected consumer's credit report or any information derived from the protected consumer's credit report.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to the use of a protected consumer's credit report or record by:Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(1): a person administering a credit file monitoring subscription service to which:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(1)(a): the protected consumer has subscribed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(1)(b): the protected consumer's representative has subscribed on the protected consumer's behalf;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(2): a person who, upon request from the protected consumer or the protected consumer's representative, provides the protected consumer or the protected consumer's representative with a copy of the protected consumer's credit report;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(3): a check services or fraud prevention services company that issues:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(3)(a): reports on incidents of fraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(3)(b): authorizations for the purpose of approving or processing negotiable instruments, electronic funds transfers, or similar payment methods;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(4): a deposit account information service company that issues reports regarding account closures due to fraud, substantial overdrafts, automated teller machine abuse, or similar information regarding an individual to inquiring banks or other financial institutions for use only in reviewing an individual's request for a deposit account at the inquiring bank or financial institution;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(5): an insurance company for the purpose of conducting the insurance company's ordinary business;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(6): a consumer reporting agency that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(6)(a): only resells credit information by assembling and merging information contained in a database of another consumer reporting agency or multiple consumer reporting agencies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(6)(b): does not maintain a permanent database of credit information from which new credit reports are produced; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7): a consumer reporting agency's database or file that consists of information that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(a): concerns and is used for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(a)(i): criminal record information;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(a)(ii): fraud prevention or detection;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(a)(iii): personal loss history information; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(a)(iv): employment, tenant, or individual background screening; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-45-503(7)(b): is not used for credit granting purposes.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 47 - Private Employer Verification Act
