Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 60 - Genetic Information Privacy Act
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Genetic Information Privacy Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(1): "Biological sample" means any human material known to contain DNA, including tissue, blood, urine, or saliva.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(2): "Consumer" means an individual who is a resident of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3): "Deidentified data" means data that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3)(a): cannot reasonably be linked to an identifiable individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3)(b): possessed by a company that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3)(b)(i): takes administrative and technical measures to ensure that the data cannot be associated with a particular consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3)(b)(ii): makes a public commitment to maintain and use data in deidentified form and not attempt to reidentify data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(3)(b)(iii): enters into legally enforceable contractual obligation that prohibits a recipient of the data from attempting to reidentify the data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(4): "Direct-to-consumer genetic testing company" or "company" means an entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(4)(a): offers consumer genetic testing products or services directly to consumers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(4)(b): collects, uses, or analyzes genetic data that a consumer provides to the entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(5): "DNA" means deoxyribonucleic acid.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(6): "Express consent" means a consumer's affirmative response to a clear, meaningful, and prominent notice regarding the collection, use, or disclosure of genetic data for a specific purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(a): "Genetic data" means any data, regardless of format, concerning a consumer's genetic characteristics.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b): "Genetic data" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b)(i): raw sequence data that result from sequencing all or a portion of a consumer's extracted DNA;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b)(ii): genotypic and phenotypic information obtained from analyzing a consumer's raw sequence data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b)(iii): self-reported health information regarding a consumer's health conditions that the consumer provides to a company that the company:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b)(iii)(A): uses for scientific research or product development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(b)(iii)(B): analyzes in connection with the consumer's raw sequence data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(7)(c): "Genetic data" does not include deidentified data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(8): "Genetic testing" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(8)(a): a laboratory test of a consumer's complete DNA, regions of DNA, chromosomes, genes, or gene products to determine the presence of genetic characteristics of the consumer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-102(8)(b): an interpretation of a consumer's genetic data.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-103 Limitations.
--------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-103(1): protected health information that is collected by a covered entity or business associate as those terms are defined in 45 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-103(2): a public or private institution of higher education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-103(3): an entity owned or operated by a public or private institution of higher education.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104 Consumer genetic information -- Privacy notice -- Consent -- Access -- Deletion -- Destruction.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1): A direct-to-consumer genetic testing company shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(a): provide to a consumer:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(a)(i): essential information about the company's collection, use, and disclosure of genetic data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(a)(ii): a prominent, publicly available privacy notice that includes information about the company's data collection, consent, use, access, disclosure, transfer, security, retention, and deletion practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(b): obtain a consumer's initial express consent for collection, use, or disclosure of the consumer's genetic data that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(b)(i): clearly describes the company's use of the genetic data that the company collects through the company's genetic testing product or service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(b)(ii): specifies who has access to test results; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(b)(iii): specifies how the company may share the genetic data;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c): if the company engages in any of the following, obtain a consumer's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(i): separate express consent for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(i)(A): the transfer or disclosure of the consumer's genetic data to any person other than the company's vendors and service providers;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(i)(B): the use of genetic data beyond the primary purpose of the company's genetic testing product or service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(i)(C): the company's retention of any biological sample provided by the consumer following the company's completion of the initial testing service requested by the consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(ii): informed consent in accordance with the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects, 45 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(ii)(A): research purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(ii)(B): research conducted under the control of the company for the purpose of publication or generalizable knowledge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(iii): express consent for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(iii)(A): marketing to a consumer based on the consumer's genetic data; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(c)(iii)(B): marketing by a third party person to a consumer based on the consumer having ordered or purchased a genetic testing product or service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(d): require valid legal process for the company's disclosure of a consumer's genetic data to law enforcement or any government entity without the consumer's express written consent;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(e): develop, implement, and maintain a comprehensive security program to protect a consumer's genetic data against unauthorized access, use, or disclosure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(f): provide a process for a consumer to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(f)(i): access the consumer's genetic data;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(f)(ii): delete the consumer's account and genetic data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(1)(f)(iii): destroy the consumer's biological sample.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-104(2): (1)(c)(iii) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-105 Prohibited disclosures.
-------------------------------------------------------
A direct-to-consumer genetic testing company may not disclose a consumer's genetic data without the consumer's written consent to:Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-105(1): an entity that offers health insurance, life insurance, or long-term care insurance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-105(2): an employer of the consumer.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106 Enforcement powers of the attorney general.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(1): The attorney general may enforce this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(2): The attorney general may initiate a civil enforcement action against a person for violating this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(3): In an action to enforce this part, the attorney general may recover:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(3)(a): actual damages to the consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(3)(b): costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(3)(c): attorney fees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-106(3)(d): $2,500 for each violation of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1): "Blood relative"  means an individual's biologically related:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(a): parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(b): grandparent;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(c): child;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(d): grandchild;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(e): sibling;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(f): uncle;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(g): aunt;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(h): nephew;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(i): niece; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(1)(j): first cousin.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(2): "DNA" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(2)(a): deoxyribonucleic acid, ribonucleic acid, and chromosomes, which may be analyzed to detect heritable diseases or conditions, including the identification of carriers, predicting risk of disease, or establishing a clinical diagnosis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(2)(b): proteins, enzymes, or other molecules associated with a genetic process, which may be modified, replaced in part or whole, superseded, or bypassed in function by a health or medical procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(3): "DNA sample" means any human biological specimen from which DNA can be extracted, or DNA extracted from such specimen.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(4): 34A-2-103 "Employer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(a): "Genetic analysis" or "genetic test" means the testing, detection, or analysis of an identifiable individual's DNA that results in information that is derived from the presence, absence, alteration, or mutation of an inherited gene or genes, or the presence or absence of a specific DNA marker or markers.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(b): "Genetic analysis" or "genetic test" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(b)(i): a routine physical examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(b)(ii): a routine chemical, blood, or urine analysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(b)(iii): a test to identify the presence of drugs or HIV infection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(5)(b)(iv): a test performed due to the presence of signs, symptoms, or other manifestations of a disease, illness, impairment, or other disorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(6): "Genetic procedure" means any therapy, treatment, or medical procedure that is intended to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(6)(a): add, remove, alter, activate, change, or cause mutation in an individual's inherited DNA; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(6)(b): replace, supersede, or bypass a normal DNA function.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(7): 31A-1-301 "Health care insurance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a): "Private genetic information" means any information about an identifiable individual that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(i): is derived from:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(i)(A): the presence, absence, alteration, or mutation of an inherited gene or genes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(i)(B): the presence or absence of a specific DNA marker or markers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(ii): has been obtained:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(ii)(A): from a genetic test or analysis of the individual's DNA;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(ii)(B): from a genetic test or analysis of the DNA of a blood relative of the individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(a)(ii)(C): from a genetic procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(b): "Private genetic information" does not include information that is derived from:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(b)(i): a routine physical examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(b)(ii): a routine chemical, blood, or urine analysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(b)(iii): a test to identify the presence of drugs or HIV infection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-203(8)(b)(iv): a test performed due to the presence of signs, symptoms, or other manifestations of a disease, illness, impairment, or other disorder.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204 Restrictions on employers.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(a): access or otherwise take into consideration private genetic information about an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(b): request or require an individual to consent to a release for the purpose of accessing private genetic information about the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(c): request or require an individual or the individual's blood relative to submit to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(c)(i): a genetic test; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(c)(ii): a genetic procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(d): inquire into or otherwise take into consideration the fact that an individual or the individual's blood relative has:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(d)(i): taken or refused to take a genetic test; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(1)(d)(ii): undergone or refused to undergo a genetic procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2): (1); (2)(b); (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(a): (1); (2)(b) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(a)(i): an employment-related judicial or administrative proceeding in which the individual has placed his health at issue; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(a)(ii): an employment-related decision in which the employer has a reasonable basis to believe that the individual's health condition poses a real and unjustifiable safety risk requiring the change or denial of an assignment.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(i): (2) An order compelling the disclosure of private genetic information pursuant to this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(i)(A): other ways of obtaining the private information are not available or would not be effective; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(i)(B): there is a compelling need for the private genetic information which substantially outweighs the potential harm to the privacy interests of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(ii): (2) An order compelling the disclosure of private genetic information pursuant to this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(ii)(A): limit disclosure to those parts of the record containing information essential to fulfill the objective of the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(ii)(B): limit disclosure to those persons whose need for the information is the basis of the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-204(2)(b)(ii)(C): include such other measures as may be necessary to limit disclosure for the protection of the individual.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205 Restrictions on health insurers.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(a): access or otherwise take into consideration private genetic information about an asymptomatic individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(b): request or require an asymptomatic individual to consent to a release for the purpose of accessing private genetic information about the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(c): request or require an asymptomatic individual or the individual's blood relative to submit to a genetic test;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(d): inquire into or otherwise take into consideration the fact that an asymptomatic individual or the individual's blood relative has taken or refused to take a genetic test;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(e): request or require an individual or the individual's blood relative to submit to a genetic procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(1)(f): inquire into the results of a genetic procedure that an individual or the individual's blood relative undergoes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2): (2); (2) An insurer offering health care insurance:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(a): may request information regarding the necessity of a genetic test, but not the results of the test, if a claim for payment for the test has been made against an individual's health insurance policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(b): may request information regarding the necessity of a genetic procedure, including the results of the procedure, if a claim for payment for the procedure has been made against an individual's health insurance policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(c): may request that portion of private genetic information that is necessary to determine the insurer's obligation to pay for health care services where:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(c)(i): the primary basis for rendering such services to an individual is the result of a genetic test; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(c)(ii): a claim for payment for such services has been made against the individual's health insurance policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(d): (2) may only store information obtained under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(2)(e): (2) may only use or otherwise disclose the information obtained under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3): (2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3)(a): (2) An insurer may, to the extent permitted by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3)(b): (2) An order authorizing the disclosure of private genetic information pursuant to this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3)(b)(i): limit disclosure to those parts of the record containing information essential to fulfill the objectives of the order;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3)(b)(ii): limit disclosure to those persons whose need for the information is the basis for the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(3)(b)(iii): include such other measures as may be necessary to limit disclosure for the protection of the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(4): Nothing in this section may be construed as restricting the ability of an insurer to use information other than private genetic information to take into account the health status of an individual, group, or population in determining premiums or making other underwriting decisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(5): Nothing in this section may be construed as:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(5)(a): requiring an insurer to pay for genetic testing or a genetic procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(5)(b): prohibiting the use of step-therapy protocols.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(6): Information maintained by an insurer about an individual under this section may be redisclosed:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(6)(a): to protect the interests of the insurer in detecting, prosecuting, or taking legal action against criminal activity, fraud, material misrepresentations, and material omissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(6)(b): to enable business decisions to be made about the purchase, transfer, merger, reinsurance, or sale of all or part of the insurer's business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-205(6)(c): to the commissioner of insurance upon formal request.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206 Private right of action.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(1)(a): An individual whose legal rights arising under this part have been violated after June 30, 2003, may recover damages and be granted equitable relief in a civil action.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(1)(b): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2): Any insurance company or employer who violates the legal rights of an individual arising from this part shall be liable to the individual for each separate violation in an amount equal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2)(a): actual damages sustained as a result of the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2)(b)(i): $100,000 if the violation is the result of an intentional and willful act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2)(b)(ii): punitive damages if the violation is the result of a malicious act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-206(2)(c): reasonable attorneys' fees.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-207 Enforcement.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-207(1): Whenever the attorney general has reason to believe that any person is using or is about to use any method, act, or practice in violation of the provisions of this part, and that proceedings would be in the public interest, the attorney general may bring an action against the person to restrain or enjoin the use of such method, act, or practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-207(2): In addition to restraining or enjoining the use of a method, act, or practice, the court may, after June 30, 2003, require the payment of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-207(2)(a): a civil fine of not more than $25,000 for each separate intentional violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-60-207(2)(b): reasonable costs of investigation and litigation, including reasonable attorneys' fees.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 61 - Utah Consumer Privacy Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(1): 13-61-403 "Account" means the Consumer Privacy Restricted Account established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(2): "Affiliate" means an entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(2)(a): controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(2)(b): shares common branding with another entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(3): "Aggregated data" means information that relates to a group or category of consumers:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(3)(a): from which individual consumer identities have been removed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(3)(b): that is not linked or reasonably linkable to any consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(4): "Air carrier" means the same as that term is defined in 49 U.S.C. Sec. 40102.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(5): 13-61-201 "Authenticate" means to use reasonable means to determine that a consumer's request to exercise the rights described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(a): "Biometric data" means data generated by automatic measurements of an individual's unique biological characteristics.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(b): "Biometric data" includes data described in Subsection (6)(a) that are generated by automatic measurements of an individual's fingerprint, voiceprint, eye retinas, irises, or any other unique biological pattern or characteristic that is used to identify a specific individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c): "Biometric data" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c)(i): a physical or digital photograph;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c)(ii): a video or audio recording;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c)(iii): data generated from an item described in Subsection (6)(c)(i) or (ii);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c)(iv): information captured from a patient in a health care setting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(6)(c)(v): information collected, used, or stored for treatment, payment, or health care operations as those terms are defined in 45 C.F.R. Parts 160, 162, and 164.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(7): "Business associate" means the same as that term is defined in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 160.103.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(8): "Child" means an individual younger than 13 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(9): "Consent" means an affirmative act by a consumer that unambiguously indicates the consumer's voluntary and informed agreement to allow a person to process personal data related to the consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(10)(a): "Consumer" means an individual who is a resident of the state acting in an individual or household context.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(10)(b): "Consumer" does not include an individual acting in an employment or commercial context.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(11): "Control" or "controlled" as used in Subsection (2) means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(11)(a): ownership of, or the power to vote, more than 50% of the outstanding shares of any class of voting securities of an entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(11)(b): control in any manner over the election of a majority of the directors or of the individuals exercising similar functions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(11)(c): the power to exercise controlling influence of the management of an entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(12): "Controller" means a person doing business in the state who determines the purposes for which and the means by which personal data are processed, regardless of whether the person makes the determination alone or with others.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(13): "Covered entity" means the same as that term is defined in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 160.103.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a): "Deidentified data" means data that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a)(i): cannot reasonably be linked to an identified individual or an identifiable individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a)(ii): are possessed by a controller who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a)(ii)(A): takes reasonable measures to ensure that a person cannot associate the data with an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a)(ii)(B): publicly commits to maintain and use the data only in deidentified form and not attempt to reidentify the data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(a)(ii)(C): contractually obligates any recipients of the data to comply with the requirements described in Subsections (14)(b)(i) and (ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(14)(b): "Deidentified data" includes synthetic data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(15): "Director" means the director of the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(16): 13-2-1 "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(17): 63G-2-103 "Governmental entity" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(18): 26B-2-201 "Health care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(19): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(20): "Identifiable individual" means an individual who can be readily identified, directly or indirectly.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(21): "Institution of higher education" means a public or private institution of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(22): 11-14-102 "Local political subdivision" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(23): 16-6a-102; 16-6a-102 "Nonprofit corporation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(23)(a): 16-6a-102 the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(23)(b): 16-6a-102 a foreign nonprofit corporation as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(24): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(24)(a): "Personal data" means information that is linked or reasonably linkable to an identified individual or an identifiable individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(24)(b): "Personal data" does not include deidentified data, aggregated data, or publicly available information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(25): "Process" means an operation or set of operations performed on personal data, including collection, use, storage, disclosure, analysis, deletion, or modification of personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(26): "Processor" means a person who processes personal data on behalf of a controller.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(27): "Protected health information" means the same as that term is defined in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 160.103.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(28): "Pseudonymous data" means personal data that cannot be attributed to a specific individual without the use of additional information, if the additional information is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(28)(a): kept separate from the consumer's personal data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(28)(b): subject to appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure that the personal data are not attributable to an identified individual or an identifiable individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(29): "Publicly available information" means information that a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(29)(a): lawfully obtains from a record of a governmental entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(29)(b): reasonably believes a consumer or widely distributed media has lawfully made available to the general public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(29)(c): if the consumer has not restricted the information to a specific audience, obtains from a person to whom the consumer disclosed the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(30): 13-61-201 "Right" means a consumer right described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(a): "Sale," "sell," or "sold" means the exchange of personal data for monetary consideration by a controller to a third party.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b): "Sale," "sell," or "sold" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(i): a controller's disclosure of personal data to a processor who processes the personal data on behalf of the controller;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(ii): a controller's disclosure of personal data to an affiliate of the controller;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(iii): considering the context in which the consumer provided the personal data to the controller, a controller's disclosure of personal data to a third party if the purpose is consistent with a consumer's reasonable expectations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(iv): the disclosure or transfer of personal data when a consumer directs a controller to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(iv)(A): disclose the personal data; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(iv)(B): interact with one or more third parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(v): a consumer's disclosure of personal data to a third party for the purpose of providing a product or service requested by the consumer or a parent or legal guardian of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(vi): the disclosure of information that the consumer:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(vi)(A): intentionally makes available to the general public via a channel of mass media; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(vi)(B): does not restrict to a specific audience; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(31)(b)(vii): a controller's transfer of personal data to a third party as an asset that is part of a proposed or actual merger, an acquisition, or a bankruptcy in which the third party assumes control of all or part of the controller's assets.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a): "Sensitive data" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i): personal data that reveals:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i)(A): an individual's racial or ethnic origin;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i)(B): an individual's religious beliefs;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i)(C): an individual's sexual orientation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i)(D): an individual's citizenship or immigration status; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(i)(E): information regarding an individual's medical history, mental or physical health condition, or medical treatment or diagnosis by a health care professional;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(ii): the processing of genetic personal data or biometric data, if the processing is for the purpose of identifying a specific individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(a)(iii): specific geolocation data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(b): "Sensitive data" does not include personal data that reveals an individual's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(b)(i): racial or ethnic origin, if the personal data are processed by a video communication service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(32)(b)(ii): if the personal data are processed by a person licensed to provide health care under Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection, or Title 58, Occupations and Professions, information regarding an individual's medical history, mental or physical health condition, or medical treatment or diagnosis by a health care professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(33): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(33)(a): "Specific geolocation data" means information derived from technology, including global position system level latitude and longitude coordinates, that directly identifies an individual's specific location, accurate within a radius of 1,750 feet or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(33)(b): "Specific geolocation data" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(33)(b)(i): the content of a communication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(33)(b)(ii): any data generated by or connected to advanced utility metering infrastructure systems or equipment for use by a utility.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(34): "Synthetic data" means data that has been generated by computer algorithms or statistical models and does not contain personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(a): "Targeted advertising" means displaying an advertisement to a consumer where the advertisement is selected based on personal data obtained from the consumer's activities over time and across nonaffiliated websites or online applications to predict the consumer's preferences or interests.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b): "Targeted advertising" does not include advertising:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(i): based on a consumer's activities within a controller's website or online application or any affiliated website or online application;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(ii): based on the context of a consumer's current search query or visit to a website or online application;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(iii): directed to a consumer in response to the consumer's request for information, product, a service, or feedback; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(iv): processing personal data solely to measure or report advertising:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(iv)(A): performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(iv)(B): reach; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(35)(b)(iv)(C): frequency.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(36): "Third party" means a person other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(36)(a): the consumer, controller, or processor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(36)(b): an affiliate or contractor of the controller or the processor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(37): "Trade secret" means information, including a formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique, or process, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(37)(a): derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from the information's disclosure or use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-101(37)(b): is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain the information's secrecy.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102 Applicability.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1): This chapter applies to any controller or processor who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(a)(i): conducts business in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(a)(ii): produces a product or service that is targeted to consumers who are residents of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(b): has annual revenue of $25,000,000 or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(c): satisfies one or more of the following thresholds:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(c)(i): during a calendar year, controls or processes personal data of 100,000 or more consumers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(1)(c)(ii): derives over 50% of the entity's gross revenue from the sale of personal data and controls or processes personal data of 25,000 or more consumers.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2): 26B-1-204 This chapter does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(a): a governmental entity or a third party under contract with a governmental entity when the third party is acting on behalf of the governmental entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(b): a tribe;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(c): an institution of higher education;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(d): a nonprofit corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(e): a covered entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(f): a business associate;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g): 26B-1-204 information that meets the definition of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(i): protected health information for purposes of the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1320d et seq., and related regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(ii): patient identifying information for purposes of 42 C.F.R. Part 2;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(iii): identifiable private information for purposes of the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects, 45 C.F.R. Part 46;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(iv): identifiable private information or personal data collected as part of human subjects research pursuant to or under the same standards as:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(iv)(A): the good clinical practice guidelines issued by the International Council for Harmonisation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(iv)(B): the Protection of Human Subjects under 21 C.F.R. Part 50 and Institutional Review Boards under 21 C.F.R. Part 56;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(v): personal data used or shared in research conducted in accordance with one or more of the requirements described in Subsection (2)(g)(iv);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(vi): 26B-1-204 information and documents created specifically for, and collected and maintained by, a committee but not a board or council listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(vii): information and documents created for purposes of the federal Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 11101 et seq., and related regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(viii): patient safety work product for purposes of 42 C.F.R. Part 3; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(ix): information that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(ix)(A): deidentified in accordance with the requirements for deidentification set forth in 45 C.F.R. Part 164; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(g)(ix)(B): derived from any of the health care-related information listed in this Subsection (2)(g);
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(h): information originating from, and intermingled to be indistinguishable with, information under Subsection (2)(g) that is maintained by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(h)(i): a health care facility or health care provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(h)(ii): a program or a qualified service organization as defined in 42 C.F.R. Sec. 2.11;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(i): information used only for public health activities and purposes as described in 45 C.F.R. Sec. 164.512;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(i): an activity by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(i)(A): a consumer reporting agency, as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(i)(B): a furnisher of information, as set forth in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681s-2, who provides information for use in a consumer report, as defined in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681a; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(i)(C): a user of a consumer report, as set forth in 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681b;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(ii): subject to regulation under the federal Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1681 et seq.; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii): involving the collection, maintenance, disclosure, sale, communication, or use of any personal data bearing on a consumer's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(A): credit worthiness;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(B): credit standing;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(C): credit capacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(D): character;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(E): general reputation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(F): personal characteristics; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(j)(iii)(G): mode of living;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(k): a financial institution or an affiliate of a financial institution governed by, or personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with, Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6801 et seq., and related regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(l): personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with the federal Driver's Privacy Protection Act of 1994, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 2721 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(m): personal data regulated by the federal Family Education Rights and Privacy Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1232g, and related regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(n): personal data collected, processed, sold, or disclosed in accordance with the federal Farm Credit Act of 1971, 12 U.S.C. Sec. 2001 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(o): data that are processed or maintained:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(o)(i): in the course of an individual applying to, being employed by, or acting as an agent or independent contractor of a controller, processor, or third party, to the extent the collection and use of the data are related to the individual's role;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(o)(ii): as the emergency contact information of an individual described in Subsection (2)(o)(i) and used for emergency contact purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(o)(iii): to administer benefits for another individual relating to an individual described in Subsection (2)(o)(i) and used for the purpose of administering the benefits;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(p): an individual's processing of personal data for purely personal or household purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(2)(q): an air carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(3): A controller is in compliance with any obligation to obtain parental consent under this chapter if the controller complies with the verifiable parental consent mechanisms under the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6501 et seq., and the act's implementing regulations and exemptions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-102(4): This chapter does not require a person to take any action in conflict with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1320d et seq., or related regulations.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-103 Preemption -- Reference to other laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-103(1): This chapter supersedes and preempts any ordinance, resolution, rule, or other regulation adopted by a local political subdivision regarding the processing of personal data by a controller or processor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-103(2): Any reference to federal law in this chapter includes any rules or regulations promulgated under the federal law.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201 Consumer rights -- Access -- Deletion -- Portability -- Opt out of certain processing.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(1): A consumer has the right to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(1)(a): confirm whether a controller is processing the consumer's personal data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(1)(b): access the consumer's personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(2): A consumer has the right to delete the consumer's personal data that the consumer provided to the controller.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(3): A consumer has the right to obtain a copy of the consumer's personal data, that the consumer previously provided to the controller, in a format that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(3)(a): to the extent technically feasible, is portable;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(3)(b): to the extent practicable, is readily usable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(3)(c): allows the consumer to transmit the data to another controller without impediment, where the processing is carried out by automated means.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(4): A consumer has the right to opt out of the processing of the consumer's personal data for purposes of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(4)(a): targeted advertising; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(4)(b): the sale of personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-201(5): 13-44-102 Nothing in this section requires a person to cause a breach of security system as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-202 Exercising consumer rights.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-202(1): A consumer may exercise a right by submitting a request to a controller, by means prescribed by the controller, specifying the right the consumer intends to exercise.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-202(2): In the case of processing personal data concerning a known child, the parent or legal guardian of the known child shall exercise a right on the child's behalf.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-202(3): Title 75, Chapter 5, Protection of Persons Under Disability and Their Property In the case of processing personal data concerning a consumer subject to guardianship, conservatorship, or other protective arrangement under


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203 Controller's response to requests.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(1): 13-61-202 Subject to the other provisions of this chapter, a controller shall comply with a consumer's request under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(a): Within 45 days after the day on which a controller receives a request to exercise a right, the controller shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(a)(i): take action on the consumer's request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(a)(ii): inform the consumer of any action taken on the consumer's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(b): The controller may extend once the initial 45-day period by an additional 45 days if reasonably necessary due to the complexity of the request or the volume of the requests received by the controller.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(c): (2)(b) If a controller extends the initial 45-day period, before the initial 45-day period expires, the controller shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(c)(i): inform the consumer of the extension, including the length of the extension; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(c)(ii): (2)(b) provide the reasons the extension is reasonably necessary as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(2)(d): The 45-day period does not apply if the controller reasonably suspects the consumer's request is fraudulent and the controller is not able to authenticate the request before the 45-day period expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(3): If, in accordance with this section, a controller chooses not to take action on a consumer's request, the controller shall within 45 days after the day on which the controller receives the request, inform the consumer of the reasons for not taking action.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4): (4)(a); (4)(b); (4)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(a): A controller may not charge a fee for information in response to a request, unless the request is the consumer's second or subsequent request during the same 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(b); (4)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b)(i): (4)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b)(i)(A): the request is excessive, repetitive, technically infeasible, or manifestly unfounded;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b)(i)(B): the controller reasonably believes the primary purpose in submitting the request was something other than exercising a right; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b)(i)(C): the request, individually or as part of an organized effort, harasses, disrupts, or imposes undue burden on the resources of the controller's business.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(4)(b)(ii): (4)(b); (4)(b)(i) A controller that charges a fee or refuses to act in accordance with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(5): 13-61-201 If a controller is unable to authenticate a consumer request to exercise a right described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(5)(a): is not required to comply with the request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-203(5)(b): may request that the consumer provide additional information reasonably necessary to authenticate the request.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301 Responsibility according to role.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(1): 13-44-202 A processor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(1)(a): adhere to the controller's instructions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(1)(b): 13-44-202 taking into account the nature of the processing and information available to the processor, by appropriate technical and organizational measures, insofar as reasonably practicable, assist the controller in meeting the controller's obligations, including obligations related to the security of processing personal data and notification of a breach of security system described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(2): Before a processor performs processing on behalf of a controller, the processor and controller shall enter into a contract that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(2)(a): clearly sets forth instructions for processing personal data, the nature and purpose of the processing, the type of data subject to processing, the duration of the processing, and the parties' rights and obligations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(2)(b): requires the processor to ensure each person processing personal data is subject to a duty of confidentiality with respect to the personal data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(2)(c): requires the processor to engage any subcontractor pursuant to a written contract that requires the subcontractor to meet the same obligations as the processor with respect to the personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(3)(a): Determining whether a person is acting as a controller or processor with respect to a specific processing of data is a fact-based determination that depends upon the context in which personal data are to be processed.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-301(3)(b): A processor that adheres to a controller's instructions with respect to a specific processing of personal data remains a processor.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302 Responsibilities of controllers -- Transparency -- Purpose specification and data minimization -- Consent for secondary use -- Security -- Nondiscrimination -- Nonretaliation -- Nonwaiver of consumer rights.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a): A controller shall provide consumers with a reasonably accessible and clear privacy notice that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a)(i): the categories of personal data processed by the controller;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a)(ii): the purposes for which the categories of personal data are processed;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a)(iii): how consumers may exercise a right;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a)(iv): the categories of personal data that the controller shares with third parties, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(a)(v): the categories of third parties, if any, with whom the controller shares personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(b): If a controller sells a consumer's personal data to one or more third parties or engages in targeted advertising, the controller shall clearly and conspicuously disclose to the consumer the manner in which the consumer may exercise the right to opt out of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(b)(i): sale of the consumer's personal data; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(1)(b)(ii): processing for targeted advertising.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(2)(a): A controller shall establish, implement, and maintain reasonable administrative, technical, and physical data security practices designed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(2)(a)(i): protect the confidentiality and integrity of personal data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(2)(a)(ii): reduce reasonably foreseeable risks of harm to consumers relating to the processing of personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(2)(b): Considering the controller's business size, scope, and type, a controller shall use data security practices that are appropriate for the volume and nature of the personal data at issue.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(3): Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, a controller may not process sensitive data collected from a consumer without:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(3)(a): first presenting the consumer with clear notice and an opportunity to opt out of the processing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(3)(b): in the case of the processing of personal data concerning a known child, processing the data in accordance with the federal Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6501 et seq., and the act's implementing regulations and exemptions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4): (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(a): A controller may not discriminate against a consumer for exercising a right by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(a)(i): denying a good or service to the consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(a)(ii): charging the consumer a different price or rate for a good or service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(a)(iii): providing the consumer a different level of quality of a good or service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(b): (4) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(b)(i): the consumer has opted out of targeted advertising; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(4)(b)(ii): the offer is related to the consumer's voluntary participation in a bona fide loyalty, rewards, premium features, discounts, or club card program.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(5): A controller is not required to provide a product, service, or functionality to a consumer if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(5)(a): the consumer's personal data are or the processing of the consumer's personal data is reasonably necessary for the controller to provide the consumer the product, service, or functionality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(5)(b): the consumer does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(5)(b)(i): provide the consumer's personal data to the controller; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(5)(b)(ii): allow the controller to process the consumer's personal data.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-302(6): Any provision of a contract that purports to waive or limit a consumer's right under this chapter is void.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(1)(c)(ii): the controller does not:

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(1)(c)(iii): the controller does not sell or otherwise disclose the personal data to any third party other than a processor, except as otherwise permitted in this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(2)(a): separately; and

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(3): (3)(a) A controller who uses pseudonymous data or deidentified data shall take reasonable steps to ensure the controller:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(3)(a): complies with any contractual obligations to which the pseudonymous data or deidentified data are subject; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-303(3)(b): (3)(a) promptly addresses any breach of a contractual obligation described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304 Limitations.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1): (1)(h)(i); 13-61-302 The requirements described in this chapter do not restrict a controller's or processor's ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(a): comply with a federal, state, or local law, rule, or regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(b): comply with a civil, criminal, or regulatory inquiry, investigation, subpoena, or summons by a federal, state, local, or other governmental entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(c): cooperate with a law enforcement agency concerning activity that the controller or processor reasonably and in good faith believes may violate federal, state, or local laws, rules, or regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(d): investigate, establish, exercise, prepare for, or defend a legal claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(e): provide a product or service requested by a consumer or a parent or legal guardian of a child;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(f): perform a contract to which the consumer or the parent or legal guardian of a child is a party, including fulfilling the terms of a written warranty or taking steps at the request of the consumer or parent or legal guardian before entering into the contract with the consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(g): take immediate steps to protect an interest that is essential for the life or physical safety of the consumer or of another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(h): (1)(h)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(h)(i): detect, prevent, protect against, or respond to a security incident, identity theft, fraud, harassment, malicious or deceptive activity, or any illegal activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(h)(ii): (1)(h)(i) investigate, report, or prosecute a person responsible for an action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(i)(i): preserve the integrity or security of systems; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(i)(ii): investigate, report, or prosecute a person responsible for harming or threatening the integrity or security of systems, as applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(j): 13-61-302 if the controller discloses the processing in a notice described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(k): assist another person with an obligation described in this subsection;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(l): process personal data to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(l)(i): conduct internal analytics or other research to develop, improve, or repair a controller's or processor's product, service, or technology;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(l)(ii): identify and repair technical errors that impair existing or intended functionality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(l)(iii): effectuate a product recall;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(m): process personal data to perform an internal operation that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(m)(i): reasonably aligned with the consumer's expectations based on the consumer's existing relationship with the controller; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(m)(ii): otherwise compatible with processing to aid the controller or processor in providing a product or service specifically requested by a consumer or a parent or legal guardian of a child or the performance of a contract to which the consumer or a parent or legal guardian of a child is a party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(1)(n): retain a consumer's email address to comply with the consumer's request to exercise a right.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(2): This chapter does not apply if a controller's or processor's compliance with this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(2)(a): violates an evidentiary privilege under Utah law;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(2)(b): as part of a privileged communication, prevents a controller or processor from providing personal data concerning a consumer to a person covered by an evidentiary privilege under Utah law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(2)(c): adversely affects the privacy or other rights of any person.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(3): A controller or processor is not in violation of this chapter if:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(3)(a): the controller or processor discloses personal data to a third party controller or processor in compliance with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(3)(b): the third party processes the personal data in violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(3)(c): the disclosing controller or processor did not have actual knowledge of the third party's intent to commit a violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(4): (1) If a controller processes personal data under an exemption described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-304(5): Nothing in this chapter requires a controller, processor, third party, or consumer to disclose a trade secret.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-305 No private cause of action.
-----------------------------------------------------------
A violation of this chapter does not provide a basis for, nor is a violation of this chapter subject to, a private right of action under this chapter or any other law.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401 Investigative powers of division.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401(1): The division shall establish and administer a system to receive consumer complaints regarding a controller's or processor's alleged violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401(2)(a): The division may investigate a consumer complaint to determine whether the controller or processor violated or is violating this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401(2)(b): If the director has reasonable cause to believe that substantial evidence exists that a person identified in a consumer complaint is in violation of this chapter, the director shall refer the matter to the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-401(2)(c): Upon request, the division shall provide consultation and assistance to the attorney general in enforcing this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402 Enforcement powers of the attorney general.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(1): The attorney general has the exclusive authority to enforce this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(2): Upon referral from the division, the attorney general may initiate an enforcement action against a controller or processor for a violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3): (3)(a); (3)(a); (3)(b); (3)(c); (3)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(a): At least 30 days before the day on which the attorney general initiates an enforcement action against a controller or processor, the attorney general shall provide the controller or processor:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(a)(i): written notice identifying each provision of this chapter the attorney general alleges the controller or processor has violated or is violating; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(a)(ii): an explanation of the basis for each allegation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(b): (3)(a) The attorney general may not initiate an action if the controller or processor:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(b)(i): (3)(a) cures the noticed violation within 30 days after the day on which the controller or processor receives the written notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(b)(ii): provides the attorney general an express written statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(b)(ii)(A): the violation has been cured; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(b)(ii)(B): no further violation of the cured violation will occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(c): (3)(a); (3)(b) The attorney general may initiate an action against a controller or processor who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(c)(i): (3)(a) fails to cure a violation after receiving the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(c)(ii): (3)(b) after curing a noticed violation and providing a written statement in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(d): (3)(c); (3)(c) In an action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(d)(i): actual damages to the consumer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(3)(d)(ii): (3)(c) for each violation described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(4): 13-61-403 All money received from an action under this chapter shall be deposited into the Consumer Privacy Account established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-402(5): If more than one controller or processor are involved in the same processing in violation of this chapter, the liability for the violation shall be allocated among the controllers or processors according to the principles of comparative fault.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403 Consumer Privacy Restricted Account.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(1): There is created a restricted account known as the "Consumer Privacy Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(2): The account shall be funded by money received through civil enforcement actions under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3): Upon appropriation, the division or the attorney general may use money deposited into the account for:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3)(a): investigation and administrative costs incurred by the division in investigating consumer complaints alleging violations of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3)(b): recovery of costs and attorney fees accrued by the attorney general in enforcing this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3)(c): providing consumer and business education regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3)(c)(i): consumer rights under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(3)(c)(ii): compliance with the provisions of this chapter for controllers and processors.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-403(4): If the balance in the account exceeds $4,000,000 at the close of any fiscal year, the Division of Finance shall transfer the amount that exceeds $4,000,000 into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404 Attorney general report.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404(1): The attorney general and the division shall compile a report:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404(1)(a): evaluating the liability and enforcement provisions of this chapter, including the effectiveness of the attorney general's and the division's efforts to enforce this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404(1)(b): summarizing the data protected and not protected by this chapter including, with reasonable detail, a list of the types of information that are publicly available from local, state, and federal government sources.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404(2): The attorney general and the division may update the report as new information becomes available.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-61-404(3): The attorney general and the division shall submit the report to the Business and Labor Interim Committee before July 1, 2025.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 62 - Digital Asset Management Act
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(1): "Agent" means a person who is authorized to act on behalf of an owner with respect to a digital asset.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(2): "Control" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(2)(a): an owner or an agent has the exclusive legal authority to conduct a transaction relating to the digital asset, including by means of a private key or the use of a multi-signature arrangement the owner or agent authorizes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(2)(b): a secured party has created a smart contract that gives the secured party exclusive legal authority to conduct a transaction relating to a digital security.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(3)(a): "Digital asset" means a representation of economic, proprietary, or access rights that is stored in a computer readable format.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(3)(b): "Digital asset" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(3)(b)(i): a digital user asset; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(3)(b)(ii): a digital security.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(4): 70A-8-101 "Digital security" means a digital asset that constitutes a security, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(5)(a): "Digital user asset" means a digital asset that is used or bought primarily for consumptive, personal, or household purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(5)(b): "Digital user asset" includes an open blockchain token.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(5)(c): "Digital user asset" does not include a digital security.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(6): "Multi-signature arrangement" means a system of access control relating to a digital asset for the purposes of preventing unauthorized transactions relating to the digital asset, in which two or more private keys are required to conduct a transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(7): "Private key" means a unique element of cryptographic data that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(7)(a): held by a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(7)(b): paired with a public key; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(7)(c): used to digitally sign a transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(8): "Public key" means a unique element of cryptographic data that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(8)(a): is publicly available;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(8)(b): is paired with a private key that is held by the owner of the public key; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(8)(c): allows viewing, but not digitally signing, electronic transactions.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-101(9): "Smart contract" means a transaction that is comprised of code, script, or programming language that executes the terms of an agreement, and which may include taking custody of and transferring a digital asset, or issuing executable instructions for these actions, based on the occurrence or nonoccurrence of specified conditions.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-102 Ownership of digital assets.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-102(1): Title 70A, Chapter 8, Uniform Commercial Code - Investment Securities; Title 70A, Chapter 9a, Uniform Commercial Code - Secured Transactions Digital securities are intangible personal property and shall be considered securities and investment property for purposes of this chapter,
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-102(2): An owner of a digital user asset may demonstrate ownership of the digital user asset through control.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-102(3): Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to restrict or impair an owner's right to own a digital asset.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103 Protection of private keys.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), a person may not be compelled to produce a private key, or any components that allow the derivation of a private key, or make a private key known to any other person in any civil, criminal, administrative, legislative, or other proceeding in the state that relates to a digital asset, digital identity, or other interest or right to which the private key provides access.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(1)(b): A person may be compelled in a civil, criminal, administrative, legislative, or other lawful proceeding in the state to produce a private key if a public key is unavailable or unable to disclose the information requested to be obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(2): A person may be compelled by court order to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(2)(a): produce, sell, transfer, convey, or disclose a digital asset, digital identity, or other interest or right to which a private key provides access; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-62-103(2)(b): disclose information about the digital asset, digital identity, or other interest or right.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(1): 31A-6b-102 "Administrative functions" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(7)(b): ends the last day on which the purchaser may cancel the vehicle value protection agreement with a full refund.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(9): "Purchaser" means a person who purchases a benefit from another person under a vehicle value protection agreement.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(12)(a)(i): the cash value of the covered vehicle when traded in for a replacement vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(12)(a)(ii): the finance agreement for a replacement vehicle; or

Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(12)(b)(iii): a vehicle cash down payment protection agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-101(12)(b)(iv): a vehicle depreciation benefit agreement.
