Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202 Liability insurance -- Security for payment -- Provider net worth value.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1): A provider under a vehicle value protection agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a): insure all vehicle value protection agreements the provider enters into under a contractual liability insurance policy that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(i)(A): is issued by an insurer authorized to do business in this state that has a surplus as to policyholders and paid-in capital of less than $10,000,000 and more than $5,000,000 and provides evidence to the division that the insurer maintains a ratio of net written premiums to surplus as to policyholders and paid-in capital of not greater than three to one; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(i)(B): is issued by an insurer authorized to do business in this state that has as a surplus as to policyholders and paid-in capital of more than $10,000,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(ii)(A): requires the insurer to reimburse the purchaser if the provider fails to perform the provider's obligations under a vehicle value protection agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(ii)(B): covers any amount the provider is required to pay for failure to perform under a vehicle value protection agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(a)(ii)(C): allows a purchaser to file with the insurer a claim for reimbursement under the vehicle value protection agreement if the provider does not pay the purchaser within 60 days after the day on which proof of damage, total loss, or unrecovered theft of the covered vehicle is provided to the provider in accordance with the terms of the vehicle value protection agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(b)(i): maintain a funded reserve account to cover the provider's obligations under all vehicle value protection agreements the provider enters into that is equal to or greater than 40% of money received by, less claims paid to, the provider for the vehicle value protection agreements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(b)(ii): place in trust with the division a security that is equal to at least 5% of money received by, less claims paid to, the provider for all vehicle value protection agreements the provider enters into and more than $25,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(1)(c): maintain, or together with the provider's parent company maintain, a net worth or stockholders' equity of $100,000,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2): (1)(a); (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(a): (1)(a) An insurer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(a)(i): a copy of the insurer's audited financial statements;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(a)(ii): the insurer's National Association of Insurance Commissioner annual statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(a)(iii): the actuarial certification filed in the insurer's state of domicile.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(b): (1)(b) The division may examine a reserve account described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(c): A provider shall, upon request, provide the division a copy of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(c)(i): the provider's or the provider's parent company's most recent Form 10-K or Form 20-F filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-202(2)(c)(ii): if the provider does not file with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a copy of the provider's audited financial statements that shows the net worth of the provider or the provider's parent company.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203 Preliminary period -- Cancellation -- Refund.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(1)(a): A vehicle value protection agreement shall provide for a preliminary period of at least 30 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(1)(b): If a purchaser cancels a vehicle value protection agreement within the preliminary period, the purchaser is entitled to a refund of the charges under the vehicle value protection agreement as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(1)(b)(i): if benefits have not been provided, a full refund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(1)(b)(ii): if benefits have been provided, a refund to the extent provided for in the vehicle value protection agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(2)(b): A provider may immediately cancel a vehicle value protection agreement upon sending a notice of cancellation to the purchaser if the reason for the cancellation is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(2)(b)(i): the purchaser's failure to pay the provider's fee under the vehicle value protection agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(2)(b)(ii): the purchaser's breach of the purchaser's duties relating to the covered vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(3): (2) A notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(3)(a): the effective date of the cancellation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(3)(b): the reason for the cancellation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(4): If a provider cancels a vehicle value protection agreement for a reason other than the purchaser's failure to pay the provider's fee under the vehicle value protection agreement, the provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(4)(a): shall refund the purchaser any unearned provider fee under the vehicle value protection agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(4)(b): may charge the purchaser an administrative fee of up to $75; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-64-203(4)(c): may deduct the amount of a benefit paid under the vehicle value protection agreement from the refund.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 65 - Utah Commercial Email Act
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(1): "Advertiser" means a person who advertises the person's product, service, or website through the use of commercial email.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(2): "Commercial email" means an email used primarily to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(2)(a): advertise or promote a commercial website, product, or service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(2)(b): solicit money, property, or personal information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(3): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(4): "Domain name" means any alphanumeric designation that is registered with or assigned by any domain name registrar, domain name registry, or other domain name registration authority as part of an electronic address on the Internet.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(5): "Electronic mail service provider" means a company or a service that provides routing, relaying, handling, storage, or support for email addresses and email inboxes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6): "Header information" means information attached to an email, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6)(a): the originating domain name;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6)(b): the originating email address;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6)(c): the destination;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6)(d): the routing information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(6)(e): any other information that appears in the header line identifying, or purporting to identify, a person initiating the message.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(7): "Initiate" means an act of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(7)(a): originating, transmitting, or sending commercial email; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(7)(b): promising, paying, or providing other consideration for another person to originate, transmit, or send a commercial email.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(8)(a): "Initiator" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(8)(a)(i): originates, transmits, or sends commercial email; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(8)(a)(ii): promises, pays, or provides other consideration for another person to originate, transmit, or send a commercial email.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(8)(b): "Initiator" does not include a person whose activities are a routine conveyance.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(9): "Preexisting or current business relationship" means a situation where the recipient has:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(9)(a): made an inquiry and provided an email address; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(9)(b): made an application, a purchase, or a transaction, with or without consideration, related to a product or a service offered by the advertiser.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(10): "Recipient" means an addressee of an unsolicited email.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(11): "Routine conveyance" means an Internet service provider's or email provider's automatic electronic mail message processes, including routing, relaying, handling, or storing through an automatic technical process, for which a person other than the Internet service provider or email provider has identified the electronic mail message recipients and provided the recipients' addresses.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(12): "Unsolicited commercial email" means a commercial email sent by an advertiser to a recipient that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(12)(a): has not provided direct consent to the advertiser to receive the commercial email; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(12)(b): does not have a preexisting or current relationship with the advertiser.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(13): "Utah email address" means an email address that :
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(13)(a): is provided by an electronic mail service provider that sends bills for providing and maintaining that email address to a mailing address in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(13)(b): is ordinarily accessed from a computer located in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(13)(c): is provided to an individual who is currently a resident of this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-101(13)(d): results in delivery of an email to a server in Utah.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-201 Prohibited uses of email.
---------------------------------------------------------
An advertiser or an initiator may not initiate or advertise in a commercial email sent from this state or sent to a Utah email address if:Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-201(1): the commercial email contains or is accompanied by a third party's domain name without the permission of the third party;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-201(2): the commercial email contains or is accompanied by false, misrepresented, or forged header information, even if the commercial email contains truthful identifying information for the advertiser in the body of the email; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-65-201(3): the commercial email has a subject line that is likely to mislead a recipient, acting reasonably under the circumstances, about a material fact regarding the identity of the advertiser, the contents, or the subject matter of the commercial email.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 67 - Online Dating Safety Act
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(1): "Banned member" means a member whose account or profile is the subject of a fraud ban.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(2): "Criminal background screening" means a name search for an individual's criminal conviction and is conducted by searching:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(2)(a): available and regularly updated government public record databases that in the aggregate provide national coverage for criminal conviction records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(2)(b): a regularly updated database with national coverage of criminal conviction records and sexual offender registries maintained by a private vendor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(3)(a): "Criminal conviction" means a conviction for a crime in this state, another state, or under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(3)(b): "Criminal conviction" includes an offense that would require registration under Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, or under a similar law in a different jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(4): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection in the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(5): "Fraud ban" means the expulsion of a member from an online dating service because, in the judgment of the online dating service provider, there is a significant risk the member will attempt to obtain money from another member through fraudulent means.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(6): "Member" means an individual who submits to an online dating service provider the information required by the online dating service provider to access the online dating service provider's online dating service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(7): "Online dating service" means a product or service that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(7)(a): conducted through a website or a mobile application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(7)(b): primarily marketed and intended to offer a member access to dating or romantic relationships with another member by arranging or facilitating the social introduction of members.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(8): "Online dating service provider" means a person predominately engaged in the business of offering an online dating service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-101(9): "Utah member" means a member who provides a Utah billing address or zip code when registering with an online dating service provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-102 Applicability of chapter. 
----------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to an Internet service provider serving as an intermediary for a transmission of an electronic message between members of an online dating service provider.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103 Criminal background screening disclosures.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(1): An online dating service provider that offers services to residents of this state and does not conduct a criminal background screening on each member shall, before permitting a Utah member to communicate through the online dating service provider with another member, clearly and conspicuously disclose to the Utah member that the online dating service provider does not conduct a criminal background screening on each member.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2): An online dating service provider that offers services to residents of this state and conducts a criminal background screening on each member shall, before permitting a Utah member to communicate through the provider with another member, clearly and conspicuously:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(a): disclose to the Utah member that the online dating service provider conducts a criminal background screening on each member; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b): include on the online dating service provider's website or mobile application:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b)(i): a statement of whether the online dating service provider excludes from the online dating service provider's online dating service an individual who is identified as having a criminal conviction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b)(ii): a statement that a criminal background screening:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b)(ii)(A): may be inaccurate or incomplete;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b)(ii)(B): may give a member a false sense of security; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-103(2)(b)(ii)(C): may be circumvented by an individual who has a criminal history.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104 Safety awareness disclosures.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(1): An online dating service provider that offers services to residents of this state shall clearly and conspicuously provide a safety awareness notification to all Utah members that includes a list of safety measures reasonably designed to increase awareness of safer online dating practices and clear guidelines and resources for reporting crimes committed by an online dating service member.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2): (1); (2)(b)(i); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a): (1) A safety awareness notification described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(i): have a heading or headings substantially similar to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(i)(A): "Online Dating Safety Awareness";
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(i)(B): "Protecting Yourself from Sexual Assault and Dating Violence"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(i)(C): "Protecting Yourself from Financial Crimes"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii): include information relevant to member safety awareness, including the following or substantially similar information, which may be revised or updated to reflect current information and best safety practices:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(A): a notice that engaging in sexual conduct without the other person's consent is a criminal act and subject to prosecution;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(B): an advisory that getting to know an individual through an online dating service may be risky and a member should follow safety precautions when sharing information or meeting in person;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(C): an advisory that a member should avoid sharing the member's last name, email address, home address, phone number, place of work, social security number, details of the member's daily routine, or other identifying information in the member's dating profile or initial email messages or communications;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(D): an advisory that a member should stop communicating with an individual who pressures the member for personal or financial information or attempts to trick the member into revealing personal or financial information;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(E): an advisory that a member should not send money to an individual the member meets on an online dating service, especially by wire transfer, even if the individual claims to be experiencing an emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(F): an advisory that if a member decides to meet another member in person, the member should tell someone in the member's family or a friend where the member is going and when the member is planning to return;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(G): an advisory that a member should provide the member's own transportation to and from an in-person date and meet in a public place with many people around;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(H): an advisory that an individual may provide false information in a dating profile;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(I): a notice that a member should block and report to the online dating service a member whose behavior is suspicious, offensive, harassing, threatening, fraudulent, or involves a request for money or an attempt to sell a product or service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(J): a request that if a member is the victim or survivor of sexual or intimate partner violence or a financial crime through someone the member met on the online dating service, the member should report the incident to the online dating service and to law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(K): a notice that if a member is the victim or survivor of sexual or intimate partner violence or a financial crime through someone the member met on the online dating service, the member is not to blame and may seek support through national or local hotlines and services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(a)(ii)(L): an advisory that reporting criminal activity by another member may help prevent a perpetrator of a rape, assault, or financial crime from hurting or continuing to hurt others, and may be necessary for an online dating service to take responsive action against the member who perpetrated the crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(b): (2)(b)(i); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(b)(i): An online dating service provider shall provide a clear and conspicuous method for a Utah member to contact the online dating service provider to report a member who engages in an act of sexual or intimate partner violence, a financial crime, or other misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b)(i); (1) An online dating service provider shall include the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-104(3): An online dating service provider that provides the notification required under this section shall give the notification at the time a Utah member registers with the online dating service provider and by way of a link on the online dating service provider's main website or mobile application.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105 Fraud ban notification.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(1): An online dating service provider shall provide to a Utah member a fraud ban notification if the Utah member has received and responded to a message from a banned member.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(2): (1) A fraud ban notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(2)(a): to the extent permitted by law, the banned member's username, identification number, or other profile identifier;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(2)(b): a statement that the banned member may have been using a false identity or attempting to defraud members;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(2)(c): a statement that a member should not send money or personal financial information to another member; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(2)(d): an online link to information regarding ways to avoid online fraud or being defrauded by a member of an online dating service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3): (1); (3)(c)(ii) A fraud ban notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3)(a): clear and conspicuous;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3)(b): sent by email, text message, or other appropriate means of communication consented to by the Utah member; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3)(c): (3)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3)(c)(i): (3)(c)(ii) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(3)(c)(ii): sent within three days after the day on which a fraud ban is initiated against a banned member if, in the judgment of the online dating service provider, the circumstances require the fraud ban notification be sent after the 24-hour period.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4): 13-67-106 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(a): the means of communication used to issue a fraud ban notification to a Utah member under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(b): the timing of a fraud ban notification sent to a Utah member under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(c): the disclosure of information in a fraud ban notification under this section, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(c)(i): information that a member is a banned member or the subject of a fraud ban;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(c)(ii): the banned member's username, identification number, or other profile identifier; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-105(4)(c)(iii): the reason that the online dating service provider initiated the fraud ban of the banned member.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-106 Violation  --  Enforcement -- Limitations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-106(1): Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection; (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-67-106(1)(a): Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection The division may enforce the provisions of this chapter in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 68 - Lawyer Referral Consultants Registration Act
******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(1): "Attorney" means an individual who is authorized to provide legal services in any state or territory of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(2): "Client" means a person that is provided lawyer referral services by a lawyer referral consultant.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(3): "Compensation" means anything of economic value that is paid, loaned, granted, given, donated, or transferred to a person for or in consideration of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(3)(a): services;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(3)(b): personal or real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(3)(c): another thing of value.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(4): "Digital marketing service" means an Internet-based company that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(4)(a): advertises legal services on behalf of a law firm; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(4)(b): does not contact prospective clients individually.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(5): "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection in the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(6): "Law firm" means an entity consisting of one or more licensed lawyers lawfully engaged in the practice of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(7): "Lawyer referral consultant" means an individual that engages in lawyer referral service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(8)(a): "Lawyer referral service" means assisting a person to find an attorney or law firm that provides legal services in the legal field appropriate for the person's legal matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(8)(b): "Lawyer referral service" does not include a digital marketing service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-101(9): "Legal services" means any form of legal advice or legal representation that is subject to the laws of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(2): A bond under this section shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(2)(a): in a form approved by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(2)(b): conditioned upon the faithful compliance of a lawyer referral consultant with this chapter and division rules; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(2)(c): maintained at all times while the lawyer referral consultant provides lawyer referral services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(3): A lawyer referral consultant shall keep the bond required under this section in force for one year after:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(3)(a): the lawyer referral consultant's registration expires; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(3)(b): the lawyer referral consultant notifies the division in writing that the lawyer referral consultant has ceased all activities regulated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(4)(a): If a surety bond posted by a lawyer referral consultant under this section is canceled due to the lawyer referral consultant's negligence, the division may assess a $300 reinstatement fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(4)(b): No part of a bond posted by a lawyer referral consultant under this section may be withdrawn:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(4)(b)(i): during the one-year period the registration under this chapter is in effect; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(4)(b)(ii): while a revocation proceeding is pending against the lawyer referral consultant.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(5)(a): A bond posted under this section by a lawyer referral consultant may be forfeited if the lawyer referral consultant's registration under this chapter is revoked.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(6): An individual may not disseminate by any means a statement indicating that the individual is a lawyer referral consultant, or proposes to engage in the business of a lawyer referral consultant, unless the individual has posted a bond under this section that is maintained throughout the period covered by the statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-204(7): A lawyer referral consultant may not make or authorize the making of an oral or written reference to the lawyer referral consultant's compliance with the bonding requirements of this section except as provided in this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-301(6): A written contract is void if not written in accordance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-303(1)(a): the full name, address, and evidence of compliance with any applicable bonding requirement including the bond number;

Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-304 Translations -- Prohibited acts.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-304(1): As used in this section, "literal translation" of a word or phrase from one language means the translation of a word or phrase without regard to the true meaning of the word or phrase in the language that is being translated.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-304(2): A lawyer referral consultant may not, with the intent to mislead, literally translate, from English into another language, words or titles, including, "notary public," "notary," "licensed," "attorney," "lawyer," or any other terms that imply that the lawyer referral consultant is an attorney, in any document, including an advertisement, stationery, letterhead, business card, or other comparable written material describing the lawyer referral consultant.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-305 Documents -- Treatment of original documents.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A lawyer referral consultant shall:Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-305(1): deliver to a client a copy of a document completed on behalf of the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-305(2): include on a document delivered to a client the name and address of the lawyer referral consultant;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-305(3): retain a copy of a document of a client for not less than three years from the date of the last service the lawyer referral consultant provides to the client; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-305(4): return to a client all original documents that the client has provided to the lawyer referral consultant.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401 Unlawful acts.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1): It is unlawful for a lawyer referral consultant or any other person to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(a): make a false or misleading statement to a client while providing services to that client;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(b): make a guarantee or promise to a client, unless the guarantee or promise is in writing and there is basis in fact for making the guarantee or promise;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(c): charge a client a fee for referral of the client to another person for services that the lawyer referral consultant cannot or will not provide to the client; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(d): communicate with a prospective client for the purpose of obtaining or referring business if the communication concerns a disaster, or an action for personal injury or wrongful death, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(d)(i): the disaster, injury, or death occurred more than 30 days before the communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(d)(ii): the prospective client is a person who has a prior familial, prior personal, or prior professional relationship with the lawyer to be referred, the lawyer referral consultant, or the person communicating with the prospective client;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(d)(iii): the communication is initiated by the prospective client; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(1)(d)(iv): the communication is requested by a third party who has a prior familial or prior close personal relationship with the prospective client.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-401(2): A sign describing the prohibition described in Subsection (1)(c) shall be conspicuously displayed in the office of a lawyer referral consultant.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402 Violations -- Actions by division.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(1): Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection The division shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(2): The attorney general, upon request, shall give legal advice to, and act as counsel for, the division in the exercise of the division's responsibilities under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3): Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(a): Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection In addition to the division's enforcement powers under
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(a)(i): the division director may impose an administrative fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(a)(ii): the division may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce a provision of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b): In a court action by the division to enforce a provision of this chapter, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(i): declare that an act or practice violates a provision of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(ii): issue an injunction for a violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(iii): order disgorgement of any money received in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(iv): order payment of disgorged money to an injured purchaser or consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(v): impose a fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(3)(b)(vi): award any other relief that the court deems reasonable and necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(4): If a court of competent jurisdiction grants judgment or injunctive relief to the division, the court shall award the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(4)(a): reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(4)(b): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(4)(c): investigative fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(5): 13-2-8
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(5)(a): A person who violates an administrative or court order issued for a violation of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty of no more than $5,000 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(5)(b): A civil penalty authorized under this section may be imposed in any civil action brought by the attorney general on behalf of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(5)(c): 13-2-8 All money received for the payment of a fine or civil penalty imposed under this section shall be deposited into the Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(6)(a): A person who intentionally violates this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(6)(a)(i): is guilty of a class A misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(6)(a)(ii): may be fined up to $10,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-402(6)(b): A person intentionally violates this part if the violation occurs after the division, attorney general, or a district or county attorney notifies the person by certified mail that the person is in violation of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403 Action by attorney general or district or county attorney.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403(1): 13-68-402(2); 13-68-402(4) Upon referral from the division, the attorney general or any district or county attorney may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403(1)(a): bring an action for temporary or permanent injunctive or other relief in any court of competent jurisdiction for any violation of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403(1)(b): 13-68-402(2) bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of penalties authorized under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403(1)(c): 13-68-402(4) bring an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-403(2): A court may, upon entry of final judgment, award restitution when appropriate to any person suffering loss because of a violation of this part if proof of loss is submitted to the satisfaction of the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-404 Recovery of losses.
---------------------------------------------------
In addition to any other remedies, a person suffering pecuniary loss because of a violation by another person of this chapter may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction and may recover:Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-404(1): the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-404(1)(a): $500; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-404(1)(b): twice the amount of the pecuniary loss; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-68-404(2): court costs and reasonable attorney fees as determined by the court.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 69 - Fiduciary Duty for Certain Providers of Legal Services
****************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(1): "Business entity" means a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company, corporation, or other legal entity that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(1)(a): used to carry on a business for profit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(1)(b): a participant in the sandbox.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(2): "Court rule" means rules of procedure, evidence, or practice for use of the courts of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(3): "Out-of-state attorney" means an individual admitted and licensed to practice law in another state or territory of the United States who is authorized by court rule to practice law in this state without being admitted and licensed to practice law in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(4): "Participant" means a business entity or a business entity's officer, director, partner, or employee that provides legal services under the sandbox:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(4)(a): to a person other than the business entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(4)(b): for the business entity's profit.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-69-101(5): "Sandbox" means the regulatory sandbox program established by the Utah Supreme Court for authorizing nontraditional legal service providers to practice law on a limited and temporary basis under Utah Supreme Court Rule of Professional Practice 14-802.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 70 - Automatic Renewal Contracts Act
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(1): "Automatic renewal provision" means a provision under a contract that is automatically renewed at the end of a definite, paid term for a subsequent, paid term that is longer than 45 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2): "Clearly and conspicuously disclose" means to disclose:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2)(a): in print:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2)(a)(i): in larger type than the surrounding text;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2)(a)(ii): in contrasting type, font, or color to the surrounding text of the same size; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2)(a)(iii): in a manner set off from the surrounding text of the same size by symbols or other marks that clearly call attention to the language; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(2)(b): through audio, in a volume and cadence sufficient to be readily audible and understandable.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(3): 13-2-1 "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(4): "Rental agreement" means any agreement, written or oral, which establishes or modifies the terms, conditions, rules, or any other provisions regarding the use or occupancy of real property for residential or commercial purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-101(5): "Trial period offer" means an offer to provide a period of time to sample or use a product or service without payment.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201 Automatic renewal provisions -- Trial period offers -- Notice -- Exceptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(1): Except as provided in Subsection (3), a person who provides an individual a product or service under a contract with an automatic renewal provision shall provide a notice to the individual, at least 30 but not more than 60 days before the day on which the automatic renewal provision renews, that clearly and conspicuously discloses:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(1)(a): the renewal date;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(1)(b): the total renewal cost; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(1)(c): options for cancellation of the contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(2): Except as provided in Subsection (3), a person who provides an individual a trial period offer shall provide a notice to the individual, at least three days before the day on which the period of time under the trial period offer expires, that clearly and conspicuously discloses:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(2)(a): the trial period offer expiration date;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(2)(b): the price to be charged for the product or service, or any further purchase obligations to be imposed on the individual, after the expiration date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(2)(c): options for cancellation of the contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3): 31A-6a-101; 54-2-1; 61-2f-102 This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(a): any individual or entity regulated under Title 31A, Insurance Code, or an affiliate of the individual or entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(b): 31A-6a-101 a person providing a service contract, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(c): a financial institution or an affiliate of a financial institution regulated under Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. Sec. 6801 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(d): 54-2-1 a public utility, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(e): an entity or affiliate of the entity that provides services regulated by the Federal Communications Commission, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, or Federal Professional Services Council;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(f): a rental agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(3)(g): 61-2f-102 an agreement for property management, as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-201(4): An automatic renewal provision that violates this section is void.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301 Administration and enforcement -- Division powers -- Fees -- Rulemaking.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(1): The division shall administer and enforce this chapter in accordance with Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(2): In addition to the division's enforcement powers under Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(2)(a): the division director may impose an administrative fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(2)(b): the division may bring a civil action to enforce this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3): In a civil action by the division to enforce this chapter, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(a): declare that an act or practice violates this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(b): issue an injunction for a violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(c): order disgorgement of any money received after a violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(d): order payment of disgorged money to an injured individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(e): impose a civil penalty of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(3)(f): award any other relief that the court deems reasonable and necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(4): If a court grants judgment or  injunctive relief to the division, the court shall award the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(4)(a): reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(4)(b): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(4)(c): investigative fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(5)(a): A person who violates an administrative or court order issued for a violation of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty of no more than $5,000 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(5)(b): A civil penalty authorized under this section may be imposed in any civil action brought by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(5)(c): The division shall deposit money received for the payment of a fine or civil penalty under this section into the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-70-301(6): The division may make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to enforce this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 71 - Utah Minor Protection in Social Media Act
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(1): "Account holder" means a person who has, creates, or opens an account or profile to use a social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(2): "Age assurance system" means measures reasonably calculated to enable a social media company to identify whether a current or prospective Utah account holder is a minor with an accuracy rate of at least 95%.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(3): "Connected account" means an account on the social media service that is directly connected to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(3)(a): the minor account holder's account; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(3)(b): an account that is directly connected to an account directly connected to the minor account holder's account.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(4): "Content" means any information, visual depictions, tools, features, links, software, or other materials that appear on or are available or enabled through a social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(5): "Directly connected" means an account on the social media service that is connected to another account by:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(5)(a): sending a request to connect to another account holder and having the request to connect accepted by the other account holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(5)(b): receiving a request to connect from another account holder and accepting the request to connect.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(6): "Director" means the director of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(7): 13-2-1 "Division" means the Division of Consumer Protection created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(8): 80-7-102 "Minor" means an individual under 18 years old that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(8)(a): 80-7-102 has not been emancipated as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(8)(b): has not been married.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(9): "Parent" includes a legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(a): "Personal information" means information that is linked or can be reasonably linked to an identified individual or an identifiable individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b): "Personal information" includes a person's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(i): first and last name;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(ii): date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(iii): home or physical address, including street name and city;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(iv): screen or user name that reveals an individual's email address, first name, or last name;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(v): telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(vi): Social Security number;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(vii): photograph, video, or audio file containing a person's image or voice;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(viii): geolocation information sufficient to identify street name and city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(10)(b)(ix): any other identifier that a person may use to contact a specific individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(11): "Push notification" means an automatic electronic message displayed on an account holder's device, when the user interface for the social media service is not actively open or visible on the device, that prompts the account holder to repeatedly check and engage with the social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(12): 53-3-102 "Resident" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(13): "Social media company" means an entity that owns or operates a social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a): "Social media service" means a public website or application that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a)(i): displays content that is primarily generated by account holders and not by the social media company;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a)(ii): permits an individual to register as an account holder and create a profile that is made visible to the general public or a set of other users defined by the account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a)(iii): connects account holders to allow users to interact socially with each other within the website or application;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a)(iv): makes available to each account holder a list or lists of other account holders with whom the account holder shares a connection within the system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(a)(v): allows account holders to post content viewable by other users.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(b): "Social media service" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(b)(i): email;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(b)(ii): cloud storage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(14)(b)(iii): document viewing, sharing, or collaboration services.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(15): "User" means an individual who accesses or uses a social media service.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(16)(a): "Utah account holder" means a person who is a Utah resident and an account holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(16)(b): "Utah account holder" includes a Utah minor account holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(17): "Utah minor account holder" means a Utah account holder who is a minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(18): "Verifiable parental consent" means authorization from a parent for a social media service to collect, use, and disclose personal information of a Utah minor account holder, that complies with the following verifiability requirements:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(18)(a): the social media service shall provide advance notice to the parent describing information practices related to the minor account holder's personal information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-101(18)(b): the social media service shall receive confirmation that the parent received the notice described in Subsection (18)(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102 Legislative findings.
-----------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that:Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(1): the state has a compelling interest in safeguarding the well-being and privacy of minors in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(2): the proliferation of social media services has led to the widespread collection and utilization of personal information, exposing minors to potential privacy and identity related harms;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(3): the addictive design features of certain social media services contribute to excessive use of a social media service by minors, impacting sleep patterns, academic performance, and overall health;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(4): social media services are designed without sufficient tools to allow adequate parental oversight, exposing minors to risks that could be mitigated with proper parental involvement and control;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(5): the state has enacted safeguards around products and activities that pose risks to minors, including regulations on motor vehicles, medications, and products and services targeted to children;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(6): prolonged and unregulated social media use has been linked to adverse effects on the mental health of minors, including increased rates of anxiety, depression, and social isolation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(7): existing measures employed by social media companies to protect minors have proven insufficient; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-102(8): the state should ensure that minors' personal data is given special protection, as minors may have less awareness of the risks, consequences, and safeguards related to a social media company's processing of minors' personal data.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201 Age assurance required.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(1): A social media company shall implement an age assurance system to determine whether a current or prospective Utah account holder on the social media company's social media service is a minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(2): 13-71-202; 13-71-203 A Utah account holder that the social media company identifies as a minor through the use of an age assurance system is subject to the requirements in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(3): A social media company shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(3)(a): implement a review process allowing account holders to appeal the account holder's age designation by submitting documentary evidence to establish the account holder's age range; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(3)(b): review evidence submitted by the account holder and make a determination within 30 days of submission of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-201(4): 13-71-204 A social media company shall segregate any personal information gathered specifically within the age assurance system and shall not use the personal information for any other purposes except for the purposes listed in Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202 Requirements for Utah minor account holders.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A social media company shall, for Utah minor account holders on the social media service:Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1): set default privacy settings to prioritize maximum privacy, including settings that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(a): restrict the visibility of a Utah minor account holder's account to only connected accounts;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(b): limit the Utah minor account holder's ability to share content to only connected accounts;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(c): restrict any data collection and sale of data from a Utah minor account holder's account that is not required for core functioning of the social media service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(d): disable search engine indexing of Utah minor account holder profiles;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(e): restrict a Utah minor account holder's direct messaging capabilities to only allow direct messaging to connected accounts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(1)(f): allow a Utah minor account holder to download a file with all information associated with the Utah minor account holder's account;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(2): implement and maintain reasonable security measures, including data encryption, to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of personal information collected from a Utah minor account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(3): provide an easily accessible and understandable notice that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(3)(a): describes any information the social media company collects from a Utah minor account holder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(3)(b): explains how the information may be used or disclosed;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(4): 13-61-203 upon request of a Utah minor account holder:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(4)(a): 13-61-203 delete the personal information of the Utah minor account holder, unless the information is required to be retained under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(4)(b): remove any information or material the Utah minor account holder made publicly available through the social media service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(5): disable the following features that prolong user engagement:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(5)(a): autoplay functions that continuously play content without user interaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(5)(b): scroll or pagination that loads additional content as long as the user continues scrolling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-202(5)(c): push notifications prompting repeated user engagement.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203 Supervisory tools.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(1): A social media company shall offer supervisory tools for a Utah minor account holder that the Utah minor account holder may decide to activate.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2): The supervisory tools described in Subsection (1) shall include capabilities for an individual selected by the Utah minor account holder to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(a): set time limits for the Utah minor account holder's daily social media service usage across devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(b): schedule mandatory breaks for the Utah minor account holder during selected days and times across devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c): view:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(i): data detailing the Utah minor account holder's total and average daily time spent on the social media service across devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(ii): a list of connected accounts;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(iii): a list of accounts blocked by the Utah minor account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(iv): the Utah minor account holder's:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(iv)(A): privacy settings;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(iv)(B): content sensitivity settings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(c)(iv)(C): direct messaging settings and permissions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-203(2)(d): receive notifications when the Utah minor account holder changes an account setting described in this Subsection (2).


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204 Parental consent -- Data privacy for Utah minor accounts.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(1): 13-71-202 A social media company may not allow a Utah minor account holder to change the default data privacy setting described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(2): A social media company's terms of service related to a Utah minor account holder shall be presumed to include an assurance of confidentiality for the Utah minor account holder's personal information.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(3): The presumption of confidentiality in Subsection (2) may be overcome if the social media company obtains verifiable parental consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4): 13-71-201 The presumption of confidentiality in Subsection (2) does not apply to a social media company's internal use or external sharing of a Utah minor account holder's personal information if the use or sharing is necessary to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(a): maintain or analyze functioning of the social media service;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(b): enable network communications;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(c): personalize the user's experience based on the user's age and location;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(d): display a username chosen by the Utah minor account holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(e): 13-71-201 obtain age assurance information as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-204(4)(f): comply with the requirements of this chapter or other federal or state laws.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301 Enforcement powers.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(1): The division shall administer and enforce the provisions of Part 2, General Requirements, in accordance with Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(2): The attorney general, upon request, shall give legal advice to, and act as counsel for, the division in the exercise of the division's responsibilities under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(a): In addition to the division's enforcement powers under Chapter 2, Division of Consumer Protection:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(a)(i): the division director may impose an administrative fine of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(a)(ii): the division may bring an action in court to enforce a provision of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b): In a court action by the division to enforce a provision of this chapter, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(i): declare that the act or practice violates a provision of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(ii): enjoin actions that violate this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(iii): order disgorgement of any money received in violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(iv): order payment of disgorged money to an injured purchaser or consumer;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(v): impose a civil penalty of up to $2,500 for each violation of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(vi): award actual damages to an injured purchaser or consumer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(b)(vii): award any other relief that the court deems reasonable and necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(c): If a court grants judgment or injunctive relief to the division, the court shall award the division:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(c)(i): reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(c)(ii): court costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(3)(c)(iii): investigative fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(4)(a): A person who violates an administrative or court order issued for a violation of this chapter is subject to a civil penalty of no more than $5,000 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(4)(b): A civil penalty authorized under this section may be imposed in any civil action brought by the division, or by the attorney general on behalf of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-301(5): 13-2-8 All money received for the payment of a fine or civil penalty imposed under this section shall be deposited into the Consumer Protection Education and Training Fund established in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302 Age assurance and verifiable parental consent safe harbor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(1): 13-71-201; 13-71-203 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the division shall make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(1)(a): 13-71-201; 13-71-203 to establish processes and means by which a social media company may:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(1)(a)(i): 13-71-201 assure whether an account holder is a minor in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(1)(a)(ii): 13-71-203 obtain verifiable parental consent in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(1)(b): to establish criteria a social media company may use to determine whether the social media company's age assurance system is 95% accurate.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(2): 13-71-201 A social media company is not subject to an enforcement action for a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-302(3): A social media company is considered to have obtained verifiable parental consent if the social media company obtains parental consent through a mechanism that complies with the rules made by the division as described in Subsection (1)(a)(ii).


Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-401 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-401(1): If any provision of this chapter or the application of any provision to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a final decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-401(2): The provisions of this chapter are severable.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-71-401(3): Nothing in this chapter shall displace any other available remedies or rights authorized under the laws of this state or the United States.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 13 - Chapter 72 - Artificial Intelligence Policy Act
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(1): "Applicant" means a person that applies for participation in the regulatory learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(2): "Artificial intelligence" means a machine-based system that makes predictions, recommendations, or decisions influencing real or virtual environments.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(3): "Artificial intelligence technology" means a computer system, application, or other product that uses or incorporates one or more forms of artificial intelligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(4): "Department" means the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(5): "Director" means the director of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(6): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(7): "Learning agenda" means the areas of artificial intelligence applications, risks, and policy considerations selected by the office for focus by the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(8): 13-72-301 "Learning laboratory" means the artificial intelligence analysis and research program created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(9): 13-74-201 "Office" means the Office of Artificial Intelligence Policy created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(10): "Participant" means a person that is accepted to participate in the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(11): 13-72-302 "Regulatory mitigation agreement" means an agreement between a participant, the office, and relevant state agencies described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(12): "Regulatory mitigation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(12)(a): when restitution to users may be required;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(12)(b): terms and conditions related to any cure period before penalties may be assessed;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(12)(c): any reduced civil fines during the participation term; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-101(12)(d): other terms tailored to identified issues of the artificial intelligence technology.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201 Creation of Office of Artificial Intelligence Policy -- Director appointed -- Duties and authority.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(1): There is created in the department the Office of Artificial Intelligence Policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(2): The executive director of the department shall appoint a director to oversee the management and operations of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3): The office shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(a): create and administer an artificial intelligence learning laboratory program;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(b): consult with businesses and other stakeholders in the state about potential regulatory proposals;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c): make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, establishing:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(i): procedures, requirements, and fees to apply to participate in the learning laboratory program;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(ii): criteria for invitation, acceptance, denial, or removal of participants;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(iii): data usage limitations and cybersecurity criteria for participants;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(iv): required participant disclosures to consumers;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(v): reporting requirements for participants to the office;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(vi): criteria for limited extension of the participation period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(c)(vii): other requirements necessary to administer the learning laboratory; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(d): report annually, before November 30, to the Business and Labor Interim Committee regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(d)(i): the proposed learning agenda for the learning laboratory;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(d)(ii): the findings, participation, and outcomes of the learning laboratory; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-201(3)(d)(iii): recommended legislation from findings from the learning laboratory.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301  Artificial Intelligence Learning Laboratory Program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(1): There is established the Artificial Intelligence Learning Laboratory Program, to be administered by the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(2): The purpose of the learning laboratory is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(2)(a): analyze and research the risks, benefits, impacts, and policy implications of artificial intelligence technologies to inform the state regulatory framework;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(2)(b): encourage development of artificial intelligence technologies in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(2)(c): evaluate the effectiveness and viability of current, potential, or proposed regulation on artificial intelligence technologies with artificial intelligence companies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(2)(d): produce findings and recommendations for legislation and regulation of artificial intelligence.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(a): The office shall periodically set a learning agenda for the learning laboratory that establishes the specific areas of artificial intelligence policy the office intends to study.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(b): In establishing the learning agenda, the office may consult with:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(b)(i): relevant agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(b)(ii): industry leaders;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(b)(iii): academic institutions in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(3)(b)(iv): key stakeholders with relevant knowledge, experience, or expertise in the area.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(4): The office may invite and receive an application from a person to participate in the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(5): The office shall establish the procedures and requirements for sending an invitation and receiving requests to participate in the learning laboratory in accordance with the purposes of the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(6): In selecting participants for the learning laboratory, the office shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(6)(a): the relevance and utility of an invitee or applicant's artificial intelligence technology to the learning agenda;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(6)(b): the invitee or applicant's expertise and knowledge specific to the learning agenda; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(6)(c): other factors identified by the office as relevant to participation in the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-301(7): The office shall work with participants to establish benchmarks and assess outcomes of participation in the learning laboratory.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302 Regulatory mitigation agreements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(1): 13-72-201 A participant who uses or wants to utilize an artificial intelligence technology in the state may apply for regulatory mitigation according to criteria and procedures outlined by the office by rule made under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(2): The office may grant, on a temporary basis, regulatory mitigation to a participant by entering into a regulatory mitigation agreement with the office and relevant agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(3): 13-72-303 To receive regulatory mitigation, a participant must demonstrate that the applicant meets eligibility criteria established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4): A regulatory mitigation agreement between a participant and the office and relevant agencies shall specify:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(a): limitations on scope of the use of the participant's artificial intelligence technology, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(a)(i): the number and types of users;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(a)(ii): geographic limitations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(a)(iii): other limitations to implementation;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(b): safeguards to be implemented; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(4)(c): any regulatory mitigation granted to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(5): The office shall consult with relevant agencies regarding appropriate terms in a regulatory mitigation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(6): A participant remains subject to all legal and regulatory requirements not expressly waived or modified by the terms of the regulatory mitigation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(7)(a): The office may remove a participant at any time and for any reason, and the participant does not have an expectation of a property right or license to participate in the learning laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(7)(b): A participant demonstrating an artificial intelligence technology that violates legal or regulatory requirements or the terms of the participation agreement may be immediately removed from further participation and subject to all applicable civil and criminal penalties.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(8): Participation in the learning laboratory does not constitute an endorsement or approval from the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-302(9): The state shall not be responsible for any claims, liabilities, damages, losses, or expenses arising out of a participant's involvement in the learning laboratory.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303 Regulatory mitigation eligibility requirements -- Application evaluation and admission.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1): To be eligible for regulatory mitigation, a participant shall demonstrate to the office that:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1)(a): the participant has the technical expertise and capability to responsibly develop and test the proposed artificial intelligence technology;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1)(b): the participant has sufficient financial resources to meet obligations during testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1)(c): the artificial intelligence technology provides potential substantial consumer benefits that may outweigh identified risks from mitigated enforcement of regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1)(d): the participant has an effective plan to monitor and minimize identified risks from testing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(1)(e): the scale, scope, and duration of proposed testing is appropriately limited based on risk assessments.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-303(2): To evaluate whether an applicant meets eligibility criteria to receive regulatory mitigation, the office may consult with relevant agencies and outside experts regarding the application.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304 Participation in Artificial Intelligence Learning Laboratory.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(1)(a): The office may approve an applicant to participate in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(1)(b): An approved applicant becomes a participant by entering into a participation agreement with the office and relevant state agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(2): A participant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(2)(a): provide required information to state agencies in accordance with the terms of the participation agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(2)(b): report to the office as required in the participation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(3): The office may establish additional cybersecurity auditing procedures applicable to participants demonstrating artificial intelligence technologies that the office considers higher risk.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(4): A participant shall retain records as required by office rule or the participation agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-304(5): A participant shall immediately report to the office any incidents resulting in consumer harm, privacy breach, or unauthorized data usage, which may result in removal of the participant from the learning laboratory.


Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-305 Program extension.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 13-72-305(1): An initial regulatory mitigation agreement shall be in force for no longer than 12 months.
